story:
Who are we?

Aileen Kyoko and Melanie Evans met at the Maggie Flanigan Acting Studio where they realized their artistic synergy and alignment. They have finally teamed up to produce exciting contemporary theatre together. 

Aileen Kyoko is the playwright, director and original producer of The Year of the Solar Eclipse. Aileen’s work has been featured at The Davenport Theatre, The Producer’s Club, Teatro La Tea and The Playwright’s Loft. As a bi-racial artist, she is determined to tell stories that reflect the diverse world in which we live. Aileen specializes in writing naturalistic dramedies- searching for both the humor and conflicting emotions in this thing we call life.

Melanie Evans is an actor, singer, and producer currently in the First National Broadway tour of Falsettos. She is the first woman of color to understudy and perform the lead role of Rosalie Mullins in the first national broadway tour of School of Rock. Other credits include First National tour of Motown The Musical and Radio City Christmas. Melanie was selected out of 7,000 applicants to participate in the 2015 NBC Diversity showcase at New World Stages in NYC. 

The Year of The Solar Eclipse

  • The play made its World Premiere at the Planet Connections Theatre Festival in July 2018 with 6 performances. It was nominated for 6 awards including: outstanding production, scenic design, original song, performance by leading actresses (2x) and performance by featured actor. 
  • The play follows three women in a shocking year of love lost, love found, and self-discovery. This is a dramedy about the bright and dark sides of relationships and all the brilliant shades in between.

Audience Reaction

We know how to put on a badass show & it's only going to get bigger & better! Here's what the audience said last year:

  • "It's as if it was written for me and about me. Thank you for this show that made me feel understood in the drama and silliness of my own existence." 
  • "Nuanced and full of truth. This play had me laughing then crying within a split second."
  • "Truly original- a must see!"
  • "Contemporary, funny and touching. Perfect casting for a fantastic show led by women."
  • " I truly believed the performances of each and every person."
  • "Beautiful acting."

How will the play be different than last year?

  • After a World Premiere in 2018 with sold out shows, it became clear that there was a demand for this production. As grateful as we are for the theatre festival experience- we are excited to tell the full story that we couldn't due to festival timing limitations. 
  • We have a new script, new characters and big goals for the play which leads us to.......

The Goals

  • To produce the play at a Off Broadway Theatre for at least two weeks.
  • To get the play published.
  • To get the play produced at other theaters across the country. 
  • To create a safe space for artists where they feel acknowledged and respected.
  • To start a movement of women of color behind the scenes as well as onstage. 
  • To tell stories that highlight and empower female sexuality.
  • To dig into the human soul and remind us why we are alive!

Where's That Money Honey?

The Big Money Break Down:

  • Cover the cost of renting a notable theatre for at least two weeks. Its important for us to have access for anyone coming in from all five boroughs, as well as Handicap access, so that as many people as possible can see our play!
  • The money will also cover: sound & lighting, house management, box office ticketing, cleaning services, tech rehearsal, rehearsal spaces, graphic design, web design, set design, costumes, make up, marketing, public relations, actor's needs, photography, props, crew and so much more. 
  • Any funds over our goal will go into making the show the greatest quality it can be and building our funds for future productions!!

Why support our campaign?

  • By contributing you are not only supporting artists of color, who are women, but you are also putting them in a place of power by helping them self produce a modern relatable story.
  • Aileen Kyoko has already done several successful campaigns for her plays and each one was produced and put up with the money invested.
  • A chance to show up for diversity and change in the entertainment industry.
  • What is it inside you that you want to see represented on stage? Truly Equal and Elevated Characters. Raw and Beautiful  Stories that tell the truth about our modern lives.​

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Ever wanted to buy us a coffee? Save that five dollars and donate it to our campaign! We don't need the sugar in that latte anyway!    
  • Can't donate because money is tight? You can STILL join the crusade by SHARING our campaign on Facebook, Instagram, and Twitter and any other social app you may have.
  • Follow us on social media for fun videos and updates: @kyoko_productions, @melevansny and @aileenkyoko. 

Thank you x a million-we love you!

XOXO, 

Aileen & Melanie

story:
Amygdala: (noun) əˈmɪɡdələ

A roughly almond shaped mass of grey matter inside each cerebral hemisphere, involved with the experience of memory and emotions, especially empathy, anger or fear.

“You think that prison is where you need to be ‘cause you’re so tough that society can’t handle you. But...it’s also the place you get a bed, a roof over your head...For me, right now, it’s the only place in the world where someone cares enough to check whether I’m in my bed every night. Even if they are getting paid for it.” 

Kelsey is in prison serving a life sentence for murder. Thea is doing a PhD and thinks she knows everything there is to know about women who kill. But, as her friendship with Kelsey deepens, Thea realises she doesn’t know the first thing about fear or what it can make a you do. Based on true events The Amygdala is a brutally honest portrait of the life of a woman in prison that explores the limits of our capacity for empathy and forgiveness. 

 

As a company of female (trans + cisgender) and LGBTQ+ artists we are committed to promoting gender-equality in the British theatre industry by exclusively showcasing the work of female (trans + cisgender) and LGBTQ+ artists. Lady Muck and Knot Theatre are collaborating on this project in order to support each other as female and LGBTQ+ led companies as well as the development of a new, essential play that challenges social preconceptions about victims of domestic violence, the criminal justice system and the "nature" of women. 

We are raising money to fund our production (rehearsal space, props, costume + set) and to ensure that all the female and LGBTQ+ artists involved are properly and fairly paid. Your contributions will help us to finance a brand new piece of female and LGBTQ+ led theatre and raise awareness about victims of domestic violence in the telling of this crucial story. 

Whether it is 50p, a fiver, £50 or simply sharing this page with others your support would be invaluable to the project and would mean the world to us!

 

Thank you!

 

Lady Muck & Knot Theatre 

 

Creatives:

Writer: Sophie Fox  

Director: Tess Monro

Dramaturg: Hannah Jones

Visuals Designer: Dee Dixon

Sound Designer: Sarah Carton

Cast:

Kelsey: Amelia Gann

Thea: Sophie Fox

story:
What Is VANDALS?

One year after the killing of Heather Heyer at the Charlottesville riots, the world is a different place. A new devised theater piece opening October 12th (previews begin October 10th)  at The Tank , VANDALS, developed over the course of last year, charts our national mood and the crisis of public monuments.

You may know the VANDALS as the tribe responsible for hacking off all the noses and penises from the Roman statues at the Met. VANDALS  adapts a public trial of a war hero/criminal into a founding myth for democracy. It  explores the personal histories of the cast to unearth the question, “What do you need to change about the past in order to live in the present?”

“There’s a debate underway in America,” says co-director Will Hand, “about whether or not words and images can be themselves violent...I wanted to provide a framework for us all to approach this question, ‘how much can we stomach of the past, and what do we have to change to live in today’s America?’  I see this idea being hashed out in a very public way, in museums, in universities, and in theaters.”

Vandals is a theater piece unlike any other. It breaks down moulds of ‘character’ and authorship to create a theater that is surprising, formally experimental, and socially exigent.

 

Who Are We?

The How is a New York City based experimental performing arts collective,
composed of artists of various disciplines from around the world. The How’s mission is to create a place for audiences and artists to be challenged by a multiplicity of viewpoints, forms, and stories. Our co-founders and directors - Will Hand and Polina Ionina - are radical cross-disciplinary upstarts who want New York’s theater to be as international, virtuosic, and diverse as the people who live in it. The How runs monthly concerts showcasing experimental music, theater and dance in Brooklyn, and regularly premieres original works.

We have been devising theatre since 2016 and need your help to continue delivering important stories to American stages and beyond. Premiered at Dixon Place in 2017, The How is looking to premiere VANDALS, featuring Ilker Oztop, Weronika H. Wozniak, Tanya Chattman, Linus Ignatius and David Glover.

 

What Do We Want To Accomplish?

Its time for our premiere. 

  • Pay Our Artists: We worked with a group who refracted and reflected different experiences and viewpoints on vandalism as protest. Our team totals 10 in all, and while the $2,000 we have budgeted won't let us pay them anywhere near what they deserve, it will at the very least be a measure of gratitude for their creativity and virtuosity.  
  • Reach New Audiences: We work fiercely to promote our shows. We put the word out through guerilla techniques like wheatpasting or enlisting bar patrons to vandalize art for instagram, as well as more traditional means like paid advertising. While paying artists is always our highest priority, throwing $1000 into ROI doesn't hurt. 
  • Tell Our Story: The remainder of our funds raised go directly towards helping our design team realize the production.

 

 What Are We Up Against?

 We rely on curatorial opportunities to pioneer new works and experiments. Meanwhile, the face of the underground is changing. 70 performance spaces have disappeared from New York in the past decade, with 10 more in danger of foreclosure.

Bringing a work to premiere is harder than ever, but we are carving out our way one show at a time, all thanks to The Tank, and our fabulous network of friends, fans, and supporters. Thanks to people like you, the candle keeps burning, no matter the attempts at sanitization, gentrification and cultural erasure the developers push forward.

 

 

What Will You Accomplish?

  • The How brings artists from around the world and from across America together. At The How, they're given a context to create, teach, experiment, and thrive.  
  • We put on workshops and classes taught by our diverse and storied collaborators, geared towards performers of every stripe. 
  • Every month we go off leash with The How Concerts, a multidisciplinary performance series that pops up around Brooklyn featuring the best minds of our generation.

 

About Our Perks

We are going to vandalize stuff for you, or we're gonna show you the time of your life. 

 

About The Tank

THE TANK is a Manhattan-based multi-disciplinary arts presenter and producer. Their mission is to remove economic barriers from the creation of new work by artists launching their careers and experimenting within their art form. Their goal is to do this in an environment that is inclusive and accessible to all. The heart of their services is providing free performance space, and they also offer a suite of other resources such as free rehearsal space, artist fees, and promotional support. They keep ticket prices affordable and view their work as democratic, opening up both the creation and attendance of the arts to all.

Under the leadership of Co-Artistic Directors Rosalind Grush and Meghan Finn, in September of 2017, the company moved to their new home in the Theater Building at 312 W 36th Street where they took full control over two theaters: a 98-seat proscenium and a 56-seat blackbox theater. They anticipate that this year we will serve over 2,000 artists presenting 800 performances by emerging artists from throughout the five boroughs.


 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you're jingling change in your pocket wondering if you can afford a deli coffee, you're probably not going to throw $10 onto our Indiegogo. We get it. Keep fighting.

Posts are free, though. So if your heart is in the right place and last week's paycheck didn't pass muster, consider throwing in a good word, a retweet, a like, or a share on social media. Or just tell a friend about us. Or someone whose standing next to you. Or whatever.

 

 

_____________________________________

VANDALS runs October 9th-25th at The Tank, 312 W 36th St NY NY. www.thetanknyc.org Tickets are $15 online at http://vandals.brownpapertickets.com More info at www.thehow.nyc/vandals

story:
Our Story

A foreign army marches through the defeated city of Troy. They destroy every vestige of civilization left after a brutal war. They’ve slaughtered the men and captured the women, whom they brutally assault and separate from their children. Will the only survivors of Troy be massacred as well? Will the women be forced into marriage or slavery by their conquerors or will they be made to live like refugees in their devastated city, subject to the whims and desires of the occupying soldiers? 

Trojan Woman is that rare work of literature that has gained more power and relevance with time... JCTC’s production of Trojan Women highlights women's strength, wisdom and compassion and is meant to spark a conversation about the ways “the others” are dehumanized through prejudice, oppression and violence in society. For thousands of years, men have fought wars, but women endure the aftermath, binding the wounds, mopping up the blood and stitching civilization back together. JCTC has brought diverse team of artists from multiple arts disciplines and cultural backgrounds to create Trojan Women for 21st century audiences. 

Cast

Tatyana Zbirovskaya, Hecuba
Samille Ganges, Hecuba
Natalia Volkodaeva, Andromache
Mahalet Dejene, Cassandra
Dina Manganaris, Helen
Naya A. Desir-Johnson, Astyanax
Steven Martin, Athena/Greek soldier
Zach Hendrickson, Poseidon/Greek soldier
Kevin Terwin, Menelaus/Greek soldier
Oliver Henry Fishman, Talthybius/Greek soldier

Trojan Women: Paula de Lima Torres, Daphnee McMaster, Julia Malinovskaya, Lorena Ibeth Marin Ortiz, Te'ena Klein, Claudia Godi, Sylvana Joyce, Ariel Guidry, and Aizzah Fatima

Greeks: Sanio Kurtesevic and John St. Croix

The Team

Casting:
Lisa Rosetta Strum – Casting Director
Dan Pieraccini – General Manager

Production:
Steven Vessella – Stage Manager
Frank Ippolito – Art and Set Designer and Construction
Lance A Michel – Lighting Designer, Tech Director
Fernando Ayres – Venue Manager, Technician 
Matthew Holowienka – Costume Designer 
Laia Cabrera – Scenography, Video-mapping Projections Design 
Isabella Duverger – Scenography, Video-mapping Projections Design 
Kasia Skorynkiewicz – Video Production
Lucy Rovetto – Image and Art design 
Ekaterina Abramova – Artist, Cover Image 
Jenny Brover – Art Photography

Marketing:
Timothy Herrick – Publicity 
Bang Chau – Graphic design, Photography

Who we are?

Jersey City Theater Center, Inc. (JCTC) – a 501c3 not-for-profit organization was founded in 2006 by Olga Levina, a theater/dance professional and Ben LoPiccolo, an award-winning real estate developer.  We are committed to inspiring conversations about the important topics of our times through innovative and progressive performing and visual arts that embrace the diversity of Jersey City, bringing its community closer together and enhancing its quality of life.

www.jctcenter.org

Why we need your support

We seek $26,000 in funding for our production of Trojan Women.

Funds raised go towards cast and production team costs, buying set materials and costumes, and marketing. Part of our mission is to bring the Jersey City community closer together. We strive to keep our tickets prices affordable for every resident of Jersey City. Your support can help us do this.

Expense summary:

Artistic team for copyrights, director, actors/actresses, set designer, set construction crew, costumer designer, lightning designer, sound designer, projections designer, stage manager, choreographer - $22,208

Production costs for sets, props, costumes, lights, music, food/drink, projectors, and miscellaneous -  $3,850

Marketing budget for flyers, postcards and programs - $720

 

Come support and see the show!

Trojan Women Schedule

Where:  Jersey City Theater Center, Merseles Studio, 339 Newark Ave, Jersey City, NJ 07302

When: November 2-18, 2018; Thursday-Saturday, 8:00PM-9:30PM; Sunday, 6:00PM-7:30PM

Tickets:  General Admission: $25 / Student and Senior: $15 on sale here 

Follow us: 
Instagram, Facebook, Twitter @jctcenter

Desir-Johnson, AstyanaxSteven Martin, Athena/Greek soldierZach Hendrickson, Poseidon/Greek soldierKevin Terwin, Menelaus/Greek soldierOliver Henry Fishman, Talthybius/Greek soldierTrojan Women: Paula de Lima Torres, Daphnee McMaster, Julia Malinovskaya, Lorena Ibeth Marin Ortiz, Te'ena Klein, Claudia Godi, Sylvana Joyce, Ariel Guidry, and Aizzah FatimaGreeks: Sanio Kurtesevic and John St. CroixThe TeamCasting:Lisa Rosetta Strum – Casting DirectorDan Pieraccini – General ManagerProduction:Steven Vessella – Stage ManagerFrank Ippolito – Art and Set Designer and ConstructionLance A Michel – Lighting Designer, Tech DirectorFernando Ayres – Venue Manager, Technician Matthew Holowienka – Costume Designer Laia Cabrera – Scenography, Video-mapping Projections Design Isabella Duverger – Scenography, Video-mapping Projections Design Kasia Skorynkiewicz – Video ProductionLucy Rovetto – Image and Art design Ekaterina Abramova – Artist, Cover Image Jenny Brover – Art PhotographyMarketing:Timothy Herrick – Publicity Bang Chau – Graphic design, PhotographyWho we are?Jersey City Theater Center, Inc. (JCTC) – a 501c3 not-for-profit organization was founded in 2006 by Olga Levina, a theater/dance professional and Ben LoPiccolo, an award-winning real estate developer.  We are committed to inspiring conversations about the important topics of our times through innovative and progressive performing and visual arts that embrace the diversity of Jersey City, bringing its community closer together and enhancing its quality of life.www.jctcenter.orgWhy we need your supportWe seek $26,000 in funding for our production of Trojan Women.Funds raised go towards cast and production team costs, buying set materials and costumes, and marketing. Part of our mission is to bring the Jersey City community closer together. We strive to keep our tickets prices affordable for every resident of Jersey City. Your support can help us do this.Expense summary:Artistic team for copyrights, director, actors/actresses, set designer, set construction crew, costumer designer, lightning designer, sound designer, projections designer, stage manager, choreographer - $22,208Production costs for sets, props, costumes, lights, music, food/drink, projectors, and miscellaneous -  $3,850Marketing budget for flyers, postcards and programs - $720 Come support and see the show!Trojan Women ScheduleWhere:  Jersey City Theater Center, Merseles Studio, 339 Newark Ave, Jersey City, NJ 07302When: November 2-18, 2018; Thursday-Saturday, 8:00PM-9:30PM; Sunday, 6:00PM-7:30PMTickets:  General Admission: $25 / Student and Senior: $15 on sale here Follow us: Instagram, Facebook, Twitter @jctcenter

story:
“DORIAN” A Wilde Rock Musical. 

https://lwtheatres.co.uk/whats-on/dorian-the-musical/ 
 

WHAT IT IS?

The magic of Oscar Wilde is derived from the fact that his renowned plays and stories can easily be transported from the Victorian parlours from where they originated to a more dangerous, spellcasting, timeless and alternative world. That’s what Ruby In The Dust have done with their production of "DORIAN", transforming it into a ‘Rock Musical’. 

Set in a fantasy world; it is a London as we know it, but with a glam coating that fits perfectly with this modern-day, rock musical retelling of “The Picture of Dorian Gray”. “DORIAN” began its life as a gala evening at Café Royal, in the very room where Oscar Wilde used to entertain his bohemian, musician, actor friends and gave readings of his work. John Gray, the real-life inspiration for the character of “Dorian”, was one of these guests. Staged on Oscar Wilde’s birthday, one could almost feel his presence in the room. Through various incarnations it has now morphed into a musical and we have now been invited to present it at the Other Palace in March 2020.

WHAT WE NEED

To realise this opportunity, we need to raise the funds to pay all the creatives (cast and crew). The costs of putting on a showcase of a new musical invariably exceeds any potential income that can be expected from ticket sales. To do justice to the script and the musical score we have assembled a hugely talented cast and creative team. The importance of getting this right is essential to the show being picked up by major investors and producers. Which is where you come in as the all-important catalysts in setting us off on this wonderful journey, and with your support you can also be a part of this production which, barely announced to the public, is already creating quite a buzz.

SO WHERE WILL YOUR MONEY GO?

Beyond paying for the talents of the cast, your pledges will create the backdrop of the story by helping to build our designer’s concept for the set:

 

And realise the vision of our costume designer’s Wilde but wild concept:

And, of course, with a Rock Musical, getting the sound right is crucial. Your support will give us access to the necessary audio equipment needed to do justice to the score. The show will feature a mix of live music and pre-recorded soundscapes. The latest sound cueing technology is in place, but radio mics do not come cheap. Not to mention our Musical Director.

We are looking towards a target of £5,000. Any pledge, however large or however small will come with its own unique rewards, but also give the satisfaction that you will have been instrumental in helping to create a unique piece of musical theatre. ‘Dorian Gray’ has never been staged as a full musical in the UK – and certainly not a Rock Musical. The time is right. All the money we can raise for this will be shared equally among the actors, musicians and technicians and go towards the necessary hardware expenses to bring Wilde’s ghostly tale to life.  

We feel that this is as much an opportunity for you, as well as us, to be involved in making many people’s dream come true. Please do share this campaign to and spread the word. 

There is no upper limit to your pledge. Every penny raised will not only help realise this production.

 

ABOUT THE COMPANY

Ruby in the Dust was formed by director/writer Linnie Reedman and composer/musician/writer/ Joe Evans. Together, they’ve brought more than 12 productions to the stage that run the gamut from the fringe to the West End. They’ve proven their skill at integrating original and interpolated music into the text. Of Bonnie and Clyde, The Times critic wrote that it conjured a “powerful visual and musical atmosphere.” They’ve won raves for their musical shows and because the stamp of authenticity that they place on every production is simultaneously true to its roots and boldly original, they’ve been able to use music that already claims a steadfast audience and introduce it to new ones. They received the blessing of the Cole Porter Estate to use several Porter compositions for their production of Hutch. The late Dr John gave them permission to use several of his songs for their New Orleans jazz inspired version of A Midsummer Night’s Dream, setting Shakespeare’s magical tale in the Jazz Clubs of Bourbon Street and the dark, moody mystery of the Louisiana bayous. Their adaptation of The Great Gatsby was developed with Royal Shakespeare Company’s director Adrian Noble, and recently has enjoyed a sell-out run as a Concert Performance at London’s famous ‘Crazy Coqs’ in Piccadilly. The Telegraph said of the production of the F. Scott Fitzgerald classic that it “grips throughout”.

Ruby in the Dust ( www.rubyinthedusttheatre.london ) are a theatre company who have developed theatre pieces around complex relationships taken from biographies or classical works, and finding the contemporary relevance which illuminates the work; thus engaging our audiences by allowing them to identify with the issues and the personalities presented. Although the source material is often from a particular period in history, it is always rendered ‘timeless’, reflecting the current political and social climate of today. But without detracting from the fact that it is great theatre.

THE TEAM

CAST

KEITH RAMSAY - Dorian Gray

FIA HOUSTON-HAMILTON - Sibyl Vane

JOHANNA STANTON - Lady Henry

LEWIS RAE - Basil Hallward

JOHN ADDISON - Lord Henry


PLEASE SEE THE 'UPDATES' SECTION FOR FURTHER NEWS, IMAGES AND AN AUDIO/VISUAL JOURNEY OF OUR PRODUCTION).
 

PRODUCTION TEAM

Linnie Reedman
Writer/Director

Joe Evans
Composer
https://www.joeevans.london

Kate Edwards
Producer

Henry Brennan
Musical Director
https://www.henrybrennanmusic.co.uk 

Belle Mundi
Costume Designer
http://www.bellemundi.com 

Justin Williams
Set Designer
http://www.justinwilliamsdesign.com 

Dominic Warwick
Lighting Designer

 

PLEASE SEE THE 'UPDATES' SECTION FOR FURTHER ANNOUNCEMENTS OF THE CREATIVE TEAM, NEWS, IMAGES AND AN AUDIO/VISUAL JOURNEY OF OUR PRODUCTION).

story:
WHAT IS BLUNDERLAND

Decadent, irreverent, hilarious, queer, psychedelic, naughty, and surreal

Born out of both New York Underground Club and contemporary cabaret culture. We are more than just another variety show, we are a call to arms for a life lived at the limits of your imagination, an insistence on expression, a seduction, and heady dose of more than the legal amount of mischief. 

A decade in and we are one of the premier variety shows in NYC with monthly shows at the infamous House of Yes. 2 Years ago we started doing shows in New Orleans followed by London and now in 2020, it is time for our greatest adventure yet as we head down to AUSTRALIA for the Adelaide Fringe Festival!!!

12 artists representing our casts from each of our current home bases will perform a run of 27 shows at the largest arts festival in the southern hemisphere!!!

 

What we need...

Well, we started looking at numbers and to our surprise, airlines do not allow you to treat them like a clown car. So a real budget happened and it had many zeros, the number we kept coming up with was between $85,000 and $120,000. WOW!!

Why so many zeros?!?

Well...

  • Festival: Fees, equipment, marketing, printing, tech, insurance.
  • Artists: Airfare, housing, and payment for 12 performers for 5 weeks in Australia
  • Creative: Aerial equipment, costumes, design, media, music licensing

It all adds up!! To present a brilliant show on the other side of the globe is AMBITIOUS!!  So we started raising funds and now are so close!! With about $35,000 we can make this incredibly ambitious show happen and take it around the world!!! With more the sky is the limit to what we can do!!!

And shucks do we have some fun items and experiences for folks who wanna help. 

The Impact

Blunderland is as much about community as it is about entertainment, we have been lucky in how we have created an international web of weirdos and wondermakers, we participate in the artistic and local communities we perform in. We create opportunities for our performers and foster collaboration between various creatives. 

There are very few American shows in the genre of variety which have tackled the international circuit in the way we are about to!

Here we are, a show that started a decade ago about to play 27 shows in a 450 seat circus tent halfway around the world. And that is just the beginning!! 

This rabbit hole is primed and Alice is ready to jump!!!

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't help with a donation today please feel free to make some noise on social media about our efforts, come and see a show sometime, or just think nice thoughts about us clowns and we figure out how to take over the world!!

story:
COLLATERAL & CO.

PRESENTS 

DUST HORIZON: DANCE, FILM AND LANDSCAPE INSPIRED BY THE POETRY OF GAILMARIE PAHMEIER

APRIL 25, 2019, 6:30PM

APRIL 27, 2019, 2:00PM

NEVADA MUSEUM OF ART 

160 W. LIBERTY ST. 

RENO, NV

Inspired by the poetry of Gailmarie Pahmeier, this multi-media dance performance presented by Collateral & Co. Contemporary Dance Company at the Nevada Museum of Art explores the landscape of Nevada through choreography, photography, and film.

Gailmarie Pahmeier is a recipient of Nevada Art Council’s esteemed Project Fellowship Grant and has spent the last year in residency at a variety of Nevada state parks composing narratives about her experience focusing on the people and environments she encounters in these often remote places. Inspired by Pahmeier’s writings, Collateral & Co. traveled to three Nevada State Parks: Washoe Lake State Park, Wild Horse Reservoir, and Valley of Fire, to record and document movement in the landscapes. In this special event, Pahmeier’s poetry combined with Collateral & Co. live and recorded movement will bring the vast and ever-changing beauty of Nevada’s landscape to the Nevada Museum of Art for two multi-sensory nights of poetry, film and dance.

Collateral & Co. Contemporary Dance Company was founded in May 2017 when Founder and Artistic Director, Caitlin McCarty, returned home to the Reno, Nevada area after working for New York-based Gallim Dance. Collateral & Co. explores the intricacies of the human experience and investigates the nuances of everyday life. The company recently welcomed, Leslie Balzer, also a native Nevadan, as their Assistant Artistic Director.

story:
EXCAVATION Spring 2019 Workshop

I am developing my first full-length original theater project! I need help!

EXCAVATION is a multi-medium theatre project that uses my Appalachian heritage and my family’s oral history as an arena for excavating lineages of settler-colonialism in the Americas.

I grew up with a super-granma who imparted me with story after story about my Appalachian ancestors. In EXCAVATION, I turn to Gigi’s stories to try to understand more about grief, intergenerational trauma, and home. Once I begin digging, however, I end up in a much bigger confrontation with my settler-colonizer ancestors.

EXCAVATION looks at how the stories we pass on shape our understandings of ourselves and the world we live in. Working within Appalachian story-telling forms, I look at how me and my family have used stories to obscure our roles in the history and persistence of colonization, and to deny culpability. But I also go to these same forms, these same stories, to ask how these traditions could be transformed and used in the service of decolonizing.

This is a piece of interdisciplinary story-telling -- incorporating text, movement, acapella singing, and live soundscape --  and presented within a ritual container which lives somewhere at the intersection of folk magic and church!

I'm currently in my first developmental workshop with an ensemble and full creative team!  Yahoo!  I am moved, excited, terrified, and so grateful. I need to pay them, plus cover other expenses incurred during this 7-week workshop period. I am planning on securing grant funding for future development, but right now, I still need your help! Any contribution would mean so much to me. 
 

My Collaborators

Azure D. Osborne Lee (director)
Marisela Grajeda Gonzalez (dramaturg)
Ali Dineen (music director)
Athena Zammit (design)

Performers: Dominic Bradley, Jennifer Cendaña Armas, Mariah Plante, Jai Mohan, Alessandra Ruiz
 

What We Need

What we need to cover with this crowdfunding campaign:
Performer Stipends - $1500
Creative & Production Team Stipends - $1050
Performance & Tech space - $225
Costumes & props - $150
Indiegogo Fees - $235

What we hope to cover with ticket sales:
books & printing - $75
casting notice postings - $75
office & art supplies - $25
snacks for weekend rehearsals - $75

Leftovers:
Last September I did a smaller Indiegogo campaign to help cover the expenses of a developmental residency for this project. I exceeded my goal by $243. I used that money towards the cost of liability event insurance for the upcoming showing this spring ($250, required by venue). 

If we surpass our goal again, any excess funds will be used towards future development, and/or to cover any remaining expenses not covered by ticket sales. 

 

The Impact

This is a piece of devised theater. Which means that it is being created in close collaboration with the ensemble and creative team. Most of it is not pre-scripted. Our rehearsals are generative. I love creating in this way. I love process-oriented, ensemble-driven work. It is my favorite kind of theater. But it does take time.

This spring workshop is the first of a series of workshop periods I'll be conducting over the next couple years as this project progresses. Between each workshop, I'll take time to write and ruminate and revise in response to what gets created in rehearsals.

My collaborators play a central role in this process, and it's important that I compensate them for their labor. Being a performing artist in NYC takes HUSTLE.  As public funding for the arts decreases, finding paid (even lowly paid) gigs is getting harder and harder. It's a labor of love, and your contribution can help us keep it up. 

Thank you so much!!!

 

Other Ways You Can Help

You can share this campaign with other folks who may be able to donate! That would be huge!

We would also love and appreciate labor donations in the form of:

  • production assistants (help with DIY lights, sound, props, set up, & errands during tech week)
  • help with creating & formatting the paper program for the showing
  • help with creating small flyers for the showing
  • help with photo & video documentation
  • contribute food to share at the showing and/or provide a meal for a rehearsal


And most of all, if you are in or near NYC, please please come to our work-in-process showing on May 31! Contact me for details :)

story:
Blood Bank: A Theatre Noir

Based loosely on the Bon Iver song of the same name, Blood Bank is a play in the noir genre that explores infidelity, stagnancy, the dangers of comfort, and the price of secrecy.

  • Written by Emma Ecklund and Directed by Lena Kutscher
  • We are looking to cover basic costs to put up the full production at this year's NYSummerfest
  • Funding will go towards festival application/participation fees, costumes, props, set, transportation

What We Need

  • We were recently accepted to put up the full play at NYSummerfest!
    • This is super cool, but it costs money!
    • Your donation will help us get our NYSummerfest production on its feet, and to get the first full length production of Blood Bank on its way
  • We are also submitting Blood Bank to other festivals around the city/country
    • This is also super cool, and also costs money!
  • If we don't reach our goal here, we will continue fundraising through other methods, hopefully (at the very least) gathering enough funds to have a successful production at Summerfest and other festivals

Production

We are so excited to have the opportunity to produce Blood Bank in its entirety in New York City. This will be our first professional theatrical endeavor outside of our undergrad.

We are currently working on presenting a 20 minute "trailer" production of the script for our Senior Capstone Project, which will be going up April 19th and 20th.

Risks & Challenges

It is expensive to produce theatre anywhere - particularly in New York City. It is even more difficult to get a brand new work of theatre out into the world.

  • Due to the current state of the Coronavirus/COVID-19 Pandemic, our Capstone Production of this show lies in jeopardy, and is at risk of being canceled altogether. While this entire situation is remarkably stressful and scary, the potential of losing our Capstone is a huge morale blow.
  • Though we both have experience in theatre production, working outside of an institution is a new frontier for us
  • Putting up a full-length play is a massive undertaking, particularly in a festival setting

Other Ways You Can Help

Can't spare any money? No worries! You can also help us out these ways:

  • Follow us on Instagram @bloodbanktheplay
  • Share our campaign on all your social media accounts
  • Come see our Capstone Presentation April 19-20 (in theory)

Written by Emma Ecklund and Directed by Lena Kutscher
We are looking to cover basic costs to put up the full production at this year's NYSummerfest
Funding will go towards festival application/participation fees, costumes, props, set, transportation


What We Need

We were recently accepted to put up the full play at NYSummerfest!
This is super cool, but it costs money!
Your donation will help us get our NYSummerfest production on its feet, and to get the first full length production of Blood Bank on its way


We are also submitting Blood Bank to other festivals around the city/countryThis is also super cool, and also costs money!

If we don't reach our goal here, we will continue fundraising through other methods, hopefully (at the very least) gathering enough funds to have a successful production at Summerfest and other festivals

Due to the current state of the Coronavirus/COVID-19 Pandemic, our Capstone Production of this show lies in jeopardy, and is at risk of being canceled altogether. While this entire situation is remarkably stressful and scary, the potential of losing our Capstone is a huge morale blow.

story:
LIVE PUPPET THEATER!

The streamers are hung, the punch has been spiked, and the cake is just begging to be eaten! Now all Bill has to do is wait for his guests to arrive. But waiting is hard.  Bill’s 44th is an original comedic show that brings two puppeteers together to create one (very worried) protagonist. Many styles of puppetry, raucous balloons, and a cheeky piece of crudité all collide to examine the pitfalls of impatience and the wonder of loneliness.

Originally slated to premiere in 2020, Bill will finally have his time to shine in at Dixon Place in NYC: 

June 2-5th

to a limited live audience and simultaneous live-streamed broadcast.  

June 7th-14th

the show will be available to watch 'on demand'

 

The road to get here

Bill's 44th began as a response to a Puppet Slam (a slam is a night of puppet theater shorts typically all created in response to a theme) commission from Puppet Homecoming. The prompt, "They're coming," made us want to make a piece about someone waiting for their birthday guests to arrive. We ended up having other work during that time so the idea sat on a shelf until Dixon Place's 'Puppet Blok' in 2018. 

Bill sprung to life and after a lovely first response we decided to try our hand at making the show a full-length piece of puppetry. 2019 involved us applying and receiving the Jim Henson Foundation's Production Grant, and experimenting with a ton of new ideas that almost all were thrown out (Sorry Bill's mom!). Nearing the end of 2019 we were accepted to Puppet Lab at St. Ann's Warehouse where we planned to develop 20 minutes of shiny new content for the show.

Of course, the world changed, and a lot of plans got put on hold, but Bill pushed on in the digital realm. We were commissioned by the New York State Puppetry Festival as the first piece in their NYSPF@HOME series. We completed rewrote the show and made a 30 minute 'ZOOM' Version. We destroyed our apartment, but we had a lot of fun in process!

Now Dixon Place is ready to open up to a limited audience!! And we are overjoyed to completely retool the show for this new set of circumstances.

If you want tickets, but don't want any sweet rewards:
http://dixonplace.org/performances/bills-44th-0...
 

What We Need & What You Get

We need your help to cover costs of transportation, wardrobe, rehearsal space, documentation, contingency, additional props and puppets, and the fees of our incredible team of artists and designers.

$350 will cover transportation costs (truck rental for moving set, props, puppets from studio to theater and back)
$200 will cover wardrobe costs (costumes and laundry)
$350 to go towards documentation (production photos, addition video coverage)
$1000 will go towards sourcing props and the designing and construction of additional puppets.
$1000 will cover rehearsal space.
$3800 will be going to pay our stage manager, designers, dramaturg, and camera op!
$300 to cover contingency (Indiegogo fees, unforeseen expenses)

 

A Breakdown of The Goodies You'll Receive:

$10 - Party Hats
- “Special Thanks” credit in the program (physical or digital)

$25 - Tasteful Crudité Platter
- “Special Thanks” credit in the program (physical or digital)
- Thank you card

$40 - Punch Bowl
- “Special Thanks” credit in the program (physical or digital)
- Thank you card
- Bill’s 44th mug

$50 - Virtual Party Guest
- “Special Thanks” credit in the program (physical or digital)
- Thank you card
- Tickets to the Live-Stream!

$65 - That Guy with the Guitar
- “Special Thanks” credit in the program (physical or digital)
- Thank you card
- Digital Download of the Bill’s 44th Soundtrack by Eamon Fogerty

$75 - Balloon Army
- “Special Thanks” credit in the program (physical or digital)
- Thank you card
- Digital Download of the Bill’s 44th Soundtrack by Eamon Fogerty
- Your choice of a Bill’s 44th T-shirt *OR* tote bag

$100 - Icing on the Cake
- “Special Thanks” credit in the program (physical or digital)
- Thank you card
- Digital Download of the Bill’s 44th Soundtrack by Eamon Fogerty
- Tickets to the Live-Stream
- Access to Bill’s 44th: A Zoom Birthday Edition
- Your choice of a Bill’s 44th T-shirt, tote bag, *OR* mug

$300 - Confetti Cannon
- “Special Thanks” credit in the program (physical or digital)
- Digital Download of the Bill’s 44th Soundtrack by Eamon Fogerty
- Tickets to the Live-Stream
- Access to Bill’s 44th: A Zoom Birthday Edition
- A Bill’s 44th T-shirt, tote bag, *AND* mug
- Hand-cut Thank You Card by Dorothy

$500 - HAPPY BIRTHDAY!
- “Special Thanks” credit in the program (physical or digital)
- Digital Download of the Bill’s 44th Soundtrack by Eamon Fogerty
- Tickets to the Live-Stream
- Access to Bill’s 44th: A Zoom Birthday Edition
- A Bill’s 44th T-shirt, tote bag, *AND* mug
- Hand-cut Thank You Card by Dorothy
- Puppetry 101 Workshop with Andy & Dorothy

$1000 - Super-Patron of Puppetry Arts
- Producer Credit on this and any future productions of Bill’s 44th
- Hand-cut Thank You Card by Dorothy
- The glory of knowing that you are an ultimate Patron Of The Arts

 

 

The Impact

Theater has been gone for so long.
Bill has been waiting.
We all have been waiting.
Let us share our art with you.
 

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Please share the campaign to friends and family and theater folk.
  • You can join our Late Night Puppet Talk Show Patreon (Bill is occasionally a guest)!

THANK YOU <3

story:
Short Summary

Hi everyone!

My name is Gaëlle Le Vu and I am addicted to Brazilian Zouk – it's very healthy though, I promise!

I have taught different forms of dancing since 2009, although I am also an eternal learner and that's how I like to see myself the most. I have done pole dancing, circus, oriental dancing, many couple dances, but Brazilian Zouk was the one that touched me the most, from the first seconds I laid my eyes on it.

Photo above - Freddy & Andressa - Students of Renata Pecanha, from whom I learnt all my Zouk basics and more, in Helsinki, Finland.

People say "dance is an art", "dancing is just dancing", or even that "dancing is a way to forget your problems". For me, it is way more than that. Zouk, in particular, has transformed me as a person. It has transformed the way I interact with people, the way I see life; it has inspired me in so many ways and given me so many ideas. It has helped me become more creative and listen to the music in sublime new ways... The list is endless.

For this reason, my project is to raise enough money so I can make a documentary about Zouk in Rio. Since Zouk is very popular here, and I am here right now, I want to take advantage of this time to make a documentary that will finally showcase what Zouk is like.

I want this to not only make zoukers proud that they are dancing Zouk, but also bring awareness about the dance to the rest of the world, and try to faithfully showcase everything that zoukers experience through this unique dance.

In case you are not a Zouk dancer yourself, here are two demos of (I dare say...) probably the most famous Zouk couple in Rio, the King and Queen of improvisation:




What We Need & What You Get

The sum of €1.200 is the bare minimum to make this happen. If we have less, it might become more of a long article with a few video shots, rather than a video documentary. If we meet the goal, we can make it happen with friends' help.
And if we get more, we can make something even nicer and more professional!

Money will be used, depending on how much we actually raise, for:

  • Equipment and video production: cameras, sound. Compensation for those who worked on and edited all the videos, including the pitch video, the updates and the documentary itself.
  • Compensation for people in the video: dancers. People who are giving us a lot of their time.
  • Transport for the crew going around the city to go to different schools and meet different people. Food, too (and a LOT of water in that hot Brazilian sun...)
  • Compensation for people who will spend time on the perks, like writing/making a video for blog posts or giving private lessons, etc.
  • If we don't reach the goal, the money will still go into these things, except that we will most likely not afford a cool camera and the documentary might have to remain at the level of an article with a few videos in it, filmed with phones :(
    So pleaaaase help us make this project come alive!

  • PERKS!!! Check out the perks on the right to see what you can get ;)

The Schedule

We started the project with whatever little resources we had on the 23th of February and will keep filming, visiting, meeting people for a month!

The more money we receive during that time, the more we can invest into the project to make it good.


The Impact

I personally hope that people find something in Zouk that moves them and makes them want to open their hearts more. Also I hope it will help change opinions about Zouk, or simply make people aware that it exists and maybe even make them want to try it!

I've heard so many stories about Zouk. That it's all a "show", that it's some crazy dance with girls shaking their heads around, that it's too sensual or even sexual. Sure, it can also be all of that, but it is also many other things and I want to show the potential it has. I want to develop the ideas I try to spread through my blog (ZoukSide Down) and put it into a visual format so more people can access it.

In the end, Zouk is what you make out of it :)

Other Ways You Can Help

Some of you might want to help, but are just not able to contribute money. That doesn't mean you can't help, though!

  • Spread the word, share this page with your friends! You can use the Indiegogo share tools.
  • Like our Facebook page!

And last but not least, every "penny" goes a loooong way! We will all really appreciate any type of contribution to this project. Each one of you who contributes is going to help bring Zouk out there, into the open :)

Check out our updates directly on the blog ZoukSide Down or on this Facebook page.

story:
WHO is Leila?

LOVE WITH LEILA tells the story of a charming, flamboyant and bearded Persian woman, who lives to please her parents and lose herself in love. Leila knows exactly who she is, proudly living her life out loud. But when Leila meets her Prince Charming, falling in love for the first time, her world is turned upside down. Is love really all it’s cracked up to be?

Leila is the star of her own hit one (wo)man show -  LOVE WITH LEILA. She was first discovered in BORDERLAND - a one man show about gay rights in the middle east and immigration for queer refugees. While that is being redeveloped with dramaturge and mentor Liza Balkan, Leila has stolen the spot light with her own story all about love and beauty. 

“Love With Leila treads the oft-told tale of love and loss in a completely unique way, tickling you with plenty of laughs and leaving you with a powerful punch of a message- that the one person really worth loving may be a lot closer than you think” - Anne Bokma, Raise The Hammer

LOVE WITH LEILA premiered at the Hamilton Fringe Festival 2014, performing to rave reviews, standing ovations, sold out performances and critics choice. The show subsequently played in Toronto for one sold out performance at The One More Night Festival. Leila then stole the holiday spotlight with her Christmas spectacular, A VERY LEILA CHRISTMAS which premiered at Buddies In Bad Times in Toronto. The View Magazine named "Anything Leila" the BEST OF HAMILTON 2014 and Etemadi returned to support the Hamilton Immigrant Women’s Centre with a storytelling workshop, which concluded in a performance on “Leila’s Girlfriends” on International Women’s Day 2015. This summer LOVE WITH LEILA will be performed in Toronto, Hamilton, Stratford, Ottawa, Port Hope, Winnipeg, Savary Island and Halifax. 

"Etemadi is easily the most innovative and enigmatic performer and writer in the area"
- Tamara Kamermans, The View Magazine

Most importantly - and what we are really excited about right now - is that Leila is attempting to break the internet with her own WEB SERIES premiering May 1st! Her first video is The Fresh Queen of Tehran (curse you Jimmy Fallon for doing the parody 3 months before ours!) . We are planning to produce 2 hilarious videos every month, including Leila Doing Hot Yoga, Leila gets her tarot cards read, Leila gets Tinder, Leila finds a mason jar, Leila dates a black guy and renditions of hit songs such as Problem and Let It Go.

Leila loves performing for her beautiful amazing audience! But being a new immigrant to Canada without a high paying job makes producing all of these projects difficult. So we are turning to you! If we make our goal and then some, we promise to NEVER crowd fund for Leila again! We hope that this initial investment in the project will be enough to get things rolling!

WHAT does she need?

Leila needs $5000! Where will it go?

Festival Costs - $2000

Dramaturgy - $500

Rehearsal Period - $750

Costumes and Props - $150

Travel Costs - $1000

Web Series Director - $400

Web Series Production Costs - $200

If (***when) we surprass our goal, everything will go towards a new camera that Leila can take on tour with her to continue creating the web series! 

The camera Leila is looking at is around $2000

HOW else can you help her?

We understand times are tough. If you like Leila and still want to contribute, how about liking us on Facebook and following us on Instagram and Twitter (AND SUBSCRIBING ON YOUTUBE!!). Spread the word! If you can make it out to a live performance we would love to have you there! And if you have any ideas, or want to get involved somehow - contact us! We love making new friends! (PS - Leila is single and looking - to apply please forward a bank statement and last years tax return to lovewithleila@gmail.com)

We understand times are tough. If you like Leila and still want to contribute, how about liking us on Facebook and following us on Instagram and Twitter (AND SUBSCRIBING ON YOUTUBE!!). Spread the word! If you can make it out to a live performance we would love to have you there! And if you have any ideas, or want to get involved somehow - contact us! We love making new friends! (PS - Leila is single and looking - to apply please forward a bank statement and last years tax return to lovewithleila@gmail.com)

story:
Hello, 

I am Lucy Warren-Whitman, the Artistic Director of North Atlantic dance Theatre (formerly known as North Atlantic Ballet).  As we are beginning preparations for our 2015 season, we at North Atlantic Dance Theatre have been tasked with the chore of raising funds for this season's performances and we are in need of your support. 
Who are we?

North Atlantic Dance Theatre  is a collaborative dance company challenging audiences with emotionally charged performances. We offer smaller classical ballets that are rarely seen and present audiences with the opportunity to embrace these powerful stories and become enchanted by them. We also nurture and encourage Dancers, Choreographers, Musicians, and Visual Artists to use the company as a platform to mold their talents and ideas; to create innovative and visually stimulating performances for our audiences and artist communities. 

North Atlantic Dance Theatre performed Vivaldi's Four seasons in September. This was made possible by supporters like you, making donations to our "Let's get this party started" Indiegogo fundraiser. The funds we raised made it possible for us to rent a theater, pay dancers, cover costume materials, hire visual artists and rent space for rehearsals. Not to mention we were also able to collaborate with Horsegod Productions on film and improvisational projection during the performances. Our first show was a success due to your support. So what's next for NAB? Well...

Scheherazade :  A mystical tale of passion, betrayal and love’s conquests. The 1001 Arabian nights comes alive through the storytelling of Scheherazade. Unlike most stage productions this story begins with Scheherazade’s arrival as the Sultan's newest bride. Her daring  struggle for her survival depends on her skill in storytelling and keeping the Sultan enthralled night after night for 1001 nights; less she be murdered as all the brides were fated before her. Her single act of bravery saves the lives of countless women as she teaches the Sultan the power of love and forgiveness. This production includes a collaboration with local Artists and musicians. By recreating a prologue through Anime while the stories come alive around the theater. Anime. live music and Dance that comes alive in the audience. Yes please.

Choreographer's Collective : 3 voices, 3 ideas, 3 new original ballets. Three local choreographers will share their vision with the company creating new works for NADT. This will be a great opportunity for dancers and emerging choreographers. We will be joined by One established choreographer, one up & coming, and one ambitious new choreographer.

Why should you help?

"If art is to nourish the roots of our culture, society must set the artist free to follow his vision wherever it takes him."

-John F. Kennedy

The life of a company relies mainly on donations from supporters, such as yourself. Your donation helps to give North Atlantic Dance Theatre the freedom to be creative without the weight of cost hindering our creative process. Myself and many other dancers have spent the better part of our lives in pursuit of dance, we have struggled to find a place to dance, built on the integrity of their creative achievements.  This is no small endeavor.  The dancers at North Atlantic Dance Theatre have been clamoring for this kind of place, a home, a safe haven. A place here they can pour their heart and soul into every performance and share it with you: 

Our supporters. 

And with your support, North Atlantic Dance Theatre will be that home. We offer new ideas with lots of energy, a sense of community, and an urge to collaborate with other artists to keep our art form fresh, but we need your support to help these ideas become realities. 

Ready to help?

YOu can go through this Indiegogo campaign or for a tax deduction donation go through our website support page:

www.northatlanticdancetheatre.squarespace.com/s...


What we need:

$30,000 will get us there. This includes:

  • Theater ($3,000-$6,000/week)
  • Lighting/tech crews ($300-$1000/show)
  • Dancers ($6,000),
  • Choreographers ($5,000-$6,000)
  • Costumes ($2,000)
  • Collaborators such as artists and musicians ($2,000)
  • Renting a dance floor ($500-$1000/week)
  • Advertising ($1,000)

What you get:

Karma, be a Friend, Young Professional, Sponsor, Benefactor or Patron

Karma $25

  • You just want to see us succeed and want to help out.

Friend $ 50

  • Receive recognition in our program for the 2015 season
  • Access to tickets one month before tickets sales open.
Young Professional $100

all preceding opportunities +

  • Access to in-studio viewing of a designated rehearsal
  •  15% off 1 ticket price of a performance of your choice.

Sponsor $500

all preceding opportunities+

  • Invitation to engage and network with the artists of NADT.
Benefactor $1,000

all preceding opportunities+

  • Behind the scenes tour with Director of NADT
  • Invitation to all fundraisers and special events for NADT
  • Individual recognition opportunities
Patron $5,000

all preceding opportunities+

  • Unlimited access to all NADT events and rehearsals.
  • Two free seasonal passes to all performances.

By sponsoring the company you are showing your support for our mission and creating new works of art. This budding company relies mainly on the donations of our supporters to cover costs for performances and day to day expenses. All donations will go to making this company thrive.  All of the donations received by North Atlantic Dance Theatre will go to aid in forging a beautiful and expressive performance unlike any that you have ever seen. 

Your Impact

With your funding, you can (through your donation), personally take part in creating an outlet for ballet in an area that is mainly dominated by modern dance companies. There are not many ballet companies in our area, and they do not have the same focus or drive that North Atlantic Dance Theatre does. This of course is not to say that they are not wonderful companies in their own right, but they have their own vision and support . 
This is an opportunity for you to become involved in something from its infancy. With your donation, you'll be able to watch us grow and mature. With your support, along with North Atlantic Dance Theatre's vision and drive, you will help to make this company stronger.

Risks & Challenges

In the off chance we don't reach our goal, no worries. All donations will go straight to the support for this company. Anything and everything helps. 
If our goal is not met then we will simply be tightening the budget. This also gives us the chance to be more creative in how we use our "smaller" budget. For instance in our "Let's get the party started" campaign we fell short of our goal. However we were still able to accomplish a lot even on a budget the fraction of what we were aiming for. We were able to rent a theater for two weekends of performances, payed dancers, collaborated with a production crew, created and designed new costumes, and landed a residency at Greenstreet Studios all of this was done because we were forced to think outside the box.

Other Ways You Can Help

Can't contribute, but still want to  help?

  • Make some noise about our campaign! The indiegogo share tools are a great way to spread the word. This is one of the most important things you could do to help us out.
  • Check out our website and let others know about it @ www.northatlanticdancetheatre.squarespace.com
Remember we can't do this without you, so thank you and see you at the shows that you made happen!

story:
_____________________________


Thank you for visiting. We are Empyrean Arts, Western North Carolina's epicenter for specialized movement arts and alternative fitness. A unique blend of strength and talent has come together to form the foundational team that will launch Empyrean Arts. Collectively, we have decades of experience in studying, training, performing, and instructing aerial arts and pole fitness. In addition, our team is also equipped with varied backgrounds in dance, gymnastics, fitness, Pilates, and yoga. This diversity of expertise allows us to offer a wide range of teaching approaches so our students can pursue their goals in an environment dedicated to supportive, high-quality movement education. Over the years, the members of our team have dedicated their personal time and finances to traveling all over the U.S. and abroad in pursuit of professional advancement in aerial arts and pole fitness. Our most recent adventure was to Cary, North Carolina, to become Aradia Fitness USA Certified Pole Fitness Instructors. We look forward to bringing this incredible art to Asheville, N.C. 

                                

The Aradia Fitness USA certified pole fitness instructors of Empyrean Arts, from top to bottom of pole: Waverly Jones, April Skelton, Alan Malpass, Dana Breen, and Heather Poole.


A little bit about our story...

We are Heather Poole and Waverly Jones, the founders of Empyrean Arts. We began studying aerial circus arts over 5 years ago, and since then have wholeheartedly committed ourselves to our training. Our interest in aerial arts soon led us to pole fitness. Advancement in these fields requires us to continue our education by traveling extensively, learning from other artists whom we greatly admire. A little over a year ago, we realized that in order to seriously pursue our devotion to aerial and pole arts, we must weigh two options: relocate from Asheville and continue our professional development elsewhere, OR create the kind of space we travel to here at home. In concluding that we both love living here, we began to bring Empyrean Arts into existence. Not only would we have our own training center, this would also provide the sought-after artists we look up to a place to share their knowledge here in Asheville. A project like this is much bigger than the two of us, so we began to seek out dedicated and passionate individuals who would come together to form Empyrean. This is how we have connected with talented artists such as: April Skelton, a highly skilled aerialist with more than 10 years experience in aerial arts, Alan Malpass, a fitness enthusiast, aerialist and dancer who leads group fitness classes, and Dana Breen, a certified pole fitness instructor who pursued a degree in neuroscience. Together, we are Empyrean Arts. 

                    


As we diligently work to find a physical space for Empyrean Arts, we are asking for encouragement from our friends, families, students, fellow artists, fitness lovers, and importantly, our community. We have received an abundance of positive feedback from all who have caught wind of this venture. Our community will greatly benefit from a fitness and dance studio that offers a wide range of classes and workshops, designed to meet the needs and interests of students of all ages and abilities. A few of the classes we will offer include pole fitness, contortion, aerial dance trapeze, strength and conditioning, ballet, and partner yoga. Our biggest goal is to make people feel good about themselves in a fun and supportive environment. We at Empyrean believe it is possible for anyone to find joy and creativity in fitness through movement art (yes, that means you!). 

                               

Waverly Jones, Empyrean Arts owner, and Dakota Fox, Aradia Fitness USA owner


Let's get down to business...

Opening a small business is a challenge. It requires the full-time attention and nourishment from its leaders. Not only is it an around-the-clock job, it comes with big expenses. Backed with a great business plan, we now need the funds to bring life to our project. To aid in achieving our goal, we are following the example of many successful start-ups by using crowdfunding to spread the word and gather capital for Empyrean Arts. Raising awareness and interest is one of the biggest benefits of this approach, and will help greatly in getting our feet on the ground. While crowdfunding gives us a platform to share our story with our audience, it also gives our supporters the opportunity to be an important part of our building process. 

After months of developing and refining our business plan and expenses, we have calculated that we need to raise around $20,000 to open our doors. We are aiming to raise a large portion of that through crowdfunding. We have constructed a pie chart to clarify where contributions will be going (check it out below!). In return for your support, we have come up with some awesome perks. To name a few: your name on a permanent art installation displayed in the studio, autographed photos of the Empyrean team, studio time through classes, private lessons, and parties, and even professional aerial performances. While we realize $20,000 is a large number, we plan to move ahead with our business plan, even if we do not fully reach our goal. In that case, the funds will still be divided into the outlined expenses in smaller amounts.

    


The point...

Aside from our desire to build a business where we can earn income through our passion for teaching movement arts, the amount of local and regional interest in a business like ours is tremendous, and regularly expressed. Individual members of the Empyrean team are constantly responding to inquiries about when and where a space like the one we intend to create will exist. Our goal is to get up and running within two months of completing our crowdfunding campaign. In the meantime, hang in there with us! Help spread the word about the campaign, tell your friends about Empyrean, and introduce people to us who share your excitement. People in our area are ready to learn incredible arts such as aerial dance trapeze and pole fitness, as well as the many other classes we are prepared to offer. 

                                  

 April Skelton, Empyrean Arts Instructor


What are we up against?

We will be the only studio that offers pole fitness and aerial dance within an almost two hour radius. We have an opportunity to rise to the top and put ourselves on the map. While financial success is important, we want to make clear that we require for ourselves a safe and healthy studio to practice, and will provide our future students with the same. We don't believe it will take long for people to want to be a part of the encouraging and enriching environment we promise to create, but we are realistic that obtaining sufficient start-up capital is a big hurdle. Even our crowdfunding campaign is an expense (that expense shrinks drastically if we meet our 20K goal, though!). We have well-organized and exciting lesson plans for classes, a solid marketing plan for attracting new customers, and highly-trained instructors to cater to a wide variety of students.  We are more than positive that we have a winning formula on our hands. Understanding that many businesses spend their early years just trying to break even, we are prepared to hang tight when times are tough. We are fully dedicated to Empyrean Arts as a business we believe in. 

                

Dana Breen, Empyrean Arts Instructor 


Ways you can help make it happen:

To stay in touch and receive updates about Empyrean Arts, please subscribe to our mailing list at EmpyreanArts.org. You can also spread the word through social media. Check us out and "Like" our page on Facebook (Empyrean Arts Asheville). Feel free to also tell every single person you talk to about how excited you are about Empyrean Arts. 

To help with funding, please donate what you can. If you're in a position to donate, read about our awesome perks as appreciation for your contribution. We appreciate anything you can do to help us with our campaign. 

                                        

Alan Malpass, Empyrean Arts Instructor


Thank you in advance. 

We want to extend our sincere gratitude to you for taking the time to read about Empyrean Arts. The simple fact you are here means the world to us.  We understand not everyone can donate, and that's okay, you're still amazing to us. We hope you'll come visit our studio. We cannot wait to spin, flip, dance, stretch, flex, invert, sweat, and hang out with you.
                   

                    

Heather Poole, Empyrean Arts Owner

                                 

Waverly Jones, Empyrean Arts Owner



 F  I  N  D                                    Y  O  U  R                            E  M  P  Y  R  E  A  N 

www.EmpyreanArts.org

story:
Who am I?

My name is Ellie Weinman and I’m earning my Bachelors of Fine Arts in Choreography and Performance at the University of Montana. I’m graduating this May and this production is my final project.

I am a current member of the professional modern repertoire Headwaters Dance Company and a former member of Bare Bait Dance. I’m a dancer for the performance guild MASC Artisan’s.

This production will also feature a dance I choreographed that will be performed at the 2015 American College Dance Association in Colorado.

Who is involved?

All of these brilliant people have contributed to my show!

Emily Curtiss- Dance Major at UM

Jaime Curtin- Community Dancer and Artist

Charlie Wiseman- Dance Major at UM

Dov Weinman- Environmental Studies Graduate Student, Camas Environmental Literary Magazine Editor

Quentin Robinson- Professional dancer with MASC Artisans at MOKSHA Aerial Studio

William Munoz- Professional Photographer

Brian Gregoire- Art Instillation Design

Paula Niccum-Costume Design

Alessia Carpoca-Costume Design

Rita Sam-venn- Costume Design

Shay Fiegi- Lighting Design

Randall Pratt- Lighting Design

Timothy McHenry- Sound Designtions, and


What is this? What can I expect?

Chrysalis an evening-length performance influenced by the workings of nature and human relations. The dances examine relationships; exploring moments in time, space, and memory. Natural elements are used within the production, making for an enhanced sensory experience, vivid for the senses as well as the mind. The dancers utilize water, dust, and dirt onstage.

An important aspect of my showcase is truth and sincerity. I’m interested in who we revealing who we (the performers) are. We are not just dancers. We are not just artists. We are people, unveiling our strength, aptitude and vulnerabilities.

I’m intrigued by how images and movement can be perceived in a multitude of ways. The production will involve a rich diversity of skills including contact dancing, modern dance, hip-hop influenced styles, acrobatics, poetry readings, photography, and art instillations.

The title "Cocoon Project" encompasses the rehearsals, manifestations, and small productions that have taken place in the process of creating the FINAL SHOWING of "Chrysalis" on the evenings of May 10 and 11. 

When & Where?

Evenings of May 10 & 11

In the back corner of the Montana Theatre on the University of Montana Campus

Ticket information COMING SOON!

 

Where is my money going?

All donations are going towards:

• Compensation for Dancers and Crew

• Space Rental ($500)

• Promotion & Press

• Lighting

• Sound

• Materials & Stage Design

• Costuming

And ofcourse….THE BEAUTY OF ART!

LAST BUT NOT LEAST…

Every penny goes a long way! I deeply appreciate your contribution to my vision. Thank you for believing in us and for believing in the arts!

story:
Short Summary

Accomplice Theatre is a Chicago theatre company committed to affordable theatre and dedicated to telling important stories in small spaces.  We are raising funds for our initial full length Chicago production--Shakespeare's Hamlet. 

We focus on: 

•Lowering the Price Tag- We believe theatre is for everyone, and that the average ticket price makes it hard to integrate "going to the theatre" into your life. That's why we keep our tickets free when possible, and low-cost when not. 

•Truthful Acting- Humans being humans on a stage. That’s what we’re most interested in.

•Getting Up Close and Too Personal- We like intimate spaces. We think too much space gives the audience an out.

•Stories Worth Telling- Shakespeare. Shanley. New work. Old work. If we like the story and if we want to share it with an audience, we will. 

Accomplice Theatre is a sponsored project of Fractured Atlas, a non-profit arts service organization. Contributions for the charitable purposes of Accomplice Theatre must be payable to "Fractured Atlas" only and are tax-deductible to the extent permitted by law. 

What We Need & What You Get

We've crunched the numbers, and have found that $10,000 is about as low as we can go to make this production happen. On the other hand, it only takes a mere $10,000 to provide free theatre to the people of Chicago.

  • Money raised will be used to pay for theatre and rehearsal space rental, paying actors and technicians, props, costumes, skulls, set, marketing, insurance, and probably something expensive we haven't even imagined yet, but will surprise and horrify us. 
  • In addition to making theatre available to everyone, and being an awesome do-gooder, we're also offering several acknowledgement perks, including unique puppet videos! 
  • In the event of not raising enough funds, the money will be used to buy handkerchiefs to wipe away our tears. Just kidding. It will be part of the Accomplice Theatre fund at Fractured Atlas, available to be used for future projects. 

The Impact

It costs a lot of money to go see theatre in Chicago. Oh sure, there's Shakespeare in the park, but if you want to go to a dedicated theatre space and see a play, it can get pretty costly pretty quickly. Even small companies are routinely charging $25 and upwards for tickets. We understand why: it's expensive to produce theatre. But costly tickets make theatre a special treat, or even a complete impossibility for many people. 

  • Removing cost is removing a barrier to the arts. 
  • The capacity of the space we'll perform in, and our month-long run, give us the potential to share our production with more than 1,000 people. 
  • By removing (or lowering) the factor of ticket price, everyone is included equally. We're all in it together.

Risks & Challenges

The biggest risk and challenge we anticipate is raising enough funds. There. We said it. We're counting on you, and absolutely can't do it without a lot of help. 

However, another challenge we're anticipating is getting the word out that there's free (or low-cost, depending on how much money we raise) theatre available. If we build it, we think there may be a few more steps before they come to the show. Figuring out how to advertise, who to talk to, and how to invite the audience will be exciting, but also tricky. We have the opportunity and the space for many people--we want to make sure we make the most of it. 

  • We plan to reach out to community organizations, senior housing, youth organizations, and community leaders, to build our audience.
  • If we do not raise enough funds to do the show for free, we will offer low-cost tickets.
  • If we do not raise enough funds to do the show at all, we will continue to fundraise until we can. Or we will do something else equally important, but not as expensive. 

Other Ways You Can Help

We all get a lot of these requests, and can't always contribute. We get it, we're broke artists. However, you can still help us out by:

  • Getting the word out. Share our campaign, tell your friends about us, or join our fundraising team!
  • If you live in Chicago, and want to work on the nitty-gritty bits of production and/or fundraising, get in touch. We have envelopes to stuff, and tickets to take, and street teaming to do!
  • If you live in Chicago, and your business, faith organization, or employer wants to make a corporate gift or has space you'd let us rehearse in,  please get in touch. 

Thank you!

Thank you!

story:
Reading Dates and location!

April 25th & May 2nd at 8pm

Lucid Body House, 230 Lexington Ave, NYC

A Concert/Play about Military Drones!?! Really?

Paul, Justin and New Morse Code meet in grad school at Yale and start talking about how to take music out of the recital hall and do something more theatrical.

Drone strikes are in the news.

Recruits fresh out of high school are at the controls - women in increasing numbers.

We start to imagine a play...               a concert...              a concert-slash-play...

Two years and much work later, Unblinking Eye is about to be born.

Whoa. What's it like?

Unblinking Eye is about a teen woman who enlists in the Air Force and works as a drone operator. She struggles with the painful realities of combat, all while living at home with her mom.

A trio plays as she tells us all about, acting as a counterpoint to the text and vice versa, so there’s a heightened level of listening.

Sounds Awesome! What's Next?

The script and score are poised for

  • reading in April
  • a production in NYC in the fall
  • a film adaptation
  •  an eventual production near you.

ALL of this is possible when you join us!

What We Need & What You Get

We need $ 10,000 to cover three specific things in April:

  • A professional promo video

  • A studio recording 

  • Reading of the text in NYC

These are all already planned in April, so we can share our idea with potential producers.

PERKS INCLUDE!!!

  • Tickets to a reading in NYC!
  • Recordings of the music!
  • Private concerts!!
  • so much more!!

Our Big Break!

Unblinking Eye marks a huge turning point in our lives.

  • Paul's first evening-length work that he eventually wants to release as an album.
  • Justin's first professional production in New York City. Details about that soon.
  • Everyone's first international tour! We designed this show to be light in elements so we can bring it to you. Your university, your concert hall, your theater, in the US, in Europe.
  • Our big response to the current wars, fought by our peers. These wars are the biggest issue of our generation and so few talk about it. So we are partnering with Iraq  war veterans groups to spread awareness of PTS and combat trauma.
  • Not to mention the FILM ADAPTATION with filmmaker Horacio Marquinez....
An album, a New York premier, a tour, a film... WOW!!
Your support now helps us get it there.

You Sure You Can Pull This Off?

It's an ambitious agenda for sure, but we've been working on this show for TWO YEARS - writing, researching, traveling to air force bases, and talking with veterans. We have all produced and toured our own works professionally. We are ready!

    Other Ways You Can Help

    • Give us a shout out on all the social medias!
    • Click SHARE on this page and add a personal message!

    Love Justin, Paul, Karen, Mike and Hannah.
