story:
Seventy year old “Chick” Chicarella has one prized possession, a 1966 Jaguar Sedan that is in need of repair.  When his son “Bone” suggests that the two finish the car to finally sell it off, old family wounds and failures rise to the surface.  They decide to employ “Carla,” a talented but strange body woman to help them complete the project. Together, the three learn some hard lessons about repairing cars and smoothing out life’s jagged edges.

Winner of the 2010 Firehouse Theater Great American Play Award

Finalist for the 2011 Laurents Hatcher Award.

2nd place, Premiere Playwright’s Contest hosted by Kean University.

CAST:  Charles Stransky  'Chick'

            Peter DeFaria            'Bone'

            Diane Mair                  'Carla'

DIRECTOR: Richard Shavzin

PLAYWRIGHT: Gino DiIorio

Every dollar you donate will provide jobs for the three Actors Equity performers performing the play; the three actors who will be their understudies; the director's fee; the designers' fees; the crafts people who will build the set, costumes, and props. Your donation will go toward renting the rehearsal space; the theatre the play is performed in. Donations go toward paying the staff of the theatre and the box office. Remember your donation is helping to provide jobs!...Your donation also helps to create Art...

story:
Making A Stage for Our Stories (MASFOS): hearts, portals, magic! is a dance and movement showcase that celebrates and affirms the experiences of LGBTTIQQ2S lives and stories on stage.

Help us honor over 20 awesome LGBTTIQQ2S performers showcasing stories that unearth histories and travel between galactic, spiritual, ancient realms -- rooted in where we come from and where we are going. Our stories are rarely seen on stage and this showcase is a unique platform where LGBTQS folks are celebrated and affirmed!

We need funds to help us to pay all performers for their time and energy. Funds will also go to ASL interpretation, production crew, and organizers. By covering these costs, we make sure folks from all our communities can share in the celebration, this will help us to pay-what-you-can options

If we reach beyond our goal, all funds raised will go towards the MASFOS dance and movement conference in 2016, providing more LGBTQ people opportunities to learn dance and share with each other!

Donate, share this page, and stay in touch:
twitter | facebook | instagram 

Together we can make magic.

Thank you!

MASFOS Organizing Team

story:
Join us in supporting the production of our original play. We have already partnered with the National Japanese American Memorial Foundation (NJAMF) and with the National Parks Service to bring you this work.

We have an amazing team of designers and performers to create a modern fable of American history.  Performing at the Japanese American Memorial near the Capital Building, "The Little Crane" tells the story of the 442nd Regimental Combat Unit in WWII. Made up of Japanese Americans who had been sent to internment camps, along with their families, they fought with valor in the face of terrible racism and prejudice. At a time when social injustice is a hot button subject, this is an important story to get to audiences of all ages.

We need support to hire the artists and tech staff, as well as materials to build costumes and puppets, to rent sound and projection equipment, as well as pay all the fees for the Fringe, marketing, and for the use of the monument through the National Parks Service. This fundraising goal just scrapes the surface of covering the expenses on the show, so like the 442nd, we hope you'll "go for broke" in joining this project!

story:
We're Sam and Geoffrey Rose, and we've been working on our labor of love "POP!" the Musical for just about 7 years now. At this point we're in the final stages of readying the show for three performances this June 19th, 20th and 21st at the Hudson Backstage Theater here in Hollywood, CA. 
Little did we know when we began this odyssey how costly the undertaking would become, even after cutting all kinds of corners and begging favor after favor. Hence this request. And here's the real reason behind the need. The show is part of the Hollywood Fringe Festival (#hff15) which typically presents shows at very affordable ticket prices in what are called Equity Waiver 99 seat theaters. Bottom line this means that we can only recoup a portion of what the show will cost to mount through ticket sales. 
Sam and I understand that we need to shoulder the lion's share of the production expenses. And we are doing everything we can to fill the theater for our three performances. But even when we do that, it will still leave us about $5,000 in the hole. As this is only the beginning of our theatrical journey (we're developing relationships with regional theaters and submitting the show to festivals) we would dearly love to break even on this first outing so as to be financially positioned to move forward with "POP!" 
I fully believe that we are going to create a buzz here at the Fringe and garner some industry attention. Under the able direction of Barry Pearl (Grease) and choreographer James Tabeek, and in the hands of an incredibly talented group of actors the show is shaping up beautifully. With a little luck we just might even win an award and attract the critically important interest from producers and backers that success with these sorts of undertakings require. That is absolutely what we are hoping to achieve. 
I understand many of these indiegogo campaigns offer perks for contributions. We're looking into what these might be... Maybe tee shirts with the show's logo on them. Maybe music downloads or signed lead sheets of songs from the show. Whatever these may ultimately be, know that our gratitude will soon be expressed in some tangible form - perhaps a perk of your choosing or a seat at a future production.
Please know, too, that any amount you can give will be greatly appreciated, and that your dollars are going directly into shaping and presenting this...  the world premier of "POP!" the Musical.

One last thought... by participating in this campaign, it will most certainly put you at the energetic heart of things here, even If you can't be with us in person this time around.

Our heartfelt thanks for any help you can be,
Geoffrey and Sam Rose

story:
Sea Legs Dance. See Whose Legs Dance?

Sea legs is a project based dance group originating in Selbyville, DE.  As the name suggests, we try to adapt our own "Sea Legs to the different places dance can take us whether that's holding the first local modern dance show in a small town in Delaware or an international tour to Sri Lanka!  

Through different projects, various opportunities for performance are offered to all levels of dancers. Sometimes we have dancers that are 8 years old and then at other times, our performers are talented professionals like you'll see in this project.  For the Sri Lanka tour, dancers from all over the USA will come together to rehearse at the end of this year for an intense rehearsal period of two weeks to prepare for a full length show. On Jan 8th, 2016, we will be on our way to take Sea Legs to Sri Lanka.  To get to know us even better, visit: www.sealegsdance.com

Planes & Perks

  • $16,900 - The cost of plane tickets for 13 dancers to fly round trip from Delaware to Sri Lanka. We will be purchasing our tickets at the beginning of August 2015 to secure our spots. We will tour from Jan 8th - 18th, 2016.
  • Perks: Let us thank you with a signed postcard from a tropical country. You know you want some snail mail with an exotic Sri Lankan stamp. Or maybe you'll be one of the lucky ones that we make a dance video for. Your video will be great because we are so very grateful for your support!
  • If we do not reach our goal, all dancers will have to pay for their airfare out of pocket.  While we have everything else covered, for example, costumes, rehearsal space, and performance venues, we still need your help to get to our destination.
  • By donating to our project, you help us not only have an amazing experience through our work, but allow us to share our art with the people of Sri Lanka. We will be performing in theater venues, concert halls, as well as visiting and teaching master classes at schools and local studios.  Help us take more modern dance around the world!

Other Ways You Can Love Us

Even if you can't contribute, you can still support us by sharing this through word of mouth and of course social media. Thank you and dance on!

story:
What is Crash Alchemy?

We are a multi-media multi-disciplinary collective of performers, designers, and technologists, crafting interactive exhibitions, installations & events. Crash Alchemy is a melange of mischief makers who seek to explore the sacred, the profane, the mundane, and everything in between. A fusion of movement, music, art, and technology formed to get down, get weird, and get real - with ongoing community involvement to facilitate interpersonal and artistic growth. By encouraging participants and audiences to interact, we invite one and all to explore and expand their definition of normal...

Crash Alchemy's TWIST

Crash Alchemy believes that any situation and circumstance can be a perfect opportunity for development and growth. Our upcoming Twist production is a mind-bending experience about our choices, where the audience pilots the direction of the show between each scene.  No two shows will ever be the same....  You, the audience, is getting Twisted...   Using dance, acrobatics, flow and movement paired with custom video content, sensor- based visuals and interactive lighting effects, and alternative projection techniques and surfaces to bridge the space between real life and our imagination and examine the reasons and effects of our choices.  We're offering performances Nov 13 - 15 and Nov 20 - 22, with matinee and evening options Saturday and Sunday showings at Bridging All Movement (BAM) Theater at 4401 Friedrich Ln.  #400 8pm Fridays and 2pm, 8pm Saturdays and Sundays.  

What We Need

Production needs are where your donations are going: rehearsal space, research and development of performance technology, costumes, insurance, aerial safety rigging, venues, marketing, designers, collaborators, this list is huge. The performance itself is crowd sourced which is why we came to Indiegogo.
In addition, Crash is building a national company which requires us to get legit! The administrative and processing fees are a part of this campaign. Crash Alchemy believes a successful artist should get paid, be healthy, have medical access, & adequate rest.

What You Get

Discount Tickets to Twist  and Art Outside Festival, 
Private rehearsals,classes,  performances, events, and crashy custom services like a singing telegram or a date with a Crasher of your choice!
Custom crafted goods and services from Crash and the Community
Lots of simple personalized ways to Thank You for a modest contribution.  
The satisfaction of knowing you are supporting a group of talented and committed individuals united in the desire to provide an extraordinary experience.  

Where Your Support Goes

These are our basic expenses to cover our ideal show run, not including compensation, which is in a cooperative format with open budgets.  We have about half of this in funds already - enough to open the show, but the more we can secure before opening, the more we can invest in supplies to go all-out in the execution

Expenses:
Venue: 2175
Projector: 2320 + 1100 = 3420
Lighting: 2000
Costumes: 1000
metal and welding: 800
Opening Act: 200/show:  2000
Advertising and Promotion: 2500


*EXPENSE ESTIMATE TOTAL

13895.00

Our Impact.
Crash Alchemy believes that in bridging the place between the real world of flaws and challenges to the endless world of the imagination, and in opening that space up to participation with the audience, a unique space is created.   Participants learn more about their independence, play out their dramas, while becoming more connected to the common humanity around them.   We've continue to be amazed by the effects of this process, and now host monthly interactive community Open House and Crash-tatic dance events open to full public participation.  

Technology is important to us because it provides such an amazing way to visually link the real world with the world of the imagination.  Your support allows us to utilize this technology, which can be resource and time-intensive. 


Challenges

For us, we know we can make the show happen self-funded as we have in the past, but covering our bottom line should not be highest possibility.  

We are going all out on this and are committed to generate the buzz for the project, resources to got all-out on the technical vision and costumes with minimum compromises.  In the end, the difference between pulling it off and success is how much, if anything we will be able to divide between cast and tech collaborators for individual contributions after that bottom line has been met.     


Other Ways You Can Help

If you just aren't able to contribute with your pocketbook, here are some other ways you can help us

  • Help us get the word out and make some noise about our campaign, using the Indiegogo share tools!
  • Email crashthis@crashalchemy.com to inquire as a volunteer in costuming or another area.  We'd love to hear your ideas!

Collaborative art is it's Community.  We appreciate you.

story:
Short Summary

Dance Wisconsin believes in possibilities. Chelsey Bradley’s new work, “Alice’s Adventures in Wonderland” proves it!  We have an exceptional choreographic story, talented dancers, dedicated volunteers, and experienced artistic and production staff ready to roll.  But, to complete our vision, we need financial support.

Established in 1999, Dance Wisconsin is a 501(c) 3 non-profit, dance company that offers exceptional dance training and educational opportunities to south-central Wisconsin residents. The company consists of fifteen dancers ages twelve to adult. Members travel from McFarland, Madison, Monona, Sun Prairie, Marshall, Lake Mills, Waunakee, and New Glarus to train with the company.   Audiences of diverse ethnicity, ages, and arts interests will be served, as well as emerging dancers and costumers.  There are few opportunities for youth and young adults to work with skilled and talented dancers, to craft choreography, design costumes, work with stage crew, and perform original works in front of an audience.  Dance Wisconsin gives young artists the space, time, instruction, and guidance to explore the ARTS. This production provides local choreographers the means to craft and present original dance; dancers the opportunity to explore working with others, props, and visual projections; and costumers to create new designs.


What We Need

Can you imagine Wonderland without life-sized playing cards? Neither can we! This campaign will support all production expenses ranging from original choreography, costumes, props, lighting design, set design, and everything else that happens behind-the-scenes.

Campaign perks begin at as low as $10, and include signed t-shirts, tickets to the show, and the opportunity to have your name listed in the "Alice in Wonderland" program.


The Impact

"Alice’s Adventures in Wonderland" premiers at Mitby Theater, Madison, Wisconsin on April 16, 2016.  The ballet showcases engaging characters and movement, beautiful costumes, and innovative set designs and video projections.  Audience members will find it possible to experience the exciting ballet adventure Alice encounters.  Dance Wisconsin will provide free community outreach programs that integrate literacy and dance.  Patrons will learn about Charles Lutwidge Dodgson and the period from which he wrote Alice in Wonderland.  Construction of choreography and costumes will also be discussed.   Discounted tickets will be provided to Girl Scouts and free tickets to Big Brothers and Big Sisters of Dane County.   Your support will make this event POSSIBLE!

Risks & Challenges

Constructing a full-length ballet is difficult.  Crafting choreography, selecting music, designing and sewing costumes, putting sets together, and mastering projection mapping are several of the challenges Dance Wisconsin faces producing an original ballet.  Casting roles, rehearsing long hours, working with theater crew, and engaging the community are other tasks that take thoughtful consideration and hard work.

Dance Wisconsin is up to the challenge of bringing "Alice's Adventures in Wonderland" to fruition.  Under the leadership of Jo Jean Retrum, direction and choreography from Chelsey Dahm Bradley, and talent of the Dance Wisconsin company and many volunteers, we are confident that a highly entertaining, professional, and innovative ballet will delight audiences April 16 and 17, 2016.

Other Ways You Can Help

Dance Wisconsin is sincerely appreciative of all contributions of support!  If you can not contribute financially to our project, please consider using the Indiegogo share tools to help spread the word of our project!  Thank You!

story:
Short Summary

As many of you know I recently left my corporate job to open up Free Spirit Dance. When I started this artist journey I never in a million years thought it would lead to a dance studio! I'm excited and grateful to have this opportunity. Running a dance studio there are many expenses and to make it through the first year I need your help. I'm raising funds to grow Free Spirit Dance into a self-sustaining and thriving community that ignites fires inside people!  By contributing to my campaign you are helping:

  • build a space that isn't simply about dance and fitness but about "community".
  • create a safe space where people can be free to express themselves without judgment and be encouraged to step outside their comfort zones and feel empowered. 
  • create opportunities for other artists to have an affordable space to create in. Space is limited and expensive in Calgary leaving many artists struggling.
  • create space for creativity. Art is an integral part of our society. Creativity is in every one of us in many different ways.
  • fostering artistic development.

What We Need

The first year of business there are many expenses. In order to attract new clientele and get past survival mode I need:

  • Employee wages, marketing and advertising dollars, signage, debit/credit machine, new equipment, video promotion, accounting, trade show equipment, lighting upgrade for events and new ceiling.
What is my unique selling proposition (USP)?
  • 1. My space is intimate so I am able to really create a close community feeling where you get to know one another, feel connected and feel like everyone knows your name. You are not just another number or dollar figure. 
  • 2. I offer unique classes that you don't see in other studios
  • 3. There are not many studios offering classes completely dedicated to Adult Dance and Fitness in the demographic I have chosen.
If I don't meet my $40,000 goal, the funds I do receive will first and foremost  go to hiring  quality teachers.

The Impact

For me Free Spirit Dance is much more than just a dance and fitness studio. I want to bring light and life into my community through my passion.

YOU ARE HELPING TRANSFORM LIVES!
  • As a teacher I see personal transformations inside people all the time. I see people who were shy about their bodies, feeling more comfortable and confident. I have had people come up to me and tell me how I helped them get through a hard time simply through movement and positivity. I have seen lonely people make friends and feel like they have a community of people who care and as a byproduct gain more confidence. I have many more stories like these ones. This is what excites me most about my job - that I can bring positivity, light and hope into peoples' lives through my passion!
  • "In everyone's life, at some time, our inner fire goes out. It is then burst into flame by an encounter with another human being." I want to light fires inside people. We are all miracles just by existing! I want people to find that inner "fire"  within that gives them purpose!

Risks & Challenges

There are many risks to opening a new business. December and January are always the slowest months and hard on revenue so I have to prepare for that. Retaining good staff can be difficult.

  • My 20 years experience in business and marketing has really helped me to get creative in how I market and find new students. I'm always looking for ways to market outside the box and mitigate my expenses.

Other Ways You Can Help

You can know that with any contribution you make I am giving it my 500% and then some! This is my dream in the making! There is no stopping this train! I've never been so sure or committed as I am at this moment! I know the value of working hard, working smarter and not losing sight of my goal. I am already riding the crazy entrepreneurial ups and downs and I'm not afraid. I've dealt with my fears and accepted the risks. I'm all in! )

I realize that not everyone is in a financial position to help.  Even if you can't contribute you can still help!!

  • Please share on your social media networks if what I am doing resonates with you.
  • Send people to the studio to try a class! www.freespiritdance.ca

story:
Feature Presentation: The Ludlow Theatre

Our goal is to restore the Ludlow Theatre as a one-of-a-kind entertainment destination, rooted in history and community, for a modern-day audience. Opening in 1946, the Ludlow Theatre boasted an Art Deco design and served as a primary source of entertainment with evening shows, matinees and features. The building endured many transitions after its post-war heyday and eventually operated as a clutch manufacturing plant for over two decades until 2009. That year Paul and Renee Miller, husband and wife and Owners and Operators of Circus Mojo, purchased the building with the backing of two benevolent uncles and the vision of restoring the theatre as a unique venue with broad appeal.

To date, over 50,000 people have attended the Ludlow Theatre’s events from plays, concerts and circus shows to square dances, pro wrestling matches and improv comedy. Highlights include: Celebrity Circus and Benefit with Jerry Springer, Operation Grace White Benefit, Playhouse in the Park’s Off the Hill productions, Keshvar Project’s dance and music productions, Gorilla Cinema’s screening of It’s a Wonderful Life, concerts by Javier Mendoza and Ramblin’ Jack Elliot, College Circus Festivals with performances by Duo Rose and Christian Stoinev, Jeff McBride’s Magic UnMasked and the City of Ludlow’s Sesquicentennial. 

For continued success in the community, we need funders, craftsman and artisans to help us restore the Ludlow Theatre and bring it fully up to date on code compliance. We are not raising funds in this campaign for BIRCUS Brewing, a microbrewery we hope to establish as an added attraction to the theatre and neighborhood. Through Indiegogo, we primarily aim to improve the theatre, keep our doors open and invite people to Ludlow . Lights, camera, action~let’s make it a GO in Ludlow!


Play a Role & Win Recognition 

  • Play a role in contributing to history and community! The National Historic Register, the official list of historic places worthy of preservation in the U.S., states that the theatre is "an important property in the development of Ludlow, especially within that city's entertainment culture" and "provides a strong example of the central role movie theaters played in small towns across the country during the movie boom following the Second World War." 
  • Donate to restoring the facade such as the marquee and doors as they originally appeared in 1946 at the Ludlow Theatre's opening and movie premiere of If I’m Lucky. We will work with the sustainable construction of GB Solutions to preserve history with modern engineering. 
  • Win recognition at the theatre with your name on a plaque to signify your contribution, whether you helped light the building or build the marquee. 
  • Take pride in creating local jobs and supporting local businesses. We practice sourcing locally whenever possible by hiring artisans in the community and customizing our circus props and theatre signs from metal and machine shops such as Bluegrass Iron Works and Spati Industries in Ludlow and Steidle Fabricating in Bromley. The marquee and other restorations will be sourced in the area for economic growth and development .  
  • Take pleasure in restoring a historic theatre as a one-of-a-kind destination and revitalizing Ludlow as a tourist attraction, reminiscent of the Lagoon Amusement Park which brought thousands a day to Ludlow from 1895-1918.   


Academy Awards for Achievement  

  • Over 5,000 cars travel past the Ludlow Theatre every day. Restoring the marquee will not only make travelers take note but will also invite them to visit the coffee and retail shops, restaurants and taverns, art studios and upcoming events with local, national and international talent at the theatre.  
  • Over 50,000 have attended events at the Ludlow Theatre in the past five years; this number is estimated to skyrocket to over 100,000 annually with the completion of restoration and the addition of Bircus Brewing. 
  • The Ludlow Theatre currently is on the National Register of Historic Places, meeting an important criterion for a Brown Tourism Sign through the Kentucky Transportation Cabinet. Designating the theater as a tourist destination and securing a tourist sign at the Ft. Wright I-71/75 exit will put Ludlow on the map. 
  • Since the purchase of the Ludlow Theatre in 2009, Ludlow welcomed 12 new businesses: AER Group, 319 Linden Street, (859) 577-5007 ; Circus Mojo, 322 Elm Street, (859) 360-7757; 230 Elm Antiques & Vintage, 230 Elm Street, (513) 368-9943; Folk School Coffee Parlor, 332 Elm Street, (859) 206-1269; Jeff & John Winkle Studio, 329 Elm Street; The Lagoon Saloon, 859 Elm Street, (859) 581-7822; Pizza Hut, 102 Elm Street, (859) 261-6111; Riverside Marketplace, 106 Elm Street, (859) 292-0442; Second Sights Spirits, 301 B Elm Street; Subway, 478 Elm Street, (859) 415-0772; Trendy Treasures, 243 Elm Street, (859) 380-5862; and Wynner’s Cup Cafe, 301 A Elm Street, (859) 912-5806. 
  • Once the Ludlow Theatre is restored, even more businesses, customers and residents will help make this quaint river town a thriving community.  


 Challenges for Cast & Crew

  • Meeting our deadline. In 2013 we secured a spot on the National Historic Register and received State and Federal Historic Tax Credits that expire December of 2015 in the sum of $59,979.06, funds not to be wasted.
  • Budgeting time and money to bring the theatre up to date on current codes. 
  • Coordinating with city and zoning officials to realize our vision.    

      

  •             There Are No Small Parts
  • Spread the word about the campaign and Ludlow's progress and potential.
  • Utilize the Indiegogo share tools and other social media.
  • Volunteer at investludow.com and hit the ACT NOW button to join us!
story_txt:
Feature Presentation: The Ludlow Theatre 
Our goal is to restore the
Ludlow Theatre as a one-of-a-kind entertainment destination, rooted in history
and community, for a modern-day audience. Opening in 1946, the Ludlow Theatre boasted an Art Deco design and served as a primary source of entertainment with
evening shows, matinees and features. The building endured many transitions
after its post-war heyday and eventually operated as a clutch manufacturing plant for over two decades until 2009. That year Paul and Renee Miller, husband
and wife and Owners and Operators of Circus Mojo, purchased the building with
the backing of two benevolent uncles and the vision of restoring the theatre as
a unique venue with broad appeal.

To date, over 50,000 people
have attended the Ludlow Theatre’s events from plays, concerts and circus shows to
square dances, pro wrestling matches and improv comedy. Highlights include: Celebrity
Circus and Benefit with Jerry Springer, Operation Grace White Benefit,
Playhouse in the Park’s Off the Hill productions, Keshvar Project’s dance and
music productions, Gorilla Cinema’s screening of It’s a Wonderful
Life, concerts by Javier Mendoza and Ramblin’ Jack Elliot, College Circus
Festivals with performances by Duo Rose and Christian Stoinev, Jeff McBride’s Magic
UnMasked and the City of Ludlow’s Sesquicentennial. 
For continued success in the community, we need
funders, craftsman and artisans to help us restore the Ludlow Theatre and bring it fully up
to date on code compliance. We are not raising funds in this campaign for BIRCUS Brewing, a microbrewery we hope to establish as an added attraction to the theatre and neighborhood. Through Indiegogo, we primarily aim to improve the theatre, keep our doors open and invite people to Ludlow . Lights, camera, action~let’s make it a GO
in Ludlow! 


Play a Role & Win Recognition 


Play a role in contributing to history and community! The National Historic Register, the official list of historic places worthy of preservation in the U.S., states that the theatre is "an important property in the development of Ludlow, especially within that city's entertainment culture" and "provides a strong example of the central role movie theaters played in small towns across the country during the movie boom following the Second World War." 
Donate to restoring the facade such as the marquee and doors as they originally appeared in 1946 at the Ludlow Theatre's opening and movie premiere of If I’m Lucky. We will work with the sustainable construction of GB Solutions to preserve history with modern engineering. 

Win recognition at the theatre with your name on a plaque to signify your contribution, whether you helped light the building or build the marquee. 

Take pride in creating local jobs and supporting local businesses. We practice sourcing locally whenever possible by hiring artisans in the community and customizing our circus props and theatre signs from metal and machine shops such as Bluegrass Iron Works and Spati Industries in Ludlow and Steidle Fabricating in Bromley. The marquee and other restorations will be sourced in the area for economic growth and development .  
Take pleasure in restoring a historic theatre as a one-of-a-kind destination and revitalizing Ludlow as a tourist attraction, reminiscent of the Lagoon Amusement Park which brought thousands a day to Ludlow from 1895-1918.   




   Academy Awards for Achievement   
Over 5,000 cars travel past the Ludlow Theatre every day. Restoring the marquee will not only make travelers take note but will also invite them to visit the coffee and retail shops, restaurants and taverns, art studios and upcoming events with local, national and international talent at the theatre.   Over 50,000 have attended events at the Ludlow Theatre in the past five years; this number is estimated to skyrocket to over 100,000 annually with the completion of restoration and the addition of Bircus Brewing. 
The Ludlow Theatre currently is on the National Register of Historic Places, meeting an important criterion for a Brown Tourism Sign through the Kentucky Transportation Cabinet. Designating the theater as a tourist destination and securing a tourist sign at the Ft. Wright I-71/75 exit will put Ludlow on the map. 
Since the purchase of the Ludlow Theatre in 2009, Ludlow welcomed 12 new businesses: AER Group, 319 Linden Street, (859) 577-5007 ; Circus Mojo, 322 Elm Street, (859) 360-7757; 230 Elm Antiques & Vintage, 230 Elm Street, (513) 368-9943; Folk School Coffee Parlor, 332 Elm Street, (859) 206-1269; Jeff & John Winkle Studio, 329 Elm Street; The Lagoon Saloon, 859 Elm Street, (859) 581-7822; Pizza Hut, 102 Elm Street, (859) 261-6111; Riverside Marketplace, 106 Elm Street, (859) 292-0442; Second Sights Spirits, 301 B Elm Street; Subway, 478 Elm Street, (859) 415-0772; Trendy Treasures, 243 Elm Street, (859) 380-5862; and Wynner’s Cup Cafe, 301 A Elm Street, (859) 912-5806. 
Once the Ludlow Theatre is restored, even more businesses, customers and residents will help make this quaint river town a thriving community.      

 Challenges for Cast & Crew

Meeting our deadline. In 2013 we secured a spot on the National Historic Register and received State and Federal Historic Tax Credits that expire December of 2015 in the sum of $59,979.06, funds not to be wasted.
Budgeting time and money to bring the theatre up to date on current codes. 
Coordinating with city and zoning officials to realize our vision.    
  


             There Are No Small Parts

Spread the word about the campaign and Ludlow's progress and potential.
Utilize the Indiegogo share tools and other social media.
Volunteer at investludow.com and hit the ACT NOW button to join us!

story:
What is Patio Playhouse?

Patio Playhouse was incorporated in November of 1967 to establish a theatre group for theatrical arts education and presentation. For almost five decades, we’ve been building a community of playgoers and participants by providing affordable, quality entertainment and opportunities for people to take part in the production of award-winning shows.

  • We provide a venue where people from school age to seniors can participate in live drama, learn new skills, and enrich the quality of life in the community. Our Youth Theatre introduces live theatre to school children by providing school performances.
  • We want to keep participation affordable and open to all in the community so, unlike some other theatres, we don’t require audition or performance fees.
  • We have no salaried employees. All aspects of productions and theatrical management are performed by volunteers.
  • We’re a federally chartered non-profit corporation supported solely by tax-deductible donations, membership dues and box office receipts.

The Plan of Attack

We have created a series of goal levels each of which will reach a level of funding to allow us to make another upgrade. This campaign has been divided into 3 different phases. Each phase and its component parts are outlined below. Noted will be the donation level needed for us to make the improvement.

1. Kitchen

  • $100 - Painting ($100)
  • $350 - New Floor ($450)
  • $100 - Wall Base ($550)
  • $50 - Re-routing Electrical ($600)
  • $50 - Tools and Hardware ($650)
  • $150 - New Coffee Machines and Electric Kettle ($800)
  • $100 - Custom Aprons ($900)
  • $50 - Brooms, Broom Rack, Cleaning Supplies ($950)
  • $100 - Microwave ($1050)
  • $100 - Rain Mat ($1150)
2. Box Office
  • $50 - Painting ($1200)
  • $350 - New Floor ($1550)
  • $50 - Key Box and Office Supplies ($1600)
  • $50 - Ceiling Tiles ($1650)
3. Lobby
  • $400 - LED Bulbs ($2050)
  • $100 - Wheelchair Ramp ($2150)
  • $450 - Video Display for Front Window ($2600)
  • $200 - Acknowledgement Plaque ($2800)

Our Fundraising Plans

We are approaching this fundraising in three manners:

  • External - Specifically, this online fundraising page, promoted through our social media channels and newsletter.
  • Internal - From our patrons and volunteers in person at our shows and events.
  • Corporate - We are actively seeking corporate business partners.

The Impact

We are committed to delivering a high quality experience for both our patrons and our volunteers:

  • By improving our accommodations, our patrons will experience a more comfortable and enjoyable theatergoing experience - meaning YOU will enjoy your time here even more than you already do!

  • From purchasing tickets at our box office to picking up concessions and everything in between, these improvements will provide an immersive, high quality experience for all visitors and attendees.

  • With proven successes in improving our audience seating and toilet facilities for performers via past fundraising campaigns, we are confident in the benefits that this project will bring to the patrons, performers, all-volunteer staff, and to our theater as we continue our mission of offering exceptional theater arts in our community.

Risks & Challenges

There is no risk to this campaign. We will be making the upgrades as the funding comes in, clearly visible to all of our patrons as they enjoy the theater. Some upgrades may be deferred and completed between productions. Any funds that are raised beyond our goal will be added to our Capital Improvements Fund and used in the future to improve our facilities and equipment.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't or don't want to contribute through this Indiegogo campaign:

  • You can contribute to the display in our lobby. (And while you're there you can check out the work we've already completed.)
  • If you own or work for a business, the business can become a "Community Partner" and be mentioned in all of our promotions for this fundraiser (including in our lobby, programs, social media and here on Indiegogo).
  • Share this with your friends.

And don't forget that we are always looking for volunteers: volunteers.patioplayhouse.com

story:
The Project and Year of Development

Antigone. Trojan Women. Medea.  Plays which vibrate with the voices of women in the expression of feminine strength in all its forms, in old age, in youth, in motherhood, in politics, in sexuality, in war. Alexandra Silber's sensitive and powerful Nouveau Classical reworkings of these plays unflinchingly encounter the experience of women.  What the Nouveau Classical approach looks for is to distill what matters, and what has always mattered, from classical works so that they can resonate both beyond their own time, place and culture, and also beyond our own time, place and culture. In making the strange familiar and the familiar strange, Silber's writing allows us to zoom out from the parochial facts of a particular time or place in order to see more fully the entire terrain of human experience.
Dutch Kills theater is dedicated exclusively to new writing, and is immensely proud to be undertaking this project. We warmly invite you to take part in this female-written, female-produced and female-starred festival experience. 
This is the first collaboration between playwright Alexandra Silber and Dutch Kills Theater.  Following the success of Antigone in the Loose Leaf Reading Series, artistic director Alley Scott commissioned Alexandra to write two more plays and put them together with Antigone to form a thematically connected series centered around women. This year will see the professional development of these plays. On February 2nd, we had a successful Equity 29 Hour Reading of Antigone and we plan to have the same for Trojan Women in May, and for Medea in November. We would like to secure a New York Theater space for the fall of 2016, in order to stage a three-week festival for these wonderful plays. Audiences will be able to see the three pieces all together in an immersive triple-bill experience, or as individual performances on different days.

The Budget  

Here is what your money will go towards right away:

READING PERFORMANCE SPACE: All readings will take place in a 60 seat professional space. $1200 

REHEARSAL SPACE: $750

ACTORS: We will pay each of our actors to honor their work, commitment, and craft. $2700

STAGE MANAGER: The unsung hero of the theater world. $600 

DIRECTORS: At the helm of the ship. $300 

OFFICE/PRINTING/INSURANCE: Scripts, volunteer accident insurance, and the little things that really make all of the difference. $1200 

WRITING: For Ms. Silber. $300 

SECURING A DOWNTOWN THEATER:  With a space and dates in the calendar set we can start assembling our team.  $10,000


 

DUTCH KILLS THEATER

Headed by artistic director Alley Scott,  Dutch Kills Theater has been developing and producing quality work since 2011, including plays, translations, physical theater, adaptations, puppetry, and cabaret. 2015 will see the third annual Loose Leaf Reading Series and full workshops of 5 new plays. 


ALEXANDRA SILBER  

A Grammy nominated singer and actress, Alexandra has been called "the fastest-rising soprano in musical theater" by the Huffington post. She has led many casts both internationally and in America, and starred on Broadway in Master Class by Terrance McNally. She made her Carnegie Hall debut last April. Alexandra trained in Glasgow at The Royal Conservatoire of Scotland, an arts academy to which she often returns in order to teach masterclasses. She is currently a professor at PACE University, where she first adapted Antigone and Trojan Women for her students. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Please feel free to share this campaign on social media using the hashtag #DK3Greeks. We want to spread the word! Follow us on twitter at @DutchKillsNYC and @alsilbs and like us on Facebook! 

If you would like to help out more with this project, your time and energy could be absolutely invaluable to us as a volunteer: running house, selling merchandise and more. Please contact us at alley@dutchkillstheater.com. 

 

Artists who have participated so far 

Brennan Brown, Logan Riley Bruner, Ethan Carlson, Christian Coulson, John Cullum, Tommy Evich, Alphonse Gonzales, Shuler Hensley, Sheryl Kaller, Jeb Kreager, Erica Malachowski, Kim Martin-Cotten, Emily Nies, Lexi Rabadi, Daniel Rowan, Peter Scolari, Alley Scott, Iris Sharp, Lucille Sharp, Tracy Shayne, Alexandra Silber,  Alexandra Socha, Jason Tam, and Zach Zaromatidis.

story:
Wrestling for Charity Event in Aid of Make A Wish

4th June 2015 in Nottingham, England

Short Summary

  • My name is Glenn E. Estes and I am a student finishing a BA(Hons) in Theatre Arts. I'm a huge wrestling fan and wanted to combine my passion for the medium with my studies and with my wish to give something to people that need a bit of help.
  • This campaign is to help finance the set-up costs for the charity event that I am putting on as my final major performance in order to get my degree as I have discovered just how expensive it is to host any charity event let alone one of this type. All the money raised through this campaign will go to ensuring the event has the best possible infrastructure and talent available.
  • As part of the event I am looking to include a merchandise table and a raffle so I am also hoping to make sure that these things are the best quality possible and part of the fund will hopefully go towards purchasing the main raffle prize which I'm looking to be 2 tickets to Wrestlemania 32.

What We Need & What You Get

  • The goal has been set at £2000 which covers ring rental, venue costs, insurance, salaries for performers and staff, posters, merchandise and prizes for the raffle (though I will be seeking help from local stores as well I want to make sure even if they aren't forthcoming that prizes and merchandise is available)
  • For Perks there will be thank you cards, videos, etc as well as T-shirts and posters, and if you give big some nice surprises.
  • Even if the goal is not reached all the money raised will go to offsetting the costs as discussed. That way all money raised on the day through ticket sales, merchandise, and the raffle can go straight to the Make A Wish Foundation. And if we raise more than the set goal everything above paying the bills also goes straight to Make A Wish.

The Impact

  • The impact is simple. You get to help make the wishes of very ill children come true as well as helping a mature University student make his vision come alive.
  • Seriously, every little bit helps the event be bigger and better and the hope is that we can carry that through into the fundraising on the day.

Risks & Challenges

  • The biggest challenge at the moment  is securing merchandise and raffle prizes
  • Going store to store in the area and asking them to donate will only go so far so money from this campaign that can be used to purchase genre specific prizes will help a lot.

Other Ways You Can Help

  • If you can't give money for this cause then please share the campaign and the event across as much social media as you can
  • If you are in England and are willing to hang-up posters when they are printed let me know so I can send you the file.
  • Go ahead and use the Indiegogo share tools!
  • Willing to help in other ways that I haven't mentioned? Get in touch.

And that's all there is to it.

story:
Theater on the Move, a not for profit 501c3 performing arts organization has been training children and offering affordable quality entertainment in Southwest Chicago and its suburbs for over 30 years. Our program has provided thousands of area children with the opportunity to explore their performing talents. It also improves social and communication skills and in many cases has proven beneficial in creating the challenge needed to improve reading skills. With your sponsorship, Theater on the Move can continue to train and inspire our talented youth.

For many years we operated our own theater/performing arts center producing shows 40 weekends each year and offering classes in drama, voice and dance. Our past child performers have gone on to perform on Broadway, choreograph for local theaters, teach, and become talent agents.  Those who moved on to other occupations learned invaluable lessons from their theater days.  Costs grew prohibitive.   
Our Budget
Our goal of $4,000 provides rental of the theater space and technical support for 2 shows and rehearsal time, rehearsal space at a local park district building, insurance and modest payments to the musicians and artists who will help produce our show. The remaining workers who costume the show and provide supervision for the children are volunteers.  
Ticket prices are kept reasonable to allow as many community members to enjoy theater as possible.  We generally barely cover expenses with ticket sales.  Funds raised by this campaign would allow us to keep our prices at the current low cost of $20 for adults, $15 for seniors and $10 for children and provide seed funds for next year's production.
What's in It for You?
Funds contributed are tax deductible as allowed by law.  If we do not meet our goal, funds will be used to defray production expenses.  
Donations of $50 or more will receive 2 tickets to either the April 11 or 12 production and recognition in the program and on the Theater on the Move website.

The Impact

Thousands of children have benefited from our programs; your support would mean that new generations could experience the joy of finding their voices and expressing their talents.  What a pleasure to see a new performer who could barely be heard at audition thrill audiences with their confident performance!  Children who are busy with theater develop poise, confidence, teamwork and respect for others along with improving their performing skills.

Risks & Challenges

Producing a show is always a challenge.  Many factors can derail the best laid plans for rehearsal schedules and attendance. For example, our reservations at the park district had to be rearranged due to an unprecedented run-off election for the mayor of Chicago; our park district doubles as a polling place!  

Having been in the business for more than 30 years, we take these obstacles and make them stepping stones!

Other Ways You Can Help

Any contribution is appreciated. If you can't spare a dime (and poor actors get this) please come to see our show and spread the word about our efforts.  Check us out at TheaterontheMove.com.  Now & Then has a few laughs comparing life when the veteran performers were young to today.  You might be surprised at the similarities!

For many years we operated our own theater/performing arts center producing shows 40 weekends each year and offering classes in drama, voice and dance. Our past child performers have gone on to perform on Broadway, choreograph for local theaters, teach, and become talent agents.  Those who moved on to other occupations learned invaluable lessons from their theater days.  Costs grew prohibitive.   
Our BudgetOur goal of $4,000 provides rental of the theater space and technical support for 2 shows and rehearsal time, rehearsal space at a local park district building, insurance and modest payments to the musicians and artists who will help produce our show. The remaining workers who costume the show and provide supervision for the children are volunteers.  Ticket prices are kept reasonable to allow as many community members to enjoy theater as possible.  We generally barely cover expenses with ticket sales.  Funds raised by this campaign would allow us to keep our prices at the current low cost of $20 for adults, $15 for seniors and $10 for children and provide seed funds for next year's production.What's in It for You?Funds contributed are tax deductible as allowed by law.  If we do not meet our goal, funds will be used to defray production expenses.  Donations of $50 or more will receive 2 tickets to either the April 11 or 12 production and recognition in the program and on the Theater on the Move website.
    The Impact Thousands of children have benefited from our programs; your support would mean that new generations could experience the joy of finding their voices and expressing their talents.  What a pleasure to see a new performer who could barely be heard at audition thrill audiences with their confident performance!  Children who are busy with theater develop poise, confidence, teamwork and respect for others along with improving their performing skills.
    Risks & Challenges Producing a show is always a challenge.  Many factors can derail the best laid plans for rehearsal schedules and attendance. For example, our reservations at the park district had to be rearranged due to an unprecedented run-off election for the mayor of Chicago; our park district doubles as a polling place!  
Having been in the business for more than 30 years, we take these obstacles and make them stepping stones!
    Other Ways You Can Help Any contribution is appreciated. If you can't spare a dime (and poor actors get this) please come to see our show and spread the word about our efforts.  Check us out at TheaterontheMove.com.  Now & Then has a few laughs comparing life when the veteran performers were young to today.  You might be surprised at the similarities!

story:
Hello! Thank you for checking out our campaign!

My name is Steven Modena. I am an actor, director, and composer working in Minneapolis, Minnesota. I am also the new artistic director of Albino Squirrel Productions. This year we will be performing a fun new musical for the Minnesota Fringe Festival. 
As theatre artists, we try to create entertaining and thought provoking work. We hope to provide a hilarious and eye opening experience with our new show. 
Pocahontas: Or how I Learned to Stop Worrying and Love the Mouse

Written by Bryn Tanner
Music and Lyrics by Steven Modena and Bryn Tanner
Directed by Steven Modena

The story follows a young woman named Allison who has always wanted to be a princess. So she auditions for a musical and is hired by two jolly yet scheming brothers named Roy and Walt (no relation) who offer her the role of Pocahontas in the new broadway musical adaptation of the Disney classic. But it turns out that being a Disney Princess may not be all it's cracked up to be as she discovers that the brothers do not seem to care that much about historical accuracy or honoring Native American culture.
A  show about how we as a society white wash history to make it more palatable for modern audiences...with jokes!

What We Need

We have a goal of 1,500 dollars for this show. There are various specific things we need to acquire to make the show a success. And we really need your help to make it happen.

1. The producer and playwright has made an initial investment of $375 to rent the show space for the festival that we really want to make back. We will be performing at HUGE Theatre in Minneapolis. 
2. We are working with simple costumes and props. But we have no concrete additional budget. All costumes, props, and set pieces are being paid for out of pocket or found and borrowed by myself, and the various other artists involved in the project. This includes the rental of  acting blocks. Costumes for 6 cast members. Some props for the show including fake weapons and food. Some chairs and tables. Fabrics to make a tree character (Grandmother Willow) as well as her magical dancing chorus of trees. There are all kinds of little purchases that add up quite a bit. The initial budget for these things is in the range of $125.
3. And finally, compensation for the cast and crew. We have six actors, a director, a stage manager, and two accompanists to pay. Totaling 10 company members.They are all dedicating their time and effort to make this show a success and to make art. They take time off of their day jobs, spend money on gas and bus fare, and even invest their own money to help bring this important story to the world. We want to pay them all for their time. We would like to get at least a 100 dollar stipend to everyone involved in the project. A small sum for all of their hard work. This would require an additional 1,000 dollars to pay the cast and crew. All other money we hope to make will be a portion of profits after the show mounts. And as they say, nobody gets rich off of Fringe.
All money made beyond the goal will be distributed equally among the cast and crew.

What You Get

We have a wide variety of perks available. 
These include: Being recognized in the show programs, personalized drawings, recordings of songs from the show, tickets to the show, and SO MUCH MORE! Well...at least SOME much more!

What we're trying to do (What's it all about?)

In addition to being a hilariously funny show, we believe that this show has a very important message. It is a commentary on how we as a society white wash, misunderstand, and sensationalize history. Especially in entertainment and the media. We want to entertain our audiences, but we also want to raise awareness. 
While the show does take a lighthearted approach to it's subject matter, the message is clear. The atrocities committed against Native Americans have been glossed over...sometimes intentionally...and it is time to start recognizing how entertainment affects our perception of other cultures.  
But we can only bring this important show to our audiences with your help. Any small donation will bring us one step closer to sharing this story with the world. 

Albino Squirrel Productions
We are a brand new company made up of many theatre artists residing in or around Minneapolis, MN. Many of whom have participated in the Minnesota Fringe Festival before. 
Cast and Crew:
Written by Bryn Tanner
Directed by Steven Modena
Music & Lyrics by Steve Modena and Bryn Tanner 
Stage Manager/Scenic Designer: Carter Roeske
Accompanist/Music Director: Sarah Dewhirst

CAST (in order of appearance): 

Jenny Mae Reierson: Allison/Pocahontas 
John Naumann: Walt/Kocoum 
Bryn Tanner: Roy/Ratcliffe/Grandmother Willow 
Mason Tyer: Alan Menken/John Smith 
Tucker Brewster Schuster: Chief/Dave 
Julia Dahl: Thomas/Nakoma 


Other Ways You Can Help!

There are many other ways to contribute to our cause other than donating. Please help us to promote this show. Share our page. Like us on Facebook. Come see the show. Tell your friends!

story:
Short Summary

My name is Kaitlin Overton and I am the creator, director, and one of the producers of the Solitude House Theatre Project. I am also a co-founder of the new theatre company No Dominion Theatre Co. with Michael Joel; Michael is my co-producer on this project and also an actor in the piece. We founded this company with a fellow college classmate, Aryana Sedarati, in the hopes of creating new, original theatre that means something both to us and to the world. That is what we aim to do with this new piece as well: what is currently unofficially titled the Solitude House Theatre Project.
What is the Solitude House Theatre Project? Great question! This project is the development process for what will become an original devised theatre piece produced by No Dominion Theatre Co. The performance will take place at the historic Solitude House in High Bridge, New Jersey on November 7th, 8th, 14th, and 15th of 2015. The show itself draws from interviews conducted with the community of High Bridge, NJ and already-existing works such as The Cherry Orchard and Three Sisters by Anton Chekhov, as well as poetry selections by Walt Whitman and Henry David Thoreau; the final product will be a performance that utilizes all of these texts and explores the ideas of hometown, moving, and what it really means to find your place in the world. 
This campaign will fund costs for this project but also future costs of our theatre company. It is crucial we are able to fund all of our projects. Costs for this project include compensation for all actors and the creative team, production costs such as costumes, set pieces, and props, and advertising materials: fliers, postcards, and business cards for the company. It means a lot to us as budding theatre creators that we will be able to fund this project as well as compensate our actors and creative team for all of their time and efforts.
By contributing to this project, you will truly be helping us produce this show. Independent theatre and new theatre companies are really on the up and up and you will be helping this piece be a part of the independent theatre community. How cool is that?! Knowing that you believe is us and in our work truly means the world to us. 

What We Need & What You Get

Our goal for this project is $4500. Here is exactly where those funds will be going:

- $500 x five actors and two creative team members
- $100 for our photographer
- $200 for incidental props/costumes/sets
- $150 for marketing materials 
- $550 for future endeavors of No Dominion Theatre Co.

For each amount donated to our campaign, there is a perk you receieve in return! For some of the smaller donations, you may receive a Facebook shoutout, your name in the program for the performance, and a handmade postcard. For larger donations, you an receive free tickets to the show or our entire season, and even be credited as a producer for our entire season!

If we do not reach our entire goal, the money will still be distributed to our actors. We plan to do the best we can in compensating our actors and creative team. We plan on reaching our goal! But if that does not happen, we will still use these funds for the items above. 


The Impact

The type of theatre we do is unique; it is new and raw and original and takes risks. This specific production is also happening in the heart of my hometown, something that is new for both me as a theatre creator and producer but also to the community of High Bridge, New Jersey. I am lucky to have gotten this amazing opportunity to rehearse and perform in the historic Solitude House and bring my theatre company to this awesome site and do theatre here. The arts scene in High Bridge is constantly growing and I am grateful and thrilled to be contributing to it. By contributing to this campaign, you are also contributing to the development of fine arts in High Bridge, New Jersey!
Our first production as a theatre company, One. Four. (Zero). by Michael Joel, also took place in Solitude House back in May of 2015. It was very well received by the community; we got lots of positivie feedback and had a great turn out. We are excited to bring more people in to see this piece and take what we learned from that production and apply it to this one!
Back in the winter of 2014-2015, I approached the High Bridge Town Council about using Solitude House as the performance venue for this piece, and they approved my proposal and idea for this theatre project. Now the performance is only a few months away! It is amazing how much support we have already gotten from the community and we are so excited about this Indiegogo campaign and the time we spend rehearsing together for this production! November will be here before we know it!

Risks & Challenges

With every theatrical endeavor comes risks and challenges; will anyone come to the show? Will people care about the material? Will people understand what the show is about? As actors, directors, and producers, we understand these questions and have asked them all our lives and throughout our college careers as theatre students. We can't always predict the future and answer these questions prematurely, but we have the tools and knowledge to work towards the answers of those questions being 'Yes.'

Social media is a huge advertising tool these days, and one that we constantly use to promote our work and projects. Facebook, Twitter, Instagram... we're on all of them! And we have a website where you can view photos and read more about us as a theatre company and what we are working on: www.nodominiontheatre.org. Word of mouth is also extremely helpful! As is advertising with lots of signage around the town as well as postcards and fliers to draw attention to the details of the performance.

As for the performance itself, we all went to school for theatre so we all know that the beginning of a productions is difficult: where to start with the script, who will be reading which lines, etc. This is why we have been having rehearsals during the past few months and workshops in order to learn more about this show ourselves. It is still in its baby stages, but eventually it will grow and develop into a final product and you will get to see it in November!


Other Ways You Can Help

If you aren't able to contribute, no problem! There are still plenty of ways you can help this project reach its goal

  • Talk about us! Either via word of mouth, email, Facebook, Twitter, Tumblr, Instagram...we love the attention! And it will truly help get the word spread about this project!
  • Come see the show in November!
  • Don't forget about the Indiegogo share tools!

Thank you so much for your support and for finding yourself here on our campaign page! Your support truly does mean the world to us. Thank you for believing in us, this company, and original theatre. We hope to see you at the performance in November!


- Kaitlin & The Solitude House Theatre Project Team

story:
The Camp and the Team

ILATHEC (International Laboratory Theatre Camp) will take place in the middle of August 2015 in Northern Greece, near Pella. It is organized by Atropos Theatre company which for the past 5 years has been organizing theatrical and anthropological projects and expeditions in different communities in Europe and Asia, as well as performances and short workshops. 

This time the idea is to invite four teachers with different backgrounds and cultures, who will lead 4 workshops during one week, and in the end to gather all material and make a performance under the direction of Stamatis Efstathiou, Atropos artistic director. All the team will live in tents and work outdoors, share simple conditions, cook and eat together. 

The possibility to take distance from the city and from the temptations of civilization is a timeless idea of working frame of Atropos theatre. The essence of this idea is that the actor-researcher devotes himself to creative training in a daily, undistracted and intensive basis. At the same time, Atropos invites external masters from different parts of the world, who develop their own independent path and share as basic philosophy the research, the constant training and the spiritual dimension of art, far away from the industry of entertainment. 


Join Our Campaign!

We want to make the training affordable to students, that's why the participation fee doesn't include some necessary expences such as masters' travel expences and salary, documentation work, project management expences, etc. Here we rely on your support! The funds raised will allow the workshop leaders to cover their tickets, accomodation and the cost of the props and materials for the workshops, to get paid for their work; and the organizers will be able to cover expences for project managing and advertising, documentation, translation, etc.

Here's our brief budget:

1100$ - teachers' travel expenses 

900$ - accomodation at the camp and food for 4 masters and 2 assistants (photographer and translator)

1600$ - teachers' salary

500$ - project managing, advertising (posters, flyers, etc.)

500$ - work of a translator

500$ - documentation

250$ - props, materials to create masks and costumes

Take a look at the rewards in the right-hand sidebar! We will be glad to thank you with different kinds of nice and delicious perks as a show of appreciation for your donations.


The Impact. What's so special about the Camp?

This camp is about many different things. First of all, it is a unique creative space in pure nature (we will live in tents on a private piece of land) where every participant can get in touch with their artistic self through different approaches to theatre, performance art and movement. The hosting venue is "The farm of peace" located in Karatzova plain, in the shadow of Mount Kaimaktsalan in Pella (Central Macedonia). The farm has a big ecological vegetable garden and vast piece of land with trees that give countless possibilities for working in the shade or in the sun. The hosts grow organic vegetables, and by donating to our campaign you will also support organic farming (because we will pay rent to the hosts and buy food from them!)

Then it is about a dialogue of cultures - workshop leaders have Greek, Russian and Iranian and Egyptian background. The final performance will be coordinated by the Greek director and actors' trainer, but will absorb all the material gained at the workshops. To some extent it will also be a revival of traditions of Ancient Greek theatre. Stamatis Efstathiou works a lot on the relationship between a protagonist(-s) and a chorus, one of points of reference of his method "Theatre of Connection" is Ancient Greek theatre. 

And the last, but not the least. We organize this project in Greece, which now is under social and economic crisis, that influences the cultural situation as well. We don't want to give in to a common decadent mood! We want to keep on working on what we love and consider important not only for the artistic circle, but for the community as a whole. The camp is being organized without any financial support from the state or from private grants. We want this work to be a positive action in the times of crisis. Apart from artistic value and opening artistic possibilities for the local rural community (people from surrounding villages can become spectators at the final performance), we will support local organic farming and give a positive feedback for Greece to the international artistic community.


Details about the Camp

If you have reached this point, probably it means that you want to learn more about us! Maybe, you even would like to participate in the camp? Here's a brief exposition about the general framework:

The camp will take place from the 17th till the 24th of August, 2015. All the work will be done in secret and less secret spots of the farm, which the team will use exclusively, without being distracted by other people. We will be working intensively from sunrise to sunset (8-9 hours) all 6 days with the necessary breaks for eating, relaxation, individual work and silence.

Four teachers will guide the team in four different themes:
- "The empty performer” 
Leader: Stamatis Efstathiou – Atropos Theatre director / Founder of Theatre of Connection
- “The journey of the actor in the world of masks” 
Leader: Sabry Zekry – Multidisciplanary artist / Founder of Recycling performance factory
- “Body and natural landscapes” 
Leader: Maria Lappa - Butoh trainer / Performer
- " Working with and without your 5 senses” 
Leader: Svetlana Antropova – Performer and organizer at Atropos Theatre

On the sixth and last day of the camp participants will present individual actions, group performance and musical improvisation under the supervision and guidance of Stamatis Efstathiou.

You can learn other details on the Camp's Facebook page or on our website.


Other Ways You Can Help

We understand if you can’t contribute money to our campaign but still want to help! In this case share our campaign and the info about the Camp to your friends, in your social media networks and to everybody who might get interested!

Get in touch with us on Facebook, read our blog, become a part of the experience!

Take a look at the rewards in the right-hand sidebar! We will be glad to thank you with different kinds of nice and delicious perks as a show of appreciation for your donations.

    The Impact. What's so special about the Camp? This camp is about many different things. First of all, it is a unique creative space in pure nature (we will live in tents on a private piece of land) where every participant can get in touch with their artistic self through different approaches to theatre, performance art and movement. The hosting venue is "The farm of peace" located in Karatzova plain, in the shadow of Mount Kaimaktsalan in Pella (Central Macedonia). The farm has a big ecological vegetable garden and vast piece of land with trees that give countless possibilities for working in the shade or in the sun. The hosts grow organic vegetables, and by donating to our campaign you will also support organic farming (because we will pay rent to the hosts and buy food from them!)
Then it is about a dialogue of cultures - workshop leaders have Greek, Russian and Iranian and Egyptian background. The final performance will be coordinated by the Greek director and actors' trainer, but will absorb all the material gained at the workshops. To some extent it will also be a revival of traditions of Ancient Greek theatre. Stamatis Efstathiou works a lot on the relationship between a protagonist(-s) and a chorus, one of points of reference of his method "Theatre of Connection" is Ancient Greek theatre. 
And the last, but not the least. We organize this project in Greece, which now is under social and economic crisis, that influences the cultural situation as well. We don't want to give in to a common decadent mood! We want to keep on working on what we love and consider important not only for the artistic circle, but for the community as a whole. The camp is being organized without any financial support from the state or from private grants. We want this work to be a positive action in the times of crisis. Apart from artistic value and opening artistic possibilities for the local rural community (people from surrounding villages can become spectators at the final performance), we will support local organic farming and give a positive feedback for Greece to the international artistic community.

    Details about the Camp If you have reached this point, probably it means that you want to learn more about us! Maybe, you even would like to participate in the camp? Here's a brief exposition about the general framework:
The camp will take place from the 17th till the 24th of August, 2015. All the work will be done in secret and less secret spots of the farm, which the team will use exclusively, without being distracted by other people. We will be working intensively from sunrise to sunset (8-9 hours) all 6 days with the necessary breaks for eating, relaxation, individual work and silence.Four teachers will guide the team in four different themes:- "The empty performer” Leader: Stamatis Efstathiou – Atropos Theatre director / Founder of Theatre of Connection- “The journey of the actor in the world of masks” Leader: Sabry Zekry – Multidisciplanary artist / Founder of Recycling performance factory- “Body and natural landscapes” Leader: Maria Lappa - Butoh trainer / Performer- " Working with and without your 5 senses” Leader: Svetlana Antropova – Performer and organizer at Atropos TheatreOn the sixth and last day of the camp participants will present individual actions, group performance and musical improvisation under the supervision and guidance of Stamatis Efstathiou.
You can learn other details on the Camp's Facebook page or on our website.   
Other Ways You Can Help We understand if you can’t contribute money to our campaign but still want to help! In this case share our campaign and the info about the Camp to your friends, in your social media networks and to everybody who might get interested!

Get in touch with us on Facebook, read our blog, become a part of the experience!

story:
Spend less than you would for ONE first-run movie...and keep the JOY open for years! 

We're nearing the end of our crowd-funding campaign! EVERY contribution helps!

It's time to put the pedal to the metal, baby! By now, you know the story:  Movie theaters have had to undergo an expensive conversion to digital projection. Many have turned to crowd-funding to cover this cost so that they could stay in business. For us, a significant increase in rent is driving the need to pay off our digital projector. 
And for you? Well, you can buy a perk such as our Date Night or our 5-Pass with Popcorn, spend LESS than you would for a show at a first-run theatre, and help keep us in the game for the long haul! Your contributions now mean big savings in the years to come. 

100% Independent.  

The Joy is 100% independently owned and operated. As such, we're a mom and pop business with all the expenses of a large building. We've set a high goal, but we'd easily surpass our target with just $20 from each of our Facebook subscribers. In other words, every contribution counts. Every dollar from our patrons, friends and local businesses will help us keep our doors open. 

The Premiums: Making it Worth Your While!

At the Joy Cinema, we strive to give you the most for your money. And we wouldn't dream of asking for contributions without giving you something in return. Take a look at our list of premiums and rewards. We've come up with some doozies, and we hope you'll find one (or two or three) you'll want. Of course, we'll have some basic packages, but here's a quick sampling of some of the crazy-fun premiums we're offering: 

  • Our One-Year Passport - good for an entire year's worth of FREE admissions.
  • The Lifer - FREE movies for LIFE!!! Are we crazy or what? 
  • The Pajama Party - Rent the Joy for a late-night screening of your favorite flick!
  • Even Weirder Wednesday - Geeks unite! YOU choose and host one of our Weird Wednesday movies! 
  • The Start-Your-Marriage-Right Package - You find the bride or groom, invite your guests, and we'll find someone to make it legal. We'll even throw in a cake.

Why All This Matters - For Businesses and Families

For the people of Tigard and the surround area, keeping the Joy open means keeping entertainment affordable. In fact, a family of four can easily save $40 by going to a movie at the Joy instead of at a multiplex. 
But the Joy is also important to the local economy and quality of life. It appeals to people who want to buy homes in the area. It attracts customers who also visit restaurants and other businesses nearby. To see what a theatre can do for a community, look at the examples right in the Portland Metro Area. Neighborhoods once in disrepair now thrive in the wake of restorations and reopenings of local, independent cinemas. 

A Labor of Love, Baby!

Simple fact #1: Nobody gets rich running a one-screen, second-run theatre.
Simple fact #2: You'll never regret doing something you love. 

Balancing these realities has been the key to our success thus far. The need to be careful with money, in fact, has driven us to be more creative and resourceful. The look of our lobby, our decor, and our onscreen pre-show were all created by members of our staff. 
Hard work, running a tight ship and a love for what we do have gotten the Joy away from the brink and back on track. Wiping out the debt taken on in our digital upgrade will ensure that we can stay open for years and keep getting better at what we do. 

Spread the Word!

As always, we thank you for your business, and we hope you'll contribute to this effort. Please use the tools provided by Indiegogo to share this with your friends, family and associates. Help us keep the Joy in Tigard.
