story:
Hold it right there you little prick!

Sorry I’m just trying to do this thing here if you don’t mind…

Well yeah I can see that you quivering barrel of deep fried turds but you’re gonna have to do better than just throwing an award in my face an expecting me to be impressed enough to fork out some cash for the likes of you


Oh…yeah I see your point. So what sort of thing should I be doing? Also what do you mean “The likes of you”? You’re just me but with bold type for  your bits.

For a start you can stop pointing that kinda stuff out it’s not big and it’s not clever. First off what’s this Angry guff you’re talking about? I wanna know more about that.

When asked to describe ANGRY director Kerala Irwin says “the phrase that floats up to the forefront of my mind most commonly is “half-naked”, both literally and metaphorically. Each character pours out half their soul, whilst hiding the rest with either badly-timed jokes, strategically placed instruments or copious amounts of foul language.” 


ANGRY has courted controversy across the country with its poetry-cum swearword script and its punk-funk music stylings. Come watch a bunch of twenty somethings in their pants, punch drums and each other to the rhythms of their inner children crying. Described as “The most important thing I've seen at NSDF, in any year” in Noises Off magazine, ANGRY promises to be a night worth remembering.

Join us as we get loud, we get violent, we get furious beyond the government-approved safety level. We will shout at you, we will swear at you, we will spill our rage at the world upon you... but we expect nothing less than the same in return.

Right, well now we’ve sorted that out. Who the fuck are the Pub Corner Poets?

The Pub Corner Poets are a group of emerging theatre makers, musicians, and spoken word artists based in Hull. Formed early in 2014 by Josh Overton and Tyler Mortimer PCP has worked hard to provide a stage for people who are passionate about their art and creating exciting work. In early November last year PCP debuted their first theatre project, Angry! After a successful run in the New Adelphi Club we were invited to perform at the National Student Drama Festival where we were awarded the Sunday Times Playwriting Award. See what people had to see about our provocative show at NSDF below:


Winner of the Sunday Times New Playwriting Award 2015

"a violent assault on our senses and sensibilities" -The Times-The party's over now


Now we have been invited to attend Incoming festival hosted by The New Diorama Theatre in London on the 9th of June. Promising to be a showcase of the best of emerging theatre making from across the country this is an exciting opportunity for us before we take on the challenge of a week long run at the world’s largest theatre festival, The Edinburgh Fringe. We are so thrilled by the opportunities we’ve been provided this summer and we hope to continue making exciting provocative work for more people to see but we simply cannot do this without your help

Aha now we get the point eh, why you need my help?

Exactly, well not really because you’re still just a paragraph with bold type but the lovely people who’ve read this far.

We need your support because as students our resources have been stretched to breaking point even getting this far. Up until this point we’ve been able to get funding together for our own shows but we are approaching a stage where we cannot rely on reviews and goodwill to get us any further. Marketing, Travel, accommodation and equipment maintenance will all exact a heavy toll on our resources over the busy summer we have ahead of us and any contribution your are able to make, large or small, would be much appreciated.

Find out more in The little book of ANGRY

story:
Our Story

The Laguna Niguel Community Theatre (LNCT) is dedicated to producing professional quality dramatic art by, with and for the citizens of Laguna Niguel.  We are a like-minded community of artists wishing to produce work that is artistically brave, morally responsible, and community-minded.  

LNCT was formed to provide for the cultural enrichment for our city and to foster the growth of the arts in our local community.  Until now, Laguna Niguel artists and patrons have had to travel to Costa Mesa, San Clemente, Laguna Beach, San Juan Capistrano, or even farther to satisfy their need for theater.  We want to bring these artistic individuals home to create a theatre community here where we live.

What We Need & What You Get

We are asking for your help to launch our inaugural performance season and to create a permanent home for theatre arts in Laguna Niguel.

  • Most of the funds raised will be used to launch our performance of Fiddler on the Roof, currently in rehearsal.  The rest will fund our community outreach programs and youth classes.
  • Every Perk is intended to immerse you in our theatrical community.   We've included everything from show tickets and behind-the-scenes tours, to acting classes and dinner with the characters from our shows.  
  • Exceeding our goals allows us to ensure the quality of our performances and begin the process of securing a permanent location.  If we miss our targets we'll scale back on small but high impact things like, costumes and sets.

A little more about us

The company is founded by husband and wife team, Jeremy and Jennifer Golden.

Jeremy, Artistic Director, and current Theatre Arts Teacher and Executive Director of the Theatre Company at Aliso Niguel High School, holds a BFA in Theatre Arts from Southern Methodist University and a MA in English.  He was also selected to participate in a Directors Summer Intensive Program at The Juilliard School and has performed, directed, and managed in a wide variety of theaters in Nebraska, Texas, and Southern California.   

Jennifer, Managing Director, is a faculty member at Saddleback College and holds a BA in English and a MS in Counseling.  Jennifer is also a performer, designer, director and manager having worked at many theaters in the South Orange County area.  Jennifer has also directed children’s theatre and served on the Board of Directors and as the parent producer for the South Orange County School of the Arts (SOCSA).

LNCT is governed by a Board of Directors who oversees the non-profit corporation.  The company is a California nonprofit corporation and is currently in the application process for their 501(c)(3) non-profit status.  It is expected that all contributions will be tax-deductible upon IRS approval of the application.


The Impact

The Laguna Niguel Community Theater supports three primary activities:

  • Live performances.
  • Theater art classes.
  • Mentoring and Internships.

Our inaugural production will be Fiddler on the Roof, music by Jerry Bock, lyrics by Sheldon Harnick, book by Joseph Stein.  The production includes 35 actors and nearly as many backstage and house crew volunteers from our community.  

Three performances will be staged at the Crown Valley Community Park Amphitheatre on August 22 and 23.

The first acting class “From Improvisation to the Scripted Scene” for ages 10-14 will begin September 3 and is made possible through our collaboration with the Laguna Niguel Parks and Recreation Department.

Theater arts, visual arts, marketing and business students from the community also serve in several summer 2015 internships including: Design, Development, Dramaturgy, Marketing, Stage Management, and Stage Production.

Other Ways You Can Help

Your donation will fund the establishment of community based theater arts and in particular, the significant costs associated with establishing a working and lasting theater company.  Part of our mission over the next 24 months is to find or build a permanent home where we can train, and share our passion with our community for years to come.  

In addition to funding we are also seeking support in the form of :

  • mentoring
  • props, set pieces or costume donations
  • sound/lighting equipment
  • printing or production services
  • volunteer hours (i.e. office, painting, building, sewing, ushers, ticket sales, sound/lighting, goodwill ambassadors

  To learn more about us and to follow our progress, please visit us at:       www.lagunanigueltheatre.org

story:
Approximately 9am April 15th, a whole block on Broadway Ave. was burned down.  

The community wants to support those that lost there homes.

We are creating an emergency fund for the 5+ residents with out homes, goods, food, and those impacted by this trauma and need special care.

  • 20 Days = $25,000 TO BEGIN!
  • The positive energy that has been brewing in this community is faced with an opportunity to overcome any depression, trauma, or other negative impacts of losing everything you own in one uncontrollable minuet 


Show The Broadway community how powerful our Love is.

story:
À peine sortis de l'école...

Tout le monde le sait, le métier de comédien n'est pas facile. Surtout lorsqu'on vient de graduer des écoles de théâtre. On a tout à construire. Jean-François Beauvais et moi-même, Gabriel Morin, avons commencé à explorer l'univers du western pour la scène aux ateliers libres, alors que nous étions étudiants au Conservatoire de Montréal.
 Un an plus tard, nos numéros western de quelques minutes sont devenus "Une dernière fois dans l'ouest" (UDFDO), la pièce de théâtre originale et sans paroles qui rend hommage à l'univers des films western-spagetthis en  les déployant dans une salle de théâtre. C'est notre première création, qui on l'espère, sera la première d'une longue série de productions théâtrales. Entourés d'une grande équipe de concepteurs (Élise Neil, Carl Vincent, Ilyaa Ghafouri et Marie-Claude Guilbeault) ainsi que de nouveaux comédiens (Sébastien René, André-Luc Tessier, Jérémie Earp-Lavergne, Carl Vincent) le spectacle arrive à la fin de sa première étape de création.
La pièce sera présentée les 28-29-30 mai, à 20h  au Studio Jean-Valcourt du Conservatoire.

La phase 1 et vous

Nos ambitions sont grandes. Nous aimerions que ce spectacle prenne de la maturité dans le milieu théâtral montréalais, pour ensuite voyager en dehors de la métropole: UDFDO est sans paroles, campé dans un univers mythique et connus de tous, en plus de s'adresser à un large public (adolescents et adultes). Il possède ainsi de grandes qualités d'exportation. Par contre puisqu'il est à son stade embryonnaire, nous faisons face à plusieurs coûts fixes, notamment la conception de costumes, d'accessoires et de décors. 
C'est là que vous entrez en jeu.
Votre soutien financier permettra l'achat de costumes et d'accessoires en plus de nous permettre la fabrication de nos deux cubes multifonctions, éléments de décors qui se transforment au courant du spectacle pour faire naître l'univers western devant les yeux des spectateurs. Par votre participation, vous nous aiderez à vaincre ce coût fixe et assurerez la pérennité de notre première création.

Pour vous 

En échange de vos dons, nous avons un système de contrepartie allant du mot de remerciement personnalisé , au remerciements publics (Facebook,programme du spectacle) personnels (mot de l'équipe, remerciement vidéo), en plus d'offrir des billets gratuits. Nous avons aussi un programme de partenariat lorsque le soutien financier atteint un certain montant (partenaire officiel, tableau d'honneur, visibilité dans le programme, ainsi que billets gratuits). 
 N'hésitez pas à partager. Si vous ne pouvez faire de don monétaire, le bouche à oreille reste une solution formidable pour nous aider.
Un gros merci à l'avance !
André-Luc tessier, Carl Vincent, Élise Neil, Marie-Claude Guilbeault, Ilyaa Ghafouri , Jérémie Earp-Lavergne, Sébastien René, Jean-françois Beauvais, Gabriel Morin.

 Un an plus tard, nos numéros western de quelques minutes sont devenus "Une dernière fois dans l'ouest" (UDFDO), la pièce de théâtre originale et sans paroles qui rend hommage à l'univers des films western-spagetthis en  les déployant dans une salle de théâtre. C'est notre première création, qui on l'espère, sera la première d'une longue série de productions théâtrales. Entourés d'une grande équipe de concepteurs (Élise Neil, Carl Vincent, Ilyaa Ghafouri et Marie-Claude Guilbeault) ainsi que de nouveaux comédiens (Sébastien René, André-Luc Tessier, Jérémie Earp-Lavergne, Carl Vincent) le spectacle arrive à la fin de sa première étape de création.
La pièce sera présentée les 28-29-30 mai, à 20h  au Studio Jean-Valcourt du Conservatoire.

La phase 1 et vous
Nos ambitions sont grandes. Nous aimerions que ce spectacle prenne de la maturité dans le milieu théâtral montréalais, pour ensuite voyager en dehors de la métropole: UDFDO est sans paroles, campé dans un univers mythique et connus de tous, en plus de s'adresser à un large public (adolescents et adultes). Il possède ainsi de grandes qualités d'exportation. Par contre puisqu'il est à son stade embryonnaire, nous faisons face à plusieurs coûts fixes, notamment la conception de costumes, d'accessoires et de décors. 
C'est là que vous entrez en jeu.
Votre soutien financier permettra l'achat de costumes et d'accessoires en plus de nous permettre la fabrication de nos deux cubes multifonctions, éléments de décors qui se transforment au courant du spectacle pour faire naître l'univers western devant les yeux des spectateurs. Par votre participation, vous nous aiderez à vaincre ce coût fixe et assurerez la pérennité de notre première création.
Pour vous 
En échange de vos dons, nous avons un système de contrepartie allant du mot de remerciement personnalisé , au remerciements publics (Facebook,programme du spectacle) personnels (mot de l'équipe, remerciement vidéo), en plus d'offrir des billets gratuits. Nous avons aussi un programme de partenariat lorsque le soutien financier atteint un certain montant (partenaire officiel, tableau d'honneur, visibilité dans le programme, ainsi que billets gratuits). 
 N'hésitez pas à partager. Si vous ne pouvez faire de don monétaire, le bouche à oreille reste une solution formidable pour nous aider.Un gros merci à l'avance !

André-Luc tessier, Carl Vincent, Élise Neil, Marie-Claude Guilbeault, Ilyaa Ghafouri , Jérémie Earp-Lavergne, Sébastien René, Jean-françois Beauvais, Gabriel Morin.

story:
What is Mercury Fur?

Mercury Fur, by Phillip Ridley, is the story of a gang of youths trying to survive by any means necessary against the backdrop of a dystopian London. They use their wits and ingenuity to navigate a landscape of nuclear bombs and hallucinogenic butterflies, yet despite the humor and the horror they experience together, even the strongest bonds of their makeshift family will be tested when one of their plans to get by goes horribly wrong. Gaining a cult status since its premiere in London in 2005, Mercury Fur remains a captivating story told at a breakneck pace about the real stakes of survival and salvation when the world is at its worst.

Mercury Fur will be performed May 4-7 in the gymnasium of Roycemore Academy, on the border of the Northwestern University campus. Student tickets are $5 and general admission is $10.

How will my donation help?

Mercury Fur is a not-for-profit and completely student-run production. Any and all donations are immensely helpful in every aspect of producing the show. Much of the funding will contribute to a variety of design-specific areas, namely lights, set, costumes, and props.  Unique to Northwestern Student Theater, the show will be staged in a non-theatrical space, and these four elements will completely transform our performance space and transport the audience into the world of the show. Another large portion of the funding will help us get the word out to the Northwestern and Evanston communities through publicity. The use of posters, flyers, and quarter-sheets are crucial in getting the word out about this production to our audience. The Mercury Fur team wants more than anything to realize a captivating, powerful, and unique vision, and every single dollar is an incredibly valuable contribution to our efforts.

Who is my donation helping?

The cast of Mercury Fur:

  • Elliot: Tom DeFrancisco
  • Darren: Axel Mark
  • Naz: Russel Kahn
  • Lola: Collin Quinn Rice
  • Spinx: Sean Foer
  • Duchess: Lindsey Olsen
  • Party Guest: Michael Fleischer

And the production team:

  • Producer: Alana Basil
    • Assistant Producer: Jake Rothstein
  • Director: Michael Rogerson
    • Assistant Director: Casey Norlin
  • Stage Manager: Sam Riese
  • Space Designer: Preston Choi
    • Assistant Space Designer: Madeleine Briggs
  • Technical Director:
  • Lighting Designer: Grace Schwartzenberger
    • Assistant Lighting Designer: Hannah Knott
  • Sound Designer: Juliet Roll
    • Assistant Sound Designer: Jason Clark
  • Costume Designer: Vanessa Strahan
    • Assistant Costume Designer: Madeleine Briggs
  • Props Designers: Delaney Burlingame and Alex Dayton
  • Blood/Gore Designer: Matthew Silverman
  • Fight Choreographer: Daniel Chenard
  • Dialect Coach: Daniel Chenard
  • Master Electrician: Ryan Miller
  • Director of Marketing: Becca Ehlers
    • Publicity Team: Adam Turkel
  • Director of Fundraising: Devon Kerr
    • Fundraising Team: Kimberly McBride, Jack Stucky
  • Graphic Designer: Sarah Sherman

How else can I help?

If you are unable to donate or are looking for ways to further assist our production, there are still some things you can do. Firstly, you can come and see Mercury Fur and watch our artistic vision unfold before your eyes. Secondly, you can spread the word about our show. Share this campaign on social media sites like Facebook and Twitter and tell everyone you know about Mercury Fur!

We are incredibly grateful for your support; after all, we couldn't do any of this if it weren't for you. Thank you so much!

story:
Incineration Congregation 

Last year, with the help of our Indiegogo supporters, Boston’s Fire Performance troupe returned to the playa for the first time in six years.  This year we are looking to go even bigger for our second annual fire show to represent Boston during the ceremonial performance.

What is Burning Man?

Burning man is an annual event that happens in the Black Rock Desert (called the playa).  It is a temporary settlement made to resemble a city that is filled with interactive art, music and fire installations.  The event lasts for eight days, and many people attend for a spiritual retreat and artistic expressive revival.

When do you perform?

Every year at Burning Man, fire groups from around the world perform their own choreographed ceremonial dance in celebration and in dedication to the honor of the "Man" prior to it being burned to the ground. This is the largest convergence of fire performers in the world and it is an honor to participate in.

Incineration Congregation has a dedicated group of fire spinners from the Boston area to perform their unique vision on playa.  Currently, our group consists of over forty individuals that are fire performers, drummers, choreographers, fire safeties, and videographers.

Information about Boston’s Incineration Congregation

Last year’s performance consisted of an elaborate theme of good versus evil that included partner acrobatic fire spinning, a fire sword and rope dart fight scene, and an array of other fire props, costumes and performance groups. This year the event's theme is 'Carnival of Mirrors' and we have already begun planning the best and most creative way to execute our performance in coordination with the theme.  

By supporting Incineration Congregation, you will help bring Boston back to the playa for our second annual performance.  

Your support will help us share our gift of fire dance to all of Black Rock!

Deadlines:

·  Burning Man: August 30- Sept 7th, 2015

·  Performance Date: September 7th, 2015

We are asking $3000 from the community to purchase:

·  Fuel to burn while fire dancing during rehearsal and our final performance on playa.

·  Shipping cost for fire equipment from Boston to Black Rock City, Nevada

·  Fund the creation of new and interesting fire props for our performance

·  Artfully crafted themed costumes to wear during the performance.

·  Safety equipment such as buckets, fire blankets, fire extinguishers, protective tarps, fueling stations and more.

PROJECTED EXPENSES

·  Safety Equipment - $300

·  Prop Construction - $550

·  Fuel Expenses -  $550

·  Costuming -  $1000

·  Transportation -  $450

·  Rehearsal Space - $350

TOTAL: $3000

**Incineration Congregation is in no way affiliated or sponsored by Burning Man.**

story:
A Killer New Musical

A shot at college, internet fame, attention from the one they like. The stakes are high at Plain Springs High's first ever Dance-a-thon. As the demonic DJ transports them to dance crazes throughout history, each contestant must face their deepest desires and greatest weaknesses. Only one couple will walk out with "The Prize." The rest won't make it out alive.

Inspired by YMTC students' personal experiences, Don't Stop Me! explores what it means to come of age while under an unbearable pressure to do it all and do it the best while everyone is watching.

Who are we?

Youth Musical Theater Company is dedicated to providing exceptional training to young theater artists through the production of exceptional musical theater.

We bring together the Bay Area’s young singer/actors and students of technical theater— (7th grade through University level)—with professional directors, designers, and musicians, creating theater that takes on challenging and sophisticated musical and dramatic themes, and that is always accompanied by a full, live orchestra.

YMTC's 2013 production of Urinetown

How Don't Stop Me! Began
In 2011 Artistic Director, Jennifer Boesing, commissioned a new musical with composer Dave Malloy and playwright Krista Knight that would serve the personal stories and struggles of it's students.  

Over the past two years, YMTC students have workshopped Don't Stop Me! working directly with the composer, playwright, director, and musical director to develop the script and music for production this summer. We are ready to bring this vibrant story to Bay Area audiences!

Composer & Playwright Rockstar Team

Dave Malloy has written music for seven full length musicals, including Natasha, Pierre & The Great Comet of 1812, an electro-pop opera based on War & Peace (2012 Richard Rodgers Award for Musical Theater; Best of 2012: NY Times, Time Out, NY Mag, NY Post). Other musicals include Beowulf - A Thousand Years of Baggage (2011 Edinburgh Herald Angel, 2008 Glickman Award, New Yorker Best of 2009); Beardo; Sandwich; and Clown Bible (“Best Play of the Year,” “Best Music,” East Bay Express 2007).  He was the 2011 composer-in-residence at Ars Nova, and has been a Guest Professor in devised music theater at Princeton and Vassar Universities. He lives in Brooklyn.

Krista Knight's work includes SALAMANDER LEVIATHAN ( KCACTF Musical Theatre Award from the Kennedy Center), CLEMENTINE AND THE CYBER DUCKS , PHANTOM BAND , and UN-HINGED: A SILENT OPERA (TerraNOVA, WordBRIDGE, Playhouse Creatures) among others. Her plays have been produced or developed at the Playwrights Center of Minneapolis, New York Theatre Workshop, Vineyard Theatre, Flea Theatre, Ashland New Plays Festival, Brown University, Live Girls!, and KSDS public radio.

Why We Matter

Art is a powerful tool that offers YMTC students a voice.  A chance to express themselves. Don't Stop Me! affords our students the unique opportunity to build a work of art from the ground up. We passionately believe that when young people have opportunities to participate in exceptional training in the theater, they are becoming not only the next generation of artists and arts appreciators, but the next generation of engaged citizens: empowered to pay attention, communicate, and energetically participate in a collaborative process.

May 2014 Workshop

Why YOU Matter
It takes a village to raise a new musical. Your support will enable our students to bring this musical -- two years in the making -- to the stage for the first time ever this summer. You can raise the next generation of artists and invest in the future of the live arts!

We will use your generous support for the following:
  • Original Cast Album - Giving our students the full experience of creating a new musical, we will be recording the musical live in a cast album that will capture these student originated roles. Every student will receive a copy.
  • Scholarships - Help us to provide young artists with financial need YMTC access to this rare opportunity to work with high level, professional artists on their passion. 
  • Rental of Performance Venue -  Make it possible to bring Don't Stop Me!  to The Malonga Casquelourd Center for the Arts in downtown Oakland for six performances over two weekends.
  • Designers/Production Team - A killer musical needs killer lights, awesome costumes, a great sound engineer and more.  Help us hire the best possible team to bring our student's vision to life.
  • Composer & Playwright Fees/Travel Stipends - We want our dynamite composer/playwright team to be able to be in the room, working side by side with our students for the entire rehearsal period up until the show opens!

Actors Ethan Ostrow and Lee Chisholm  rehearsing 

Stretch and Flex
If we surpass our goal of $8,000 extra funding will be used to take Don't Stop Me! to the next level:
  • Accessible Ticket Program - We will be able to offer free tickets to underserved students who would not otherwise be able to attend our show.
Thank you for considering being a part of this exciting musical adventure!  We appreciate any amount you may be able to give to bring Don't Stop Me! to audiences.

Can't Donate?
You can support Don't Stop Me! in other ways! Spread the word about this campaign.  Share it on Facebook, send an email to your community, and come see the show! 

YMTC's 2012 production of Ragtime


Thank You!

Composer & Playwright Fees/Travel Stipends - We want our dynamite composer/playwright team to be able to be in the room, working side by side with our students for the entire rehearsal period up until the show opens!



Actors Ethan Ostrow and Lee Chisholm  rehearsing 


Stretch and Flex

Accessible Ticket Program - We will be able to offer free tickets to underserved students who would not otherwise be able to attend our show.

Can't Donate?
You can support Don't Stop Me! in other ways! Spread the word about this campaign.  Share it on Facebook, send an email to your community, and come see the show! 




YMTC's 2012 production of Ragtime


Thank You!

story:
Tickets for ROPE at HERE are on sale NOW!

$15 General Admission
Purchase HERE

My name is Brendan Drake. Under the umbrella of my company Brendan Drake Choreography, I fuse contrasting genres, humor and theatricality to create stylized performance spectacles.

A little over a year ago, I launched my first crowdfunding effort and managed to raise $2,000 of seed money for my company’s general operations. With those funds,  I premiered work at Dixon Place, the Wild Project and Triskelion Arts Center, enjoyed a residency at MANA Contemporary and have been commissioned to create new work on students at the University of Massachusetts at Amherst. 

NOT BAD FOR JUST A YEAR

In addition, I also plunged head first into the world of fashion, acting as movement coordinator for over 14 editorial shoots - working with Cate Blanchette, Lorde, Elle & Porter Magazines and choreographed the fall 2014 campaign for Adidas Originals/Pharrall Williams which can be seen here.

CURIOUS YET?

I was also able to begin work on ROPE, which had its developmental premiere at Gowanus Loft Brooklyn in March 2015. I am so excited to continue expanding ROPE into an evening length production after being awarded a generous grant by the CUNY Dance Initiative at Baruch College which allows me phenomenal rehearsal space at no expense to me personally. 

WHAT IS ROPE?

Inspired by the camp of Hollywood Film noir and the closeted gay experience, Rope is a work for four dancers that creates a correlation between homosexual innuendo and villainy.

NOW THAT I HAVE YOUR ATTENTION

I am so excited to be premiering a BIGGER, BADDER version of ROPE through a fabulous opportunity at HERE. 

This production is a part of SubletSeries@HERE: Co-op, HERE's curated rental program, which provides artists with subsidized space and equipment, as well as technical support.

ROPE has been a passion project of mine for the past year and I want it produced in a very real way.  Funds raised from this campaign will go towards:

  • Technical and General Management
  • More Advanced Marketing Efforts
  • Press Materials
  • Adequate Compensation for the All Involved with the Production 

Additionally, the goal of this fundraiser is to create ticket sales at the box office which will in turn create funds for me to move forward with ROPE and future projects. In a sense, this is more of an investment opportunity in my company, and me, than a fundraiser.

 Brendan Drake Choreography is a proud fiscally sponsored 501(c)3 non-profit organization through Fractured Atlas. I cannot stress enough the importance your contribution makes to the success of this production and my career. By making a tax-deductible donation, you are showing your unwavering support not just for myself, but for dance and all independent artists alike.

Can't donate? Spread the love and sing our praises. There is strength in numbers so  follow us on Facebook, Twitter and Instagram, share your excitement over our show and be sure to get your tickets for ROPE at HERE August 18th-23rd.

Can't donate? Spread the love and sing our praises. There is strength in numbers so  follow us on Facebook, Twitter and Instagram, share your excitement over our show and be sure to get your tickets for ROPE at HERE August 18th-23rd.

story:
Short Summary

We are GROOV3, a high-energy dance class that is making choreographed dance accessible to the masses. Our mission is to inspire change, and build a global community through the power of dance. 

What started out as just a fun dance class once a week has now turned into one of the largest dance fitness communities in Los Angeles... and we are starting to spread throughout the country (and world).

GROOV3 is more than just calorie-burning; its a confidence-building, stress-reducing, mentally stimulating, full body experience. 

We've become an extensive family, but we truly believe that you can't have a community without an official hub! 

We are embarking on the biggest endeavor to date: taking on our very own community space that will encompass everything from classes, events, trainings, movie nights, shows, and filming (lots of) content. This is a once in a life time opportunity for us to really begin to build out more programming, and connect more people locally and worldwide! 

Located on the border of Culver City and Playa Vista, your contributions will help build the foundation for what will be, without a doubt, the most special place for all things DANCE. 

What We Need & What You Get

We want to create an environment that can not only be fully customizable for classes, shoots, events, and shows, but we want to set the tone for a dance space the way WE want it.

In order to create all this, we need FLOORS, MIRRORS, SOUND, and LIGHTING. As you can imagine, these components are not inexpensive, but it will benefit everyone. 

To build the studio space we envision, cost would be an excess $60,000!  However, we are going to you, the community, to help raise $25,000. This amount will enable us to purchase and install the initial items we need, so we can open our doors as soon as possible (floors -$11k, sound - $5k, lighting - $5k, mirrors - $2,500, locker/lounge area - $1,500). *These prices include equipment and labor.

We've designed some great perks for you: imagine getting free classes for one month, or even one year (depending on your donation amount). You would spend that money anyway, so why not contribute to this campaign? 

If we don't reach our full goal, any money raised will go towards the base cost of items. Maybe we'll only be able to start with the necessary basics (floors, mirrors, and sound), and will have to wait until we can raise more money for lighting and a locker/lounge area.

The Impact

There are lots of ways we could have gone about getting capital for this project, but we truly believe the new space will benefit the community: we wanted all of you to personally feel like you had a hand in laying the groundwork for this epic new spot. 

Because the space was previously used for film production, this will enable us to quickly start filming various creative content for all the GROOV3RS around the world to benefit from. 

Imagine how awesome it will be for us to stream classes live! We even have some new concepts we will be experimenting with which could literally change the dance fitness business. Sounds exciting, right?!

Risks & Challenges

This is a HUGE space (3,600sq. ft.), and a huge responsibility! We will need to increase our staff, and our overhead has nearly doubled. Scared? YES! Extremely excited? HECK YES! 

We have gotten this far because of the love and support from all of you, and we truly believe we are creating something that will continue to further our mission of changing lives and creating a GLOBAL community through the power of dance. 

We have a great team in place that's ready for action, and have set up a solid plan for success over the next 6-12 months. We are ready for challenges and excited to take this on.  We just need you!

Other Ways You Can Help

We know it's hard to give money, but that doesn't mean you can't help in other ways:

  • Share this campaign on your social networks. Maybe you have friends, or friends of friends who might be able to help (don't forget to use the indiegogo share tools).
  • If you are connected to a product or other service that could help our efforts in putting the space together, please email us.

We can't say it enough, THANK YOU!!

story:
MANSON is a Senior project, one-act play going up at Purchase College in the Underground Theatre. The project is the combined efforts of seniors Nicole Erkoboni, director, Parker Harris, playwright, Rebecca Rein, stage manager and Melissa Kettner, dramaturg. The play dates are March 11th at 6:30, 12th, 13th at 7:30, and there will be two shows on the 14th at 2:30 and 7:30. There will be a talk back after the final show on the 14th. 

Hi, I'm Sam Jaffe, who along with Nicole Ehrhard, act as the assistant director to MANSON. I initially heard about MANSON when Nicole, who was my director at that point, approached me mentioning how she needed an assistant director. Knowing who would be involved and the amount of talent that would be associated with this project, I immediately jumped at the opportunity and offered my time. The script has been tweaked and rehearsed and the characters have been cast. 

The plot follows the elusive cult leader, Charles Manson, during his time in jail. While in jail he is haunted by the ideas of his former followers and colleagues, including some like Jeffrey Dahmer and Sadie Atkins, all the while Manson forms an unusual relationship with his prison guard. The cast is as followed:

Charles Manson: Mike Miele

Jim Jones: Amine Kassaoui

Jefferey Dahmer: Nicholas Tyler Corbin

Guard: Vince Lane

Sadie Atkins: Ali Henderson

Patricia Krenwinkle: Rebecca Wierman

We are in need of donations in order to provide set, costumes, props, and much more. Any amount counts and we are so thankful!

story:
Coast to Coast Theatre Collaboration of UK and US Artists 

Two directors, separated by an ocean and a continent, discover the raw poetry of a genius cult writer, they produce his work to great acclaim in their home cities, and look ahead to turning his poetic words again into live performance. They serendipitously enquire about doing the same show at the same time...and a brilliant rep-project is born!

MERCURY FUR directed by Frances Loy 2010

Five years ago Frances Loy directed the first major London revival of Philip Ridley's shocking Mercury Fur, two years later Paul Takacs took on the American premiere of Ridley's Tender Napalm. 

August, 2015, they are introduced as competitors for the rights to perform Ridley's brutal one-woman piece Dark Vanilla Jungle - just as Phil reveals its male companion piece Tonight with Donny Stixx.

TENDER NAPALM directed by Paul Takacs 2012

“Philip Ridley follows the dark and murky byways of lives that have gone lyrically wrong in language that lacerates any vestigial sense of well-being and “all’s right with the world” in an audience.”
The Independent, UK, on Dark Vanilla Jungle, Edinburgh Festival, 2013
“Philip Ridley delivers a heart wrenching blend of tenderness and viciousness”
The Independent, UK, on Tonight with Donny Stixx, Edinburgh Festival, 2015

Philip Ridley is a unanimously lauded playwright from the UK, whose work kickstarted the in-yer-face theatre movement scene of the 1990'swhich included writers like Mark Ravenhill and Sarah Kane; Phil has arguably emerged the leader of the movement, who continues to produce startling work every year which wins rave reviews, critical and audience acclaim, and has achieved cult status. His work has been produced in piecemeal in the United States, with audiences clamouring for more.

In August 2015, the New Group, NYC, presented Ridley's shocking play Mercury Fur, and New York audiences reacted with enthusiasm to the new setting of their own city:

"Mercury Fur is a profoundly moral play...the play's stunningly indeterminate ending leaves you moved, muddled and gasping for air"    The New York Times on Mercury Fur, August 2015

In 2013 Ridley opened Dark Vanilla Jungle in Edinburgh, which transferred to London to great acclaim, and Tonight with Donny Stixx was completed and premiered summer 2015 at the Edinburgh Festival - this is the first global production since then. This is also the first time these companion pieces have been presented and created together, and it is a US debut for both pieces. Ridley is a valued friend of Frances Loy and supports the project as a cohesive piece, giving it its combination name TONIGHT/JUNGLE.

On January 21st 2016, both shows will open at the Here Arts Center in NYC and run in rep - Frances will direct Harry Farmer as Donny, and Paul will direct Robyn Kerr as Andrea, shared design team, made up of Steven Kemp (set), Dante Olivia Smith (lights) and Toby Algya (sound) will create a cohesive stage in which to explore these visceral, lyrical pieces, staged side by side and created with a shared creative vision, for an audience eager to see work that pulls viciously on their heart strings by way of ripping out their guts.

 The production will then transfer to Los Angeles later in 2016.

This campaign is being created by Ferment Theatre, the LA based producers, covering half the production costs of the entire project for both New York and Los Angeles, and is being run by Artistic Director Frances Loy, Producer Belinda Gosbee, and Associate Producers Jillian Barba, Jeff Mitchell and Tom Curitore.


Money Money Money

We are fundraising for our part of the full production budget, which totals $30,000. This covers ferment theatre's share of the project taking place in both cities.

Although our indiegogo campaign target is high, our main aim we're reaching for is the initial $13,000 we need to get the production on New York

This money covers:

- our half of the fees for the creative team, actors and stage managers. We are firm believers that even in this industry in which we toil for love, we owe it to our colleagues to lead the way in providing more than a glass of wine at the end of the run. These are professionals who deserve to be  compensated for their talent, dedication and dogged determination to create incredible theatre

- flights for the LA team to fly to New York, and our share of the design team's flights to LA - it would be a shame to raise the fees for the team only to make them spend it on their travel!

- our half of the set and costumes budget

- space hire/development in Los Angeles

- performance rights for Los Angeles

- our half of all press and marketing costs. This is arguably the area in which we just can't cut the costs, in order to get the reach to the audiences we want, and to get the all important critic in the room, we have to pay (again, the professionals) the people who can make this happen. HAVE NO FEAR we shall still be utilizing every creative free way of spreading the word, please help by utilising all your social media outlets!


Frances Loy: Why this piece, now, why me?

I worked pretty tirelessly on the London theatre circuit for several years, juggling menial paid jobs with incredible directing experiences, co-founding and running an acclaimed alternative space theatre company and somehow keeping two small humans alive in the process. Three years ago our family moved to America where I was given the downtrodden visa status H4 - leave to remain but not to work. While it has been wonderful to have had the opportunity to be with my children, I have seriously missed my work, my community. My confidence over whether I could even run a rehearsal room again was at rock bottom, until someone recently gave me the chance to prove myself again. With the reforged love for my craft, along with a very handy Green Card (Thanks Obama!), this project was born and it is literally my blood and guts and heart and life running through it.

I have long adored Phil's work; I mounted the first major London revival of Mercury Fur in 2010, to critical acclaim and sell-out audiences; he has remained a valued friend and I have been biding my time for the right place, space and moment to return to his work again.

Both TONIGHT WITH DONNY STIXX and DARK VANILLA JUNGLE are incredible stand alone pieces that speak to the darkest reaches of human experience, in the wonderfully macabre but poetical way that Phil has. These young people have everything thrown at them and yet they continue to strive to be the best they can be, to survive and find love and acceptance, a connection. Ultimately society wins, and they fail, but not without leaving an audience full of conflicted feelings of abhorrence and empathy. These are everypeople, very much depicting the consistent failure of our most vulnerable young people, people whose tragic loss of worth and potential happens every single day. They are comments on underage sex trafficking, gun crime, grief, mental illness, illusion, perception, obsession, socio-economic stigma. But most of all, they are two people, two sides of the same coin, just trying to connect to something real, yet only managing to survive by becoming completely enveloped by their fantasy lives. There is never NOT a time to be staging this production.

For me, the timing could not be more fated and serendipitous: I'm so excited to be creating this project with Paul Takacs, a New York based American director, who has also found great success directing Phil's work before now. Paul initially intended to mount DARK VANILLA JUNGLE over a year ago - it just seems too coincidental that life circumstances forced him to delay until, unbeknown to him, I was finally ready to work again and Phil was about to complete TONIGHT WITH DONNY STIXX. We have a shared vision for what a rep production of these two pieces can give an audience prepared to have them both laid bare before them, and are committed to creating a cohesive design that seamlessly transports us between and within these two worlds. 

We're also incredibly lucky to be following close on the heels of a highly successful run of MERCURY FUR by the New Group in NYC - it feels like America is on the cusp of embracing Philip Ridley, and to have this opportunity to share his work and to provide a platform for it is wonderful. It's also creating fabulous opportunities for our actors, stage managers and designers to be able to showcase their work in two such opposing but equally important and dynamic cities in America...everyone is on board with this production and truly excited about what it beholds for us all.

What if?....

When we first decided to go ahead with this show, Paul threw "Spring" around as potential timeline....only a few months ago he found the perfect venue in NYC, the problem being the dates are much sooner than anticipated. I don't deny the overwhelming fear of failure is never far away - how to raise this much money in such a short amount of time particularly when Christmas is fast approaching. The very day we agreed to bite the bullet and go for it, even though it's going to be by the skin of our teeth, I was mid meltdown when a dear friend called me for a pep talk...the first thing he said was "What happens if you don't do it?" I didn't have an answer for him; I haven't once considered that this may not happen. Somehow we will find a way, basically it can't NOT happen - there is already too much love, commitment and passion being poured into this project. Every single cent will bring us closer to realising it, and for that, we are truly grateful.

Other Ways You Can Help

Please share the hell out of our campaign - we are giving ourselves such a short amount of time to raise what feels to us like a huge sum of money, and while we're under no illusions that this will be the new pebble watch and go viral, there may be someone you know who thinks "sure, it's worth chucking $10 I found in my car glove compartment at them"...every. cent. helps.....

THANKYOU!!!

story:
Why you should donate money to help I Love Dance! open a studio...

ILD! has been traversing the city of Atlanta and its suburbs for 11 years bringing dance to children of working families that otherwise wouldn't have dance in their school setting.

ILD! has built a trusted reputation and home base in the Tri-Cities area (Hapeville, East Point & College Park) over thousands of miles and many, many costume changes.

For years, parents and students have asked me, "Ms. A, when are you going to open a dance studio?" These questions have now practically escalated to people beating down my door wondering when I will open the doors to an underserved area.

We have found a home in Hapeville that's the right location, layout and size. However, our space needs repairs/renovations inside and out.

Youth and adults in the areas surrounding Hapeville will finally have a place to dance that is diverse, modern, and of course, filled with dance and fitness classes that are RELEVANT to the times. We plan to be an inclusive dance studio, offering classes for those who use a wheelchair, the blind and deaf community and those with other mobility limitations such as Parkinson's.

Please help us raise 10,000 in 15 days so we can open our doors in 2016. Children's classes will begin in March and adult classes will launch in August. Donating to ILD! will enrich thousands of lives and improve our community. Please help be a part of the wonderful change that is happening in Southwest Atlanta. Thank you.

Children's classes will begin in March and adult classes will launch in August. Donating to ILD! will enrich thousands of lives and improve our community. Please help be a part of the wonderful change that is happening in Southwest Atlanta. Thank you.

story:
What are these Bits and Chunks you speak of??

Hi friends! 

For those of who don't already know me or feel as though you just don't know enough, I am Bella, your local ATL choreographer, performer, and general weird, wired, and witty (or at least I like to think so) lady around town.

I have been dancing for years upon years and finally settled into full on creation mode in Atlanta circa 2014. And to keep my stage game on point, I still continue to perform as often as I can with many talented local choreographers.

And now for a bit about why we're all here reading this page:


Bits and Chunks

Bits and Chunks is a movement narrative about the inner grotesque. It is a physical representation of neurotic manifestations; anxiety, anger, jealousy, rage, lust, control. As repulsive or unacceptable as these states can be, they are inherently human and reside, to some degree, in each of us. Where it gets gritty and personal is in the choices we make to acknowledge, accept, repress, or indulge in the ecstasy of emotional submersion. What I've found through my own experiences is that to acknowledge the neurosis is to make space for the beast; to mollify the monster. Without the grotesque, the ugly, the frightening, how can we recognize and appreciate that which is beautiful, gentle, and serene? 
Take away the ugly and perhaps all that remains is tedious geniality. Now wouldn't that be a tragedy?

Why does this need to happen? 

I want to transport you, the audience, to a state of mind crowded with a lot of messy emotions. I want you to live inside my head for 15 minutes and see if the interior design is similar to your own. Maybe it is, maybe it isn't. Maybe you love the decor or maybe you leave thinking, "Jesus, Mary, and Joseph, better her than me." Either way, we will have experienced an intentional moment of shared reality and nothing would make me happier.  
So to make all this magic happen I have enlisted a crew of dancers and a maker of masks to shape the visual landscape, and these people deserve millions of dollars for their effort and artistry. Lucky for you, we shall be asking for generous donations of a much more reasonable sum and in return you'll receive a special gift to commemorate our collaboration. Indeed, as a donor you are officially an invaluable collaborator. 


The Financial Break Down:

Artist salaries:
Dancers salaries: $3,000
  • compensation covers rehearsal time and performances for 8 dancers involved in various capacities throughout this process
Mask maker: $400
  • Naked Headless, a.k.a. Mathew Maher, has painstakingly crafted 8 individual and totally original masks specifically for Bits and Chunks. Last I heard, the man clocked 50+ hours of creation time and he's still tweaking them! A consummate professional and perfectionist is he.
Production fees: $400
  • the fantastic dance film directed, shot, AND edited by my cinema wizard of a brother, Guillermo Dorado
Printing, processing fees: $200
  • this covers showcase application fees, tech fees, and the production costs for promotional materials
Grand total = $4000!
For your generous donation, you will receive a super special gift! These nifty donor perks are a collection of all kinds of cool goodies set at a variety of price levels. No amount is too small....or too big!

So what happens to the money if we don't reach our fundraising goal?? 
Whatever we raise will first be distributed to the dancers, mask maker, and cinematographer. Anything left over will go towards our production costs. It is so important for us to hit our fundraising goal because if we don't, any costs not covered by this campaign will come out of my pocket. And while I definitely didn't get into the art world to get rich, it would be nice to at least come out even! 


Other Ways You Can Help!

Strugglers unite! No one understands financial struggle better than an independent artist, and everyone one of us in this project is a struggling indie art maker. If contributing money just isn't an option for you, no fears my dears, you are still a crucial piece to our puzzle. SHARE, SHARE, SHARE! Get the word out to your friends and loved ones and let them know why they just have to help us out! You never know, if you show your passion maybe Moms will want to help ease your existential suffering by throwing a dollar or two our way.

story:
Hello, I’m Roger Grunwald, a performing artist and playwright — the actor in and creator of The Obligation, a provocative new one-person play.  Through drama and humor, The Obligation explores little-known aspects of The Holocaust and the post-war survivor experience and asks: Who decides what culture, race and ethnicity mean? What is identity? Why do we demonize "the other”? 

The Obligation, which is being directed by Nancy Carlin (see bio below), has great personal meaning to me. It was inspired by, and is in homage to, my mother who, as an Auschwitz survivor, used her wartime experience as a tool for teaching the lessons of history to young people. With my mother’s generation dying out, The Obligation represents the fulfillment of a promise to use my skills as a writer and performing artist to connect the theater and its capacity to touch people with the historical necessity of keeping the lessons of The Holocaust alive. 

The Obligation includes the complete text and characters from the short play, The Mitzvah, that I co-authored with Annie McGreevey. The original production of The Mitzvah was directed by Ms. McGreevey.

I created an original lecture that I paired with The Mitzvah  (the combination became The Mitzvah Project) which I've been touring since 2014 . To date, The Mitzvah Project has been seen by over 8,000 people at over 70 venues internationally — including Stanford and Oxford University, the University of Pennsylvania, University of Leeds, Hebrew University, the Illinois Holocaust Museum and Education Center in Skokie, etc. 

 

Your contribution will help us raise our basic goal of $15,000 making possible The Obligation's world premiere, October 12, 2017, at the Potrero Stage in San Francisco. It will cover several mission-critical expenses including: theater and rehearsal facility rental as well as salaries for the director and a key designer. 

Here's a pie chart that breaks down the project's expenses by percentage.

… and there are all kinds of rewards and perks you will get for your support — from your name listed in the program, to free tickets to an exclusive dinner with Nancy Carlin and me! Your generosity will make all the difference.

∞ Our conservative audience estimate is at least 750 people over the course of the play's initial run of sixteen performances at the Potrero Stage;

∞ We hope to engage audiences -- through the play and post-perfomance talk backs -- on questions of identity and the dangers facing society when we acquiesce in the face of prejudice and hatred.

∞ We will make every effort to bring out critics and generate interest for a possible future tour of The Obligation.

Philip C. Sneed, Arvada Center for the Arts and Humanities, Colorado

Dan Friedman, Ph.D., Castillo Theatre, New York

Cindy D. Rosenthal, Ph.D., Hofstra University, New York

 

Omar Ali, Ph.D., University of North Carolina at Greensboro

 

 

Campaign: Basic and Stretch Goals

story:
Skipping Stones Theatre: Who We Are

We are a group of young and emerging Canadian Theatre artists. We all started off in a small pond, and now are swimming out to explore, train, learn, seek and hone our craft in different ponds (ie. around the world). After completing a BFA in acting at the University of Windsor, both Breanna Maloney (General Manager) and Sean O'Brien (Artistic Director) moved to England to pursue MFA's in acting and directing. Kate McArthur (Managing Producer) is also a Windsor grad. After completing her BFA in acting in 2013, she has been working as an actor and yoga instructor in the Toronto and Burlington area. The cast of 4.48 Psychosis consists of Dylan Mawson, Kate McArthur and Breanna Maloney. The show will be directed by Sean O'Brien and Stage Managed by Jocelyn Levadoux. 

Skipping Stones Theatre is making its theatre debut this Summer at the 2016 Hamilton Fringe festival. We will be taking on one of Sarah Kane's most complex and remarkable pieces of work: 4.48 Psychosis. As a result of severe depression, Kane took her own life at the age of 28. This play honours her brilliance, honesty and humility surrounding depression and mental health. We want to share it with the city of Hamilton but in order to do this, we need YOUR help. Any donation is greatly appreciated.  

Where the Money Goes

Here is where your donations will go: 

  • $625: Goes to our venue cost.
  • $250: Goes to our costume, set and props 
  • $200: Goes to our marketing (posters and flyers)
  • $700: Goes to script licensing for 4.48 Psychosis
  • $100: Goes towards general management (transport, disposable materials, etc.)

The Impact

By supporting this campaign and the production we will be performing at Hamilton Fringe, you are helping to support the following: 

  • Young emerging theatre artists
  • Mental health awareness, specifically depression 
  • Feminism and feminist theatre
  • Independent theatre near you

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Support us on Facebook. Follow us at https://www.facebook.com/events/276085796068439/
  • Follow us on Instagram @skippingstonestheatre
  • share this page with EVERYONE!
Thank you so much in advance for all of your help and support! 
Love,
Skipping Stones Theatre
(Breanna Maloney, Sean O'Brien, Kate MacArthur, Dylan Mawson, Jocelyn Levadoux)

story:
Since August 2005, Manhattan Repertory Theatre has been a creative hub for thousands of playwrights, directors, actors, choreographers, dancers and more in New York City. Since we opened 11 years ago, we have produced, in our 46 seat theatre on 42nd St, over 1000 full-length plays and close to 2000 short works and dance pieces. A-Listers like Meryl Streep, Edward Albee, Tracy Ullman, Ally Sheedy, John Patrick Shanley, and Mamie Gumer have attended. Recently, we had the opportunity to present the reunited cast of THE GUIDING LIGHT in BREATHING UNDER DIRT by veteran Guiding Light actor Michael O’Leary. 

But beyond the name-dropping, and most importantly, we have been the creative home for the LIVE ARTIST developing their work and presenting it on stage here in New York City with little or no cost to the participant.

Last November, we found out that we had to leave our home of 10 years on 42nd St for they were selling the building, so we went on the hunt for a new space. We contacted commercial brokers and walked the streets of Manhattan searching for space on a quest to save our creative home. We soon discovered very few buildings would even consider our use case. No one wanted to house a small independent theatre because of foot traffic, noise and more, and, not to mention, commercial real estate prices in New York City had more than doubled in over 10 years, with a myriad of added costs.

But we continued our search because we could not let Manhattan Rep die. We put offers in on spaces and were rejected, dealt with shady brokers and building owners, and learned that a handshake agreement means nothing in the commercial real estate world in New York City. In January, we were told that we could stay in our building, only to be told in April that we had to leave again. 

So we searched and searched and were rejected again and again.  (For a detailed account of our Manhattan theatre space hunting check out manhattanrep.com.) In our quest for a space, we worked with over 30 different brokers, saw scores of spaces, but no one wanted a small independent theatre. No one. Finally through sheer crazy determination, by literally walking the streets of Manhattan for days on end, we found a great space on West 45th St, personally brokered the deal, and we were accepted, and we moved in September 5 with a month to build out our new theatre.

So this is where we need your help.

We have a big empty space, and we need additional funds to build a GREAT theatre in time for our October opening.

 

 When designing our new space, we decided that we would fix some of the problems that we experienced with our space on 42nd St:

 

THE STAGE

First off, our new stage will be bigger, offering larger productions an opportunity to shine at Manhattan Rep. And we have designed a new set of theatre risers that will slide accommodating 27 to 50 + audience members. The performing area of the stage will be 50% bigger and with the sliding risers, it can be almost doubled. The stage will still be intimate, but not cramped, with gorgeous brand new hardwood floors and an even higher ceiling than on 42nd St.

 

THE DRESSING ROOM

The Dressing Room will NOT be next to the stage so it will be easier for actors to prepare before going on and there won’t be any sound issues with actors making noise backstage. The dressing room is in a separate room with a door, adjacent to the theatre office and concession area. The dressing room will be equipped with ample counter space and make up mirrors, ample shelf storage for props, a costume rack for costumes, a gorgeous ceiling fan, and personal individual outlets for one’s cell phone. 

 

NO MORE POLICE SIRENS

The theatre is in the back of a building on 45th St, NOT on the avenue as we are on 42nd St so police sirens, fire trucks and street sounds will NOT be a problem as they are on 42nd St and 8th Ave. We hope to purchase new quieter air conditioner units to make the summer experience in the new space even quieter and cooler.

 

A NICER NEIGHBORHOOD

And the neighborhood on West 45th St. is cleaner, and safer. Recently, 42nd and 8th Ave has become incredibly dirty with garbage strewn all over at night and many “questionable” characters hanging out. West 45th St has many restaurants and hotels, a beautiful outdoor park with a fountain and, of course, a Starbucks. Nearest parking is less than 1 block away on 46th St. It is such a beautiful upgrade.

And we are still only a block and a half from Times Square.

 

HELP US CREATE AN AMAZING THEATRE FOR NEW WORK IN NEW YORK CITY!

We want to open this space with an even better theatre. A place one can feel proud to work in and attend. A place playwrights, directors, actors, choreographers, dancers, and poets can continue to call HOME. A place that playwrights, directors, actors and live artists in New York City need to develop and hone their work.

And in order to do that, we need your help.

 

WHAT WE NEED FUNDING FOR:

We need to hire an electrician to wire and hook up the lighting.

We need to hire a carpenter to build our sliding theatre risers, our office and concession area.

We need to purchase lots of wood, a ton of sheetrock, an office door, lighting fixtures, cans and cans of paint along with paint brushes, rollers and more, mirrors, lots of shelving, brand new fireproof curtains, curtain track, new chairs, new speakers and sound system, exit signs, new doorknobs and locks, a refrigerator, 2 new air conditioners and so much more.

And all of this costs a lot of money. 

 

PLEASE HELP US DO THIS RIGHT!

Help us build our new theatre so we can help even more live artists develop and grow their work in a safe, supportive and AWESOME environment here in NYC. 

In life, when you are about to lose something, you often realize it’s importance even more. When we almost lost Manhattan Rep, we again realized how important it is to have an on-going theatre for NEW WORK in Midtown Manhattan.  It all begins with trying out new work. That is how playwrights develop their plays and how actors and directors practice their craft! Help us make Manhattan Rep the best theatre for NEW WORK in New York City. Help us to continue to celebrate the new artist, in a city that is killing small independent theatres.

 

SOME OF OUR UPCOMING PLANS FOR OUR NEW THEATRE

We will continue to offer opportunities for playwrights, directors and actors to share and explore their craft in a safe, supportive environment here in Midtown Manhattan with New Play Events, Short Play Competitions, Full-Length Play development and more.

We will offer low-priced playwriting, acting and directing classes that will lead to production. Private Playwriting Mentoring, Monologue Coaching, Yoga for actors, and more.

We are going to be developing an on-going playwriting program for Young Adults.

DAD AND THE DOG, New York City’s first one man, one dog show will return, which celebrates the amazing transformation power of a dog's love.

Our Premiere Play Series will present some of the best full-length plays by area playwrights.

And we plan on developing a working resident company to present some crazy awesome theatre on-going in the heart of New York City including THE MATCH GAME, THE PEOPLE IN MY HIPS and MEN, along with some surprises, which just might include Shakespeare's The Tempest as a tribute to the late, great Jack Kirby.

And that is just the beginning.

 

HELP SUPPORT THE THEATRE THAT HAS SUPPORTED SO MANY ARTISTS OVER THE LAST 11 YEARS!

Please help us out with whatever you can contribute so we can continue to do what we do even better!  

Ken Wolf, Artistic Director and Co-Founder

Jennifer Pierro, CFO, CEO and Co-Founder

Manhattan Repertory Theatre

PS. Really cool contribution Perks are listed to the right.

Help us make the new Manhattan Rep the absolute best theatre for new work in New York City!

Help us make Manhattan Rep the best theatre for NEW WORK in New York City. Help us to continue to celebrate the new artist, in a city that is killing small independent theatres. SOME OF OUR UPCOMING PLANS FOR OUR NEW THEATREWe will continue to offer opportunities for playwrights, directors and actors to share and explore their craft in a safe, supportive environment here in Midtown Manhattan with New Play Events, Short Play Competitions, Full-Length Play development and more.We will offer low-priced playwriting, acting and directing classes that will lead to production. Private Playwriting Mentoring, Monologue Coaching, Yoga for actors, and more.We are going to be developing an on-going playwriting program for Young Adults.DAD AND THE DOG, New York City’s first one man, one dog show will return, which celebrates the amazing transformation power of a dog's love.Our Premiere Play Series will present some of the best full-length plays by area playwrights.And we plan on developing a working resident company to present some crazy awesome theatre on-going in the heart of New York City including THE MATCH GAME, THE PEOPLE IN MY HIPS and MEN, along with some surprises, which just might include Shakespeare's The Tempest as a tribute to the late, great Jack Kirby.And that is just the beginning. HELP SUPPORT THE THEATRE THAT HAS SUPPORTED SO MANY ARTISTS OVER THE LAST 11 YEARS!Please help us out with whatever you can contribute so we can continue to do what we do even better!  Ken Wolf, Artistic Director and Co-FounderJennifer Pierro, CFO, CEO and Co-FounderManhattan Repertory TheatrePS. Really cool contribution Perks are listed to the right.Help us make the new Manhattan Rep the absolute best theatre for new work in New York City!

story:
Summary

In 2008, Aaron McGloin Dance was created with a mission to make honest and ambitious dance that brings people together. In our 8 years as a company we have been able to share our work with artists and patrons across the country through performances, classes, and community engagement. We are thrilled to have had these opportunities and are eager to continue our journey.

Over the past few years we have started to gain momentum, not only performing and teaching in the NYC dance community but being given opportunities to tour our work to new venues across the country - including Phoenix, Philadelphia and Baltimore in early 2017 alone. ALL of our projects over the past year were made possible by the success of our 2016 fundraising campaign and, as a result, AMD has been able to make more ambitious strides towards our goals of creating a more sustainable organization. This year we hope to expand our touring schedule to include new communities outside of NYC as well as breaking ground on some exciting new work to add to our repertory.

What We Need & What You Get

This is where WE NEED YOU! In the past we've been able to operate on a tight budget, finding creative solutions to our financial shortcomings. NOW we are looking to expand the reach of our work, adding the cost of travel and accommodation to our already tight creative budget without sacrificing quality. The estimated budget for our 2017 projects is $8,500 with the majority of that split between touring costs, rehearsal space, and dancer pay. The remainder will go towards costumes, promotional materials, photo/video documentation, and to pay Aaron for his contributions in and out of the studio (the guy literally does all the graphic, web, and lighting design, and sews costumes in his apt). As much as we dream of affording all this out-of-pocket we simply aren't there (yet) and look to you, our friends, fans, and patrons of the arts, to help us realize our ambitious dreams!

In return for donating, not only can you cash in on some sweet rewards and build some good karma but you get some SERIOUS bragging rights without having to feel guilty about any of it.

The Impact

We hope that you'll consider making a donation to support not only our creative process, but our continued growth as an organization. All funding will go directly to subsidize the high cost of rehearsal space, costumes, marketing materials, and (most importantly) to pay the dancers for their time and creative contributions in and out of the studio. As a result of our successful 2015 & 2016 campaigns we have been able to hire more dancers, spend more time in the studio and spread the word about the work we are all so passionate about. We couldn't have done it without people like you who chose to be a part of the art and supported our ongoing efforts.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't donate or want to contribute beyond a monetary gift, help us spread the word about our campaign and the projects we're doing with your network of arts supporters. Consider sharing this page and any of our work with your social media networks and connect with us on Facebook, Instagram, Twitter, Vimeo, and at www.aaronmcgloindance.com.

story:
THE STAFF ROOM PLAY

@STAFFROOMplay

Why fund us?!

  • My name is Michelle Payne and I'm a 26 year old playwright from Essex. So hello, that's me!
  • The Staff Room is the second play I've written, and we were lucky enough to receive a FIVE STAR review from London Theatre 1 last summer. From this, we decided we should try to take our show to Edinburgh Fringe. I cast three fantastic actors -  hard working individuals! 
  • My cast currently includes (subject to change due to various ((AMAZING)) opportunities -- I wouldn't be losing them for nothing): Craig Webb, Faye Derham, Hilary Murnane.
  • We have already secured a professional performance of the show at the Queens Theatre, Hornchurch. All money from this will go towards the Edinburgh budget.
  • Our ultimate goal is to be spotted at the Fringe by Channel4 and be overnight sitcom sensations!! - But if not, we would love to get another credit to our CV, raise our profiles, network a little and get some more great reviews in order to constantly pitch it towards the bigger theatres and eventually TV companies.

What We Need & What You Get

Our financial break down:

  • VENUE: Theatre 3, The Space @ Surgeon's Hall = £675+VAT (I've paid the £162 deposit).
  • FRINGE APPLICATION FEE: £295.
  • ACCOMMODATION: £1500 (booked and deposit paid).
  • TRAVEL: approx £500 

TOTAL: £2970 (eek)

  • We are having gorgeous badges, tote bags, t-shirts and hoodies printed for our fringe run! So if you'd like to get in on that, they will be available as prizes.

The Impact

Feel free to explain more about your campaign and let people know the difference their contribution will make:

  • We, in this industry, talk a lot about working class actors/writer/directors finding it more difficult, (especially female writers, and especially female writers writing comedy!) So here I am writing good plays, taking fellow creatives to share our work at the Edinburgh Fringe.
  • My first play 'ORCHID' has completed a run at the Camden Fringe and Black Fox Festival, winning Moors Theatre awards 'Best New Writing' and 'Best Actress: Michelle Payne'.
  • I have had scripts chosen for a lot of the Actor Awareness (campaign for working class actors) scratch nights, and they have helped me raise both my profile and my standard of writing. It is thanks to this that I was offered my show at Theatre N16 and other opportunities so far! @ActorAwareness for more info.

Other Ways You Can Help

  • You can buy a ticket for our fundraising show at Phoenix Artist Club on Sunday 19th March, 2.30pm. (Tickets: £10) The afternoon will feature all of my short plays & monologues so far!
  • You can also purchase raffle tickets for this event.

Thank you for reading! And I hope you can help us reach our goals!!
