story:
Summary

Written by playwright, screenwriter and actor John Pollono, "Small Engine Repair" swept every major Los Angeles theatre award and had an extended off-Broadway run at MCC Theater. Clearly we better do this production justice! So, we need your help to do so.  

Former high school buddies Frank, Swaino and Packie—now past their prime—meet off-hours one night in Frank's out-of-the-way repair shop under cloudy circumstances that only Frank seems to have a handle on. Enter Chad, a plugged-in, preppy college jock, whose arrival ignites a long-simmering resentment that sets this whip-smart and brutally funny play on it's breathless course.

  • Starring Nick Reinhardt as Frank, Brandon Irons as Packie, Johnny Rivas as Swaino and Declan Michael Laird as Chad.
  • Produced by ShoWorks Entertainment and directed by Jo Galloway.

"...the play becomes a devastating commentary on the dangers of the internet, the position of women in society, and the madness of single parenting, to name just a few of the subjects Pollono is trying to deal with. It would be unfair to say anymore, because, when the surprises come, they come rushing at you from so many different directions that it proves unsettling at first and strangely satisfying at last."
                                                                                                                                       -stageandcinema.com review

What We Need & What You Get

To expand the footlights further, we are going to need you to help "mask the comedy and tragedy" of putting on an independent production.

We've set our goal at $10,000, but of course every donation matters! You don't have to start at a perk level. $1 can make a huge dent in our campaign, and we appreciate all donations that help us bring this show to life. This money is going to be used in many spectacular ways.

If we manage to reach our goal, the entire cast has sworn an oath of lifelong commitment to receive "Small Engine Repair" tattoos. That's commitment people!

The Funds Fundraised in this Fun Fundraiser, will Further Finance this Fabulous Feat in the Following Forms:

·       Rehearsal Space Rental

·       Theater Rental

·       Rights For The Play

·       Insurance

·       Costumes

·       Lighting & Sound Design

·       Set Design Building and Production by acclaimed Set Designer Alessandra Manias

·       Front of House & Box Office

·       Publicity and Marketing

·       Graphic Design 

·       Printing- Programs, Posters & Postcards

We have some fabulous perks that this crazy lot have created, including posing in all their manliness for a 2019 calendar, complete with tool belts and grease....

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Advertisement -  Have a business you'd like to promote? Limited space is available in our Playbills that will be distributed to all audience members throughout the run of the show and featured on our website. For pricing and information, please contact: info@showorksentertainment.com  These contributions will help offset the cost of design and printing.

Social Media - Help us spread the word by sharing this campaign and following us @smallenginerepairLA on Facebook @showorksentertainment on Instagram and #smallenginerepairLA. Also you can follow the team @johnnypatisaul @declanmlaird @brandonirons5150 @jogalloway3 @showorksentertainment

 

Our Cast

Johnny Rivas

Johnny was born in Oxnard California and moved to Portland Oregon at the age of 10.  He began doing school theatre and choir at the age of 11, and moved to Los Angeles at 21.  He booked his first lead in the feature film named “Tied Up” currently on Netflix and Amazon, and has been seen in many national commercials, films and TV shows.  Johnny has won the “Best Actor Award” for The A3F film festival and has been seen in the CBS series Marvels "Agents of S.H.I.E.L.D." as well GO-90’s “Algorythm” to name a few.  He continues to study at The Howard Fine Acting School as well as with Alan Langdon at Circle In The Square. Johnny has just finished writing, directing, producing, and leading in “King Thief” which has just been submitted to many major film festivals nationally and internationally.  Johnny is also a professional snuggler.  

 

Brandon Irons

Brandon would like to thank his family for supporting his various pyramid schemes throughout the years. As well as, putting up with his execrable behavior throughout the course of holiday functions   Specifically, he would like to thank his Mom for her love and also for driving him hours across California for auditions when he was a young chap. Some of his film credits include "The Girl Next Door" for 20th Century Fox and "American Pie 4" for Universal, amongst others. Some of his favorite roles on a stage include Austin/Lee (True West) and Bobby (Coyote On a Fence). Brandon enjoys time traveling, competitive knife fighting, Jay walking, climbing trees and stealing candy from chubby babies. His current favorite quotes include: "See that system here? That is HI-FI...high fidelity. What that means is that is the highest quality fidelity"and "Sharp little guy...He's one of the worst students we got.'' In addition, Brandon is an ordained minister who will shoot from the hip and speak from the heart, providing that cash is involved.

 

Nick Reinhardt

Nick Reinhardt is very excited to a take a crack at a New England Accent in "Small Engine Repair." Nick is know for his appearances on several obscure Webseries. He holds a BFA from NYU: Tisch School of the Arts at the Stella Adler Studio.

 

Declan Laird

'Declan moved from Scotland to Los Angeles leaving his role in BBC show "River City" after being offered a full scholarship to the prestigious Stella Adler Academy of Acting. Upon graduating, Declan has worked frequently across TV/Film, his most recent work being in feature films "Hot Air", "Green Fever" as well as the upcoming TV series "Big Dogs", all of these projects are to be released by the beginning of next year." 

 

About Us

The Production Company 

ShoWorks Entertainment offers a "one-stop bespoke production shop"  assisting in producing individual theatre and film projects in Los Angeles, bringing them from “page to stage.” "Small Engine Repair" marks the award nominated company's 5th theatre production in Los Angeles since 2016. ShoWorks is also a proud sponsor of the "Don't Wait. Create! Award" at the annual Hollywood Fringe Festival for original and innovative production.

About the Director 

Jo Galloway made the move out to the States from Cape Town in 2012. She  is qualified in Speech and Drama, Musical Theatre and she holds her International Tap & Modern Dance Teacher qualifications through the Waterfront Theatre School in Cape Town and the I.S.T.D London.  Jo has co-written and directed numerous original theatre productions, one of which was performed at the prestigious Athol Fugard Theatre in Cape Town.  In addition, she writes & produces original scripts for film & stage, as well as teaching acting, drama and dance to young actors. With their series of recent short films, ShoWorks strives to create solid creative content for young actors, while allowing them a safe and professional environment to hone their skills as up-and-coming talent. As a performer, Jo has performed lead roles in professional international theatre productions such as “Cats,” “The Full Monty," "The Buddy Holly Story,” "Hairspray,” "Happily Ever Laughter," "Look Back In Anger," "Some Girls," "Boeing-Boeing," "Perfect Wedding, " “All For Art,”and the Award nominated production “Infantryman In the Wardrobe,”which she also wrote and directed. Jo was nominated twice for her stage performances-the role of Demeter in "Cats,"followed by Amber in "Hairspray." 

 

FEBRUARY 2019

TICKETS SALES OPEN DECEMBER 1ST 2018 AVAILABLE THROUGH BROWN PAPER TICKETS

story:
What is this?

 

Erin is a struggling writer who works in a bar. She has big hopes and dreams, but finds herself mostly concerned with making ends meet. Then one night she can't sleep. And she can't sleep the next night. It seems like she will never sleep again...

 

Giacomo is a violin maker living in 19th century Venice who is deeply in love with his wife, but lives in fear of his own mediocrity. He also may or may not be cursed...

 

Insomnia is a time-traveling, psychedelic exploration into what happens when a strange, life-shattering illness interrupts an ordinary life. It is about the struggle to live and love and make things, and about what we inherit - whether we like it or not.

 

Why donate?

We're so excited about making this play a reality, but we need your help to do so! We're looking to pay our creative team and actors, secure rehearsal space, and have basic props and costumes. 

 

What you get:

Check out our rewards!

story:
ALL DONATIONS TO THIS CAMPAIGN ARE TAX DEDUCTIBLE!

Point of Origin is an exciting new work by Rat King Theatre. 

Point of Origin, Rat King Theatre’s first full-length production, explores how identities are formed by personal, familial, and cultural stories. Incorporating song, dance and food, Point of Origin follows the journeys of a mythical Finnish witch, a Greek con man, and two women in New York who form a friendship as they grapple with the legacies of their ancestors. It is an immersive theatre experience with dancing, cooking and feasting by cast and audience.

Like any great dinner party Point of Origin is an ambitious project. We need your support for the success of this project and to provide traction for Rat King to continue to produce innovative work. By contributing to this campaign you are supporting: burgeoning and exciting experimental theater; an all women production team; and wonderfully messy stories. With your generous support we have full faith that we'll produce something delicious!

Funds from this campaign go towards: 

  • Paying our artists- we have an incredibly talented cast and production team and we prioritize compensating artists and technicians for their work. 
  • Rehearsal space
  • Lights, sound, set (including an onstage oven and fridge), costumes - all the magic that goes into theater!
  • FOOD!

What else can you do?

  • Come to the show! (tickets available here)
  • Get the word out! Indiegogo has fancy sharing tools, please use them and share this campaign with thousands of your closest friends.
  • Visit our website and like us on Facebook.

story_txt:
ALL DONATIONS TO THIS CAMPAIGN ARE TAX DEDUCTIBLE!Point of Origin is an exciting new work by Rat King Theatre. 
Point of Origin, Rat King Theatre’s first full-length
production, explores how identities are formed by personal, familial, and cultural
stories. Incorporating song, dance and food, Point of Origin follows
the journeys of a mythical Finnish witch, a Greek con man, and two women in New
York who form a friendship as they grapple with the legacies of their
ancestors. It is an immersive theatre experience with dancing, cooking and
feasting by cast and audience.
Like any great
dinner party Point of Origin is an ambitious project. We
need your support for the success of this project and to provide
traction for Rat King to continue to produce innovative work. By contributing
to this campaign you are supporting: burgeoning and exciting experimental
theater; an all women production team; and wonderfully messy stories. With your generous support we have full faith that we'll produce
something delicious!
Funds from this campaign go towards: 


Paying our artists- we have an incredibly talented cast and
     production team and we prioritize compensating artists and technicians for
     their work. 
Rehearsal space
Lights, sound, set (including an onstage oven and fridge), costumes
     - all the magic that goes into theater!
FOOD!

What else can you do?

Come to the show! (tickets available here)
Get the word out! Indiegogo has fancy sharing tools, please use
     them and share this campaign with thousands of your closest friends.
Visit our website and like us on Facebook.

Linda Vega

Tessa Allen and Krystalla Pearce - Writers
Guan Li - Producer
Caroline Craig - Consultant/Dramaturg

story:
Legends In The Making Dance League (LITM)

            My name is Paul “Koncept” Guintu, I am 24 years old and have been dancing for 11 years now. I grew up learning about dance in Sacramento with an “I just want to get better” mentality. As I kept on practicing, I would generate ideas of ways to improve and expedite growth. The main concepts I kept coming across was community, mentorship, free expression through movement and battling.

Those ideas are the main reasons why LITM is important to me. Community, mentorship, free expression through movement and battling are all why I’ve grown to become the person I am. I am always hungry to grow, aim to push any dancer I come across and support all upcoming and seasoned dancers. Free expression through movement and battling is the main form of communication to all dancers. It creates a conversation with one another and opens a direct path for exchange of craft.

All of this will build the dance community in Sacramento, CA. I believe by bringing all of those aspects to LITM, It will help facilitate the process of growth within the community.

Your contribution will help create, build and facilitate this idea to help grow dancers to their fullest potential, surround the youth with positivity through dance, and bring people together.

ABOUT THE EVENTS & Dance Workshops

32 dancers have been drafted into a battle league, throughout a season they will have matched up battles and their stats recorded. The top 16 at the end of the season will go to the championship and battle tournament style.

During each event I will bring out a special guest dancer to teach a workshop and judge the battles. An open dance tournament will also be available to the dancers who were not drafted into the dance league and still have the chance to compete.

What you get!

I will need about 5,000 to help start this up. I highly believe in paying artists for their craft. The contributions will go towards bringing the best dancers in from all over the country to teach and spread knowledge in Sacramento. It will also help fund to keep a place to facilitate these events and workshops as well as equipment we need to document the events.

By contributing you can obtain a season pass as well as free LITM merchandise for the season, even obtain an ALL ACCESS PASS to attend all events AND workshops with free LITM Merchandise for the season!!!


Other ways you can help!

If you are not able to contribute money today, that is ok!

Please spread the word and help build this dance community! That is a great contribution.

Thank you!

-Paul “Koncept” Guintu

story:
HELP MAKE LEMONADE THAT MUCH SWEETER!

After more than 20 years experience in New York City's downtown art scene, now is the opportune moment for me to focus on my stories will the goal of creating a daring and  moving piece of theatre on my own terms! I am  the recipient of  the prestigious Fox Foundation Resident Actor Fellowship in the category of "Extraordinary Potential" for acting. In April I will present my first solo show at La MaMa ETC. However, I still need extra financial  support to make "Lemonade" a reality and bring my story about "that girl on the other side" in the film industry.

Lemonade is not only a Valentine for New York City but also  a tribute to the legacy of my mother, Nancy. As she always said, "Heather Lynn, Honey… When Life Hands you Lemons you just got to make Lemonade." HERE'S THE STORY!

Lemonade  will take you on a journey weaving through my experiences of  young adulthood in the Lower East Side of NYC.  I worked in the sexualized underground performance scene of the 90's at legendary nightclubs such as The Pyramid and Jackie 60 and even The Limelight, dancing  in a cage above the dance floor. It's all set against the backdrop of my mother, Nancy and her gentile  southern values we talked almost daily. Moving to my own challenges as an actress in the film industry. After taking a part in my first big major motion picture "Requiem for a Dream"opposite Jennifer Connelly in one of the most terrifying sex scenes in film to date and how it affected me as and actress and as a woman feeling marginalized and type cast. During the writing of Lemonade  my mother unexpectedly passed away she was my Steel Magnolia  and the string of pearls that held everything together.  So bringing Lemonade to the stage in its best form has more poignancy than ever. Now that our conversations have come to a halt , I realize that maybe mother did know best and  we were more alike than I ever realized. I will also  recount several other film roles with tongue in cheek dialogue and a few behind the scene secrets.  I want to take my power back and honor my mother at the same time.I truly hope you will help me.

A movie still of Heather in "Requiem for a Dream"


After years of interpretive roles it is time for me to take that wild horse by the reigns and be a generative artist and express true self and to defy and play with stereotypes always trust upon me.

How far does one go to get that acting role? In your own life how far will a southern woman go to get what she needs? Is this the way world perceives me ?Are these characters part of me?

THE TIME IS NOW!!!
I approached Mia Yoo the Artist Director of La MaMa about applying for the Fox Fellowship  with Theatre Communication Group. Mia said, YES Let's do it ! All it takes is one Yes. So together as a team we submitted our application and we won. As part of my  Fox Fellowship one of my primary goals  is to make a solo show in April of  2016. So  here it is LEMONADE! The piece started out as a poem but has grown into a full scale theatre show and will complete my requirements with TCG and the Fox Grant. This piece is my finale' to two years of hard work growing and cultivating as an actress, writer and creator . Looking back on my first experiences and what continues to come from  them this piece and this moment for my career and my personal development  is an immense opportunity  to express myself as  an empowered woman artist.

Who is La MaMa?
An integral part of New York City’s cultural landscape, La MaMa has a worldwide reputation for producing daring work in theatre, dance, performance art, and music that defies form and transcends boundaries of language, race, and culture. Founded in 1961 by theatre pioneer and legend Ellen Stewart, La MaMa is a global organization with creative partners and dedicated audiences around the world. La MaMa presents an average of 60-70 productions annually, most of which are world premieres. To date, over 3,500 productions have been presented at La MaMa with artists from more than 70 nations.

The Lemonade Team!
As  I get into the thick of production I  need extra help financially.  Please help  me by making a contribution to getting Lemonade up and running with the best team I can possibly assemble. I am still re-writing  and fine tuning the script and  "Lemonade" opens at La MaMa on April 15th.  So I am walking a production  tightrope. Lemonade will cost upwards to $12,000 to make  according to  my vision and magic of storytelling on the stage  the most professional piece of Theatre I can create and be proud of with the Lemonade Team. I need the resources  to pay for a  director, lighting designer, video designer and stage manger,PR person,to help get people in the seats, costumes  and   other costs of  producing a professional piece of theatre in New York City. And that Producer is ME!

Elena Heyman (Director) Elena Heyman is a New York theatre Director and Co-Artistic Director of The Orbiting Human Circus with Julian Koster (Neutral Milk Hotel). She recently directed Longyarn (Banana, Bag & Bodice) and the solo shows of Erin Markey and Becca Blackwell. ellieheyman.com

Lucy Sexton (Dramaturge) Lucy works in dance theater and film. With Anne Lobst she is the co-director of the performance group DANCENOISE; she diredted Spaulding Grey;Stories Left  to Tell and The Magical Ridiculous Journey of Alien Comic; she produced Charles Atlas's Legend of Leigh Bowery and his film with Antony TURNING.

Mike Albo (Script Editor) Mike is  a writer and performer. His solo show The Junket appeared off- broadway at The Lynn Redgrave Theatre in 2014. His upcoming show Spermhood,will be at Dixon Place in May.

I need extra financial help to help pay for the costs of  these talented people who are also in very high demand as artists for their time, energy , professionalism and delicious creative brains.

Heather presenting an earlier reading of Lemonade at La MaMa in Nickyland
Any contribution will help. I have included perks for tickets to the show and other fantastic opportunities to get to know me and the show.  If you can't contribute financially no problem  you could help  me manifest and get the word out by sharing with your friends, colleagues, family, lovers or  sharing on social media. You and your energy are such a viable contribution.

I want to thank you again for your support and friendship on helping me bring "Lemonade" to the La MaMa stage.

You can also  purchase tickets here and Please sign up for my newsletter and visit my new website: heatherlitteer.com

Heather Litteer and La MaMa ETC are participants in the Fox Foundation Resident Actor Fellowships, funded by the William & Eva Foundation and administered by The Theatre Communications Group.

story:
Here's a bit about us: collectvely, we are Pandaemonium Shadow Shows, a new production company with some Old Theater Hands. Fearless Leader is your humble, Charles D. Prokopp. I've been performing since my first radio voicework sometime in the Mid-1950s. Proud possessor of a degree in Theater Arts from Illinois Wesleyan University. I'm especially noted for playing peculiar people.
     Most of those peculiar people were under the direction of John Gunn, with whom I've worked frequently since 1995. John has gotten my very best performances out of me, and I thought of him as soon as I saw the opportunity to do "KARLOFF". We are a team. John is noted for the extraordinary quality and sophistication of his direction. Together, we have an amazing track record of daring productions!
     And the important thing: for me, this is a labor of love. I have revered Mr. Karloff since I was a boy, longer ago than I care to contemplate. He was responsible for inspiring me to become an actor. This is my chance to pay him back.


     We will need $6000 to bring this to fruition. So far, I have been financing the whole project. I'd like to use these contributions to take some of the strain off my retirement savings. Seems like a good idea.
Our main expense is renting the APCOT Theater space. I've already made an $1100 deposit on it, with the same amount due when we move in. We'll also need to pay our stage manager and Patrick Reed for his makeup skills. A digital projector will need to be rented for the background images that punctuate the play. The set is very simple, almost non-existent: a chair, a stool, a table and an odd tree. Mostly, these will come from the theater's store room. I've already provided the costumes. Printing tickets and the programs will be included in this.

     This show will be something truly exciting for the Tucson theater community and our audiences. It's not the sort of play that appears frequently here, and will appeal not only to younger people, but to the area's older citizens who'd like an entertaining reminder of one of cinema's most beloved stars.
     Your contributions over $50 will also guarantee you get tickets, as laid out in our contribution page. If you want those, do make sure we have your names!

     There are challenges, to be sure. The script is essentially a long monologue. I've been beavering my way through it for a few months and have nearly finished the line work. Like Boris, when confronted with a difficult task, I simply get on with it!
     If we fail to meet our full funding goal, my intention is to continue as I have been doing: raid my savings and carry on. This play is too important to me to do otherwise!
     Now I realize not everyone can contribute money, but everyone can help by talking this up on Facebook, using the tools on Indiegogo or just mentioning it among your friends. Every little bit helps.

story:
Short Summary

My name is David Herrera and I am the artistic director of David Herrera Performance Company in San Francisco.  Since 2007 DHPCo. has been at the forefront of emerging dance theater companies shaping the SF/Bay Area artistic landscape.  We are celebrating our 9th season with the premiere of "The Least of Them" on May 12-14, 2016 at Z Space theater in San Francisco.  

"The Least of Them" explores and investigates how peoples' misunderstandings, stereotypes, biases, compartmentalization, and fears of another person's skin color and race can lead to the downfall of relationships, communities, and cultural threads.  At a moment when the nation is facing so many cases of skin color conflicts and uprisings DHPCo. feels that this work is both timely and necessary.  

The 60minute production utilizes the talents of 7 dancers, 7 designers, and myself as choreographer/artistic director.  For 5 months these artists have been working hard and efficiently to bring to life a concept larger than any one of us.  The work has challenged and pushed us into very creative territory and it will bluntly ask our audience to think more critically about their own roles within these circumstances.  

To make a dance theater production takes hundreds of hours of manpower and a matching budget: rehearsing, building sets, composing an original musical score, technical and electrical work, constructing costumes; in short, physical and intellectual labor that comes at a cost. This is where you, our supporters, followers, donors, friends, family, and fans can help!

What We Need & What You Get

We would like your help in raising $5,000 out of the $9,800 total cost for the theater rental.  The theater is a crucial component in presenting new dance works, it also happens to be the largest expense on our production budget.  By helping us achieve our goal you are also in essence freeing up funds that can be redirected to help pay our artists a competitive living wage.   As government and foundation support has recently decreased on a national level, individual sponsors like you are stepping up to the plate.  YOU have the power to make great art accessible. 

Two ways to donate:

1) Make your direct donation via this online campaign

Or

2) Make a Tax-Deductible donation via our fiscal sponsor Dancers Group.  Go to their webpage, www.dancersgroup.org click on donate and select David Herrera Performance Company as your recipient.  

The Impact 

We are truly excited to bring “ The Least of Them” to life on stage.  Come May 12 we would be honored to have you amongst our audience so that you may witness firsthand how your generous donation was utilized.  You are investing not just in this season but also in the ongoing longevity of the company.

Since 2007 DHPCo has grown in visibility, press support, funding, and presentation, and performances.  We have been able to tour to Seattle, Chicago, Los Angeles, Austin, San Jose, Santa Cruz, and yearly in San Francisco.  We have been featured in many print publications and online.  We have gained commissions by UC Santa Cruz (CA), Marin School of the Arts, William Sonoma (San Francisco office), FWD.US, and Push Dance Company.  DHPCo. has been awarded the Zellerbach Family Foundation Grant, Puffin Foundation Grant, Salesforce community grant, & artistic residencies at Mission Cultural Center for Latino Arts and Studio 210. 

Last year's production of "TOUCH" was a sold-out hit at the very same venue we are presenting in this season. 

The growth of DHPCo in all these areas tells us that we are creating work that resonates with a diverse audience, in particular with people who had never had a prior relationship to modern dance. Your donation helps further the impact we are able to have on our communities, both locally and nationally, as we continue to create, perform, and tour. 

Other Ways You Can Help

We understand that times can be financially difficult for everyone but please know that even the smallest contribution makes a big difference. 

If you are unable to help financially, you can still help us out by distributing this campaign to your friends and family, by posting it on facebook, or by volunteering during performances.  We appreciate any form of aid you can give!

2) Make a Tax-Deductible donation via our fiscal sponsor Dancers Group.  Go to their webpage, www.dancersgroup.org click on donate and select David Herrera Performance Company as your recipient.  

The Impact 
 We are truly excited to bring “ The Least of Them” to life on stage.  Come May 12 we would be honored to have you amongst our audience so that you may witness firsthand how your generous donation was utilized.  You are investing not just in this season but also in the ongoing longevity of the company.
Since 2007 DHPCo has grown in visibility, press support, funding, and presentation, and performances.  We have been able to tour to Seattle, Chicago, Los Angeles, Austin, San Jose, Santa Cruz, and yearly in San Francisco.  We have been featured in many print publications and online.  We have gained commissions by UC Santa Cruz (CA), Marin School of the Arts, William Sonoma (San Francisco office), FWD.US, and Push Dance Company.  DHPCo. has been awarded the Zellerbach Family Foundation Grant, Puffin Foundation Grant, Salesforce community grant, & artistic residencies at Mission Cultural Center for Latino Arts and Studio 210. 
Last year's production of "TOUCH" was a sold-out hit at the very same venue we are presenting in this season. 
The growth of DHPCo in all these areas tells us that we are creating work that resonates with a diverse audience, in particular with people who had never had a prior relationship to modern dance. Your donation helps further the impact we are able to have on our communities, both locally and nationally, as we continue to create, perform, and tour. 
 Other Ways You Can Help
 
We understand that times can be financially difficult for everyone but please know that even the smallest contribution makes a big difference. 
If you are unable to help financially, you can still help us out by distributing this campaign to your friends and family, by posting it on facebook, or by volunteering during performances.  We appreciate any form of aid you can give!

story:
I am Bianca Trulli. I'm 22 years old, born and raised in Ancaster, Ontario. I am in Toronto majoring in Choreography and Performance in The School of the Arts, Performance, Media and Design Undergrad at York University.

 I am the founder and artistic director of a new dance company called Echo Dance Company. March 23-24th, 2016 Echo is presenting their first annual performance "Breaking Formality" at the Winchester Street Theatre.  Echo Dance Company wants to give emerging artists an opportunity to perform in a professional setting. In order to do so we need your support. Your contributions will help pay for the venue and allow the dancers to perform in a professional setting. This is vital to a dancers career as its one of the first opportunities they have to be seen in Toronto’s dance community. 

Echo’s goal is to raise $4,000 in order to pay for the venue, production fees, costuming, technical crew, photography, videography, promotional costs such as posters, postcards, and programs.

Echo is unique because it offers and incorporates a variety of movement styles. It allows artists to discover their movement signature and be original in their creative process. If we don’t reach our goal, the funding for the show will be coming out of the pockets of working students. Any contribution is greatly appreciated. If you can't donate towards Echo, your support and word of mouth is also greatly appreciated.

story:
It's been eight years since we produced our first run of The Garden rock opera. A lot of amazing people came together to make it happen--crew, cast, technicians, musicians, managers, designers, and directors extraordinaire. You know who you are. You know what you did. We are forever grateful. 

But, as is this case with all shows, first runs are just the beginning! Since then, Sandy has rewritten and replaced songs, shaving almost an hour off the show and sharpening its dramatic arc. 

Now, we need to incorporate those changes into our 32-song score. James has a window of time this summer, in which he could finish the score (and if you know James, you know how unusual that is), but he needs some funding in order to support his lovely family while he works, and he needs to purchase the full updated Finale software package:

Phase I
$2400  Support James' work on the score
$600     Purchase Finale software

If we raise enough money to finish the score, we would love to then begin the process of bringing The Garden to a wider audience, which involves marketing the show to potential producers and preparing materials they will need to produce the show. 

Phase II
$4250  Development of branding & marketing materials
$1250   Printing of marketing materials
$250     CD production for marketing materials
$250     Mailing costs

For those of you not familiar with our epic musical rendition of the biblical meta-narrative, you can read about it and listen to some of our music at  TheGardenRockOpera.com. 

Thanks for considering our campaign! And if you know any company, church, group, or school that would like to produce The Garden in the fall, please let us know. We appreciate your support and helping us get the word out!

Sandy Kruse and James Carrano

story:
Who We Are

Rant & Rave is an emerging theatre company and is comprised of current and former UEA students.

Our singular desire is to get the nation talking about sex, gender and sexuality by breaking down the barrier of British bashfulness.

Our founding members are: Oliver McFadden, Creative Director; and Lauren Kelly, Production Director.

Our first project is Sexual Fears of a Modern Day Virgin. We will be going up to the Edinburgh Fringe Festival in August 2016. The show will run from the 5th to the 20th of August, running from 15:00-15:50, at Olive Studio on Infirmary Street which is run by the marvellous Greenside Venues.

Crew:

Director - Oliver McFadden

Production Manager - Lauren Kelly

Assistant Director - Anissa Praquin

Assistant Production Manager - Lorianne Ho

Dramaturg - James McDermott

Cast:

Lewis Wilding

Mercy Phillips

Louis Raghunathan

Zoe Mitchell

Carys Jones

Why We Need Your Help

There are lots of challenges between here and Edinburgh and we need your help to overcome them. This show is not only a creative risk but also a financial risk. Any support you can give would be invaluable to us.

We are working as hard as we can and no one in the company makes any money from this project. For some of us Rant & Rave could quite literally become our lives and, hopefully, our livelihoods. Any help you can give us takes us one step closer to being able to dedicate ourselves to something we are really passionate about.

Every penny you can give us helps to ensure this show is a success but also ensures that Rant & Rave Theatre Company can continue to produce future shows to support local performers and open up rarely-had discussions in the Norwich and Norfolk area.

Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you can't give any money please share this crowd funding link, share our Facebook page, or tweet us! Any and all help to spread our word via social media is invaluable to us. Also, please come along and support our events at UEA!

story:
The Cause...

On April 7th, 2016 at Theater Row, we will be presenting the culmination of our actor training to industry professionals of various backgrounds to gain experience, exposure & a platform that will take our talents to greater heights!


Info:
The Beckett Theater @ Theater Row ( 410 W. 42 street, NYC)
For more information, please contact the Program Head.

Undergraduate Acting Program
Rose Burnett Bonczek
theater@brooklyn.cuny.edu
718-951-5000 Ext. 2768


Who We Are...

We are a bunch of magnetic misfits with hopes of contributing to the world through our artistry! Thrill-seekers who want a shot at making a difference through theater/film/TV. We're human beings on a mission to reach other human beings through entertainment, one stage/screen at a time! 

Why We Need YOU!

You are a key factor in making sure this all goes off without a hitch! 

Here is what your money will be going towards:

  • Catering expenses 
  • Rental Insurance 
  • Space rental
  • Travel expenses
  • Printing & Mailing expenses (Brochures, Invitations, Program, add'l headshots, etc.)

Performance Photos!

Javon in Much Ado About Nothing by William Shakespeare

Amy in Quake by Melanie Marnich

Miklos in Belleville by Amy Herzog

Mildred in Picnic by William Inge

Drew in Bengal Tiger at the Baghdad Zoo by Rajiv Joseph

Alexandra & Shomari in Baltimore Waltz by Paula Vogel

Annabelle in Camino Real by Tennessee Williams

story:
Short Summary

Don't Talk About It, SP!T About It, is a Spoken Word play in the form of an Epic Poem about the circumstances and struggles of 8 heroic denizens that inhabit the city of Los Angeles. Combining meter, prose, and free verse, the play explores the metropolitan train rail and bus stops that contain stories about Love, Loss, Compromise, and ultimately, how people face and live with the decisions that shape their lives. This work focuses on educating, inspiring and unifying our inner city communities.

What We Need & What You Get

The Cast and Crew of Don't Talk About It, SP!T About It is looking to raise $10,000 to cover the cost of production and technical needs for our 2016 run at Casa 0101.

We are looking to collaborate with you, our community, to bring our voices to the stage. 

The Impact

Don't Talk About It, SP!T About It is a mix of classic theatre and contemporary poetry and spoken word to speak for our people, to educate our communities and to uplift those around us.

We are working to fuse art, music, movement and the urban theatre movement to bring to you the story of our LA city street. 

Risks & Challenges

The topics that SP!T works to tackle such as the Black Lives Matter Movement, Homelessness and Poverty, Domestic Violence, Social Welfare and Justice; topics that are not commonly presented on the stage. We need your help to bring this work to life. We cannot do it alone. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Donate Today and Spread The Word. Tell your friends, families and loved ones. Follow us on Facebook and come enjoy the show!

story:
HELLO

We are Manic Chord, a theatre company based in Leeds. Founded in 2012 by Alex Monk, David Cartwright and Sam Berrill, the company creates energetic work born out of an initial curiosity.

That curiosity grows through research and development bringing together a host of performers, designers, artists and specialists whom mould that initial interest into a performance for an equally curious audience. 

This Autumn sees us returns to the West Yorkshire Playhouse to premiere our fourth show - THE ECONOMY OF ECOLOGY - an insightful piece exploring the importance of TOUCH. To date the project has been self-funded with the help and support from Cast, The Civic, Slung Low and the West Yorkshire Playhouse. 

So far we have developed the show with of a lot of kindness, good will and in-kind support from some generous venues, artists and organisations. However, in order to further develop this beautiful show we need to pay some brilliant artists, buy some essential technical equipment and ensure the work itself is clear and accessible.

To start us off, we have received a seed commission from the brilliant people at the West Yorkshire Playhouse who will be helping us along the way.

Now we need your help to continue the journey.

 

THE ECONOMY OF ECOLOGY 

Touch shapes the mind, nurtures the body and nourishes the soul. Skin on skin. A busy bus, a momentary void and a tree falls. One man explores grief and the human experiences which connect us to each other and the world.

This is a show about people, community and connection. It explores one of our most significant assets, our sense of touch. From even before we are born, touch has the ability to shape our world and the people living in it. Using a variety of projector and cameras, a lot of leaves and the idea that mushrooms can save the world, five performers share one man's story of pilgrimage. In the hope that we all might re-engage with our most personal of sense... touch. 

 

WHAT WE NEED & WHAT YOU GET

We need to raise a further £2000 to further develop the show over a three week period at the West Yorkshire Playhouse before premiering it at the Furnace festival in October. The show will then go to Edinburgh in 2017 before heading out on the road for our largest national tour to date in October and November 2017.

Here are a few things we need to pay for to make this show spectacular - Wages for 4 fabulous performers, technical equipment such as microphones, speakers and a projector and a visually spectacular set featuring over 10,000 Autumn leaves and barrage of plant specimens. 

There will be a variety of tasty little treats we are offering including tickets to see the show, a limited edition screen print poster and a multitude of recognition across the project.

 

HELP US MAKE THIS HAPPEN

Manic Chord produces work with the hope of striking a conversation, starting with the audience and ricocheting out to the wider public. It is important for us that our work has something to say and we want you to join us in that conversation. Therefore, alongside the show in October we will be curating an evening of discussions, provocations and performance about the topic of TOUCH - unpicking its effects and deliberating calls that we’ve become a touch deprived culture. This will be live streamed for all of those unable to attend the event.

Yes, we are asking for your well earned, cold hard cash, however, if you are not able to support us financially there are still plenty of ways to help make this show happen. You could share this campaign on social media, tell as many friends or strangers about the project and quite simply shout loudly from the tops of as many tall building as you can find, about this wonderful show. Whatever you can do, we appreciate.

So, finally. Thank you for taking the time to browse this page. We appreciate your support enormously.

Sam, Al & Dave x

story:
Opening Day: August 2, 2016, and beyond...

Hey, y'all!  We are Heidi & Jeff McKerley, and S. Renee Clark, a multiple award-winning, Atlanta-based musical theatre team with 84+ cumulative years of theatrical experience in directing, choreography, music direction, performing, and theatre education. 

Our new musical, The Fine Art of Forgetting, is one of only four musicals selected for presentation at the first Atlanta Musical Theatre Festival, August 2016. We want to produce the highest quality theatre possible within this short time frame.

With your generosity, we will be able to perform our entertaining story of love and loss using the best Atlanta artists, technicians, musicians, and designers.  Moreover, you will be contributing to the documentation and recording for marketing future productions.  Most importantly, you will be an integral part of a team responsible for cultivating Atlanta as the newest place to foster the development of artists and new works!  That, my friend, is exciting for all of us!!!

Want to know more?  ExploreThe Fine Art of Forgetting website here.

 

What We Need & What You Get

With your help, we can raise $15,000 quickly.  This capital will be used to:

  • Employ the best Atlanta actors, designers, musicians and technicians
  • Rent adequate rehearsal space
  • Purchase and/or rent props, costumes, furniture
  • Purchase building materials
  • Employ manual labor to build set pieces
  • Produce a professional recording of the songs
  • Produce a professional video of the performance
  • Produce and maintain a working manuscript for archival and marketing purposes
  • Defer administrative costs (scripts, scores, marketing, media, personnel)

In return for your awesome support, we have several perks which will fit any budget. Take a look at the complete list.  Here are a few favorites:

  • A personal "sing out" ("shout out") on all of our social media platforms
  • A downloadable preview recording of a song from the show
  • A chance to name an un-named character in the show
  • Get a sneak peek by personal invitation to a rehearsal
  • A Sunday Brunch with the creative team and available cast members (after the festival, of course)

Every donation helps, no matter the amount.  You can make a difference.  And, since this is a flexible campaign, we get to keep any amount raised (less admin costs) even if we don't reach our entire goal.  First and foremost, the acquired funds will go toward compensating our extraordinary actors, designers, and technicians. You know, all those creative individuals who will breathe life into the words and notes on the page!

 

But, wait...there's more!

Our musical centers around Karen and her mother, who is suffering from Alzheimer's disease.  Our desire is that this show will reach and connect with others who may be going through similar circumstances.  If The Fine Art of Forgetting becomes a success, it is our hope that we can contribute a portion of the profits to help fight Alzheimer's, as well as other debilitating diseases.

Eventually, we will raise the funds to create a non-profit company and acquire additional subsidy through arts-centered organizations.

 

Join us...

As with any artistic endeavor, our musical is subject to critique, opinion, and rejection.  We don't care!  We have a story to tell.  Our story is worth telling.  We will tell this story to inspire conversation, reflection, and acceptance.  Take the risk with us!   

The Suzi Bass Awards is Atlanta's very own yearly ceremony for awards in theatrical excellence.  Over the past 12 seasons, we have 22 nominations and 5 wins.  As you can tell, we strive for excellence!  We take risks!  Join us...be a part of our team!  Be a part of our vision for excellence!

 

 

Please spread the word!  We can't do it without you!

We're artists.  We understand budgets.  Even if you can't contribute, that doesn't mean you can't help!  Here's how:

  • Use the Indiegogo "share" tools at the top of the page and share our message with your friends and family
  • Visit and like our Facebook page here.
  • Share and retweet our journey on Twitter (@fineartmusical) here.
  • Stay connected with pics & videos on Instagram (thefineartofforgetting) here.

Thank you so much for visiting our Indiegogo campaign!  Above all, thank you for your interest in supporting the arts!  You rock!

Sincerely,

Jeff, Heidi, & Renee

Our musical centers around Karen and her mother, who is suffering from Alzheimer's disease.  Our desire is that this show will reach and connect with others who may be going through similar circumstances.  If The Fine Art of Forgetting becomes a success, it is our hope that we can contribute a portion of the profits to help fight Alzheimer's, as well as other debilitating diseases.
Eventually, we will raise the funds to create a non-profit company and acquire additional subsidy through arts-centered organizations.
 

Join us...
As with any artistic endeavor, our musical is subject to critique, opinion, and rejection.  We don't care!  We have a story to tell.  Our story is worth telling.  We will tell this story to inspire conversation, reflection, and acceptance.  Take the risk with us!   
The Suzi Bass Awards is Atlanta's very own yearly ceremony for awards in theatrical excellence.  Over the past 12 seasons, we have 22 nominations and 5 wins.  As you can tell, we strive for excellence!  We take risks!  Join us...be a part of our team!  Be a part of our vision for excellence!
 
 

Please spread the word!  We can't do it without you!
We're artists.  We understand budgets.  Even if you can't contribute, that doesn't mean you can't help!  Here's how:

Use the Indiegogo "share" tools at the top of the page and share our message with your friends and family
Visit and like our Facebook page here.
Share and retweet our journey on Twitter (@fineartmusical) here.
Stay connected with pics & videos on Instagram (thefineartofforgetting) here.

Thank you so much for visiting our Indiegogo campaign!  Above all, thank you for your interest in supporting the arts!  You rock!
Sincerely,
Jeff, Heidi, & Renee

story:
We got picked!

Recently LNRChoreography, was picked to present the duet "Clinging Shadows" at the Detroit Dance City Festival. How exciting!!

This will be the first festival that we are performing in and we are so grateful for the opportunity to present this work and make an impact on the audiences that view it. It's self-empowering message is an important one that anyone can relate to and our hope is that we can help people work past their own shadows.

By contributing to this campaign, you'll be helping us complete that mission as well as keeping a teacher, a recent college graduate, and a college student out of debt.

Break it down now!

So here's the breakdown of how exactly you'd be helping us.

Flight for 3: $842.88

Airbnb for 4 nights: $260

Festival Fee: $105

Uber rides: $100

Paying the dancers: anything extra!


We LOVE and APPRECIATE our donors so much that we have some perks for you. Helllllloooooo free stuff! But seriously, these are simple tokens of our gratitude because we really can't express enough how grateful we would be for your help. 


Impacting others is our goal.

From our choreographer, Lauren Reynolds:
Clinging Shadows is in essence a therapy session. I created this piece as, what I hoped would be, a way for a dear friend to finally be able to let go of the self-consciousness that had haunted him in various stages ever since I knew him. I began by asking him a simple question, "Tell me your name". After laying out his journey and what I hoped to be his ending I asked him yet another question. "Tell me who you are".

By presenting this piece at the festival, we hope to expose its message of hope and triumph over one's demons to all those who view it. 


Introductions

Lauren Reynolds: Choreographer

Lauren Reynolds is a freelance dancer and choreographer based in Tampa, Florida. She graduated from the University of South Florida with a BA in Dance Studies. She is currently working as the resident dance instructor at the non-profit, charter school Pepin Academy. As a choreographer, she has worked to create various group pieces and solos that seek to both comfort and disturb in hopes that they will help others move forward. In 2015, she adopted the name, LNRChoreography, to represent her work. To see samples of her work, click here. 

Robert Kelley: Dancer

Robert Kelley has received his Bachelor of Fine Arts in Dance with a concentration in Modern Dance from the University of South Florida. He has had the opportunity to work with and perform the works of many renowned national and international artists including, Derrick Minter, Robert Moses, Alonzo King, Doug Gillespie, Ohad Naharin, among others. Robert has presented his own choreography at various venues, works including “Continuum” in July 2013 and “People: The reason why?” in July 2014, as well as presenting “Made In Chaos” that premiered in April 2014. Also collaborative works with Florida-based artist, Katrina Soricelli where they premiered “Fragmented Memories” in November 2013 and “Let's Call It” again with Ms. Soricelli and Wisconsin-based artist Emily Hansel in November 2014. Both premiered at the Dance for Food concert that is part of the non-profit organization, Artists for a Cause.



Beaudau Banks: Dancer

Beaudau Banks is a freelance dancer and choreographer based in Tampa, Florida. He is originally from Belize, Central America and lives between New York City and Tampa. He is currently a BFA candidate attending the University of South Florida. As a dancer he has worked with choreographers including Brice Mousset, Julia Ehrstrand, Lauren Reynolds, Christian Denice, John Parks, Bliss Kohlmyer and Darcy Naganuma. He has presented work in Naganuma Dance Summer Intensive and Student Dance Concert while at USF. 


Other Ways You Can Help

We understand that not everyone can contribute monitarily, but that doesn't mean they can't help:

You can get the word out and make some noise about our campaign! Share on Facebook, Instagram, and Twitter! The more we get the word out the more we're likely to reach our goal.

story:
Qui sommes-nous?

Les Malchaussées, c'est une compagnie de danse gumboot (OBNL), basée à Québec et qui a été créé en 2014. Nous nous spécialisons dans la représentation de la danse gumboot, tout en la transformant à notre  image.

Les Malchaussées, c'est 4 membres fondatrices, et depuis 2015, nous avons agrandi la famille à 12 interprètes!  Nous avons fait plusieurs prestations dans différents festivals et évènements. De plus, nous avons réalisé notre premier spectacle en salle, Courants, qui a été présenté au Vieux Bureau de Poste à Lévis. Nous travaillons également à un nouveau concept avec la famille élargie!

Notre jeune compagnie travaille actuellement sur un premier spectacle jeune public intitulé Une botte à la mer! Nous sommes récipiendaires de la bourse du programme Première Ovation, volet danse pour la création de ce spectacle.

De plus, une membre fondatrice, Karine Chiasson a reçu une bourse du Conseil des Arts et des Lettres du Québec (CALQ), au volet recherche et création. Nous bénéficions également d’un fond en formation et mentorat afin de profiter de l’expertise de Madame Sylvie Mercier, figure emblématique de la danse gumboot au Québec. Ces subventions nous soutiennent dans la réalisation de notre première étape de création d’Une botte à la mer!

La première étape de création étant terminée, nous avons déjà utilisé les sous donnés afin d'acheter du matériel (tissus, bois, accessoires), en plus de payer les locaux de répétitions, les impressions pour les cartons d'invitations. Nous souhaitons maintenant amener le projet de spectacle à un autre niveau, soit celle de la diffusion du spectacle en salle et ainsi payer tous nos artisans décemment. C'est pourquoi nous faisons aujourd'hui une campagne Indiegogo!

Nous auront également une résidence de création  au Théâtre jeunesse Les Gros Becs, le plus grand diffuseur de spectacle jeune public dans l’Est du Québec, entre le 20 et le 24 septembre prochain.

Une botte à la mer! est un hommage aux différentes femmes pirates qui ont sillonné les mers durant l’âge d’or de la piraterie. Les 3 plus grandes pirates de tous les temps partent en quête de la botte la plus recherchée dans les légendes, la Botte dorée! Cependant, elles ne sont pas seules à bord...

À SUIVRE...

Création pour nous et surprises pour vous!

 La campagne servira en totalité à payer les créateurs de ce projet d'envergure! Des heures seront consacrées (et l'ont déjà été!) afin de construire, coudre, coller et tout mettre en place, en plus des répétitions afin de créer des chorégraphies! L'ensemble du montant de la campagne servira à payer les artistes et artisans de la relève des arts de la scène de la région de la Capitale-Nationale, afin de stimuler la création dans cette belle région!

Voici l'équipe de création pour le spectacle Une botte à la mer!

Idée originale: Karine Chiasson, Anne-Marie Dumontier, Alexandra G. Brisson et Annie Veillette

Mise en scène: Guillaume Pepin

Interprètes: Karine Chiasson, Paul Fruteau de Laclos, Valérie Pitre et Annie Veillette

Décors et costumes: Sonia Pagé

Conception sonore: Mathieu Turcotte

Vidéo et éclairages: Keven Dubois


    CONTREPARTIES! 

    Nous avons pensé à vous et avons trouvé des façons originales de vous permettre de mieux nous connaître ou encore de découvrir la magie de la danse gumboot! Il y aura des macarons, cartes postales et t-shirts pour nous encourager, mais on sait que vivre une expérience est encore mieux pour comprendre et aimer le gumboot!

    Vous pouvez obtenir un atelier de danse gumboot pour vous et 5 de vos ami(e)s afin de découvrir dans l'action les bases de cette danse africaine!

    Avec la contrepartie de LA MUTINERIE, vous pouvez même surprendre une personne pour une occasion spéciale où nous lui ferons une courte prestation!  Oui!!! On se déplace!

    On peut même venir faire une prestation dans le confort de votre maison ou de votre travail (il faut quand même avertir les voisins de notre venue et vérifier que les fondations sont solides, car on déplace bien des choses et pas seulement de l'énergie!).

    Vous pouvez même devenir le FAN #1 et vous pourrez nous suivre pendant 1 an et on prendra soin de donner des nouvelles de toutes nos activités et même d'avoir ta place à tous nos spectacles!

    N'hésitez pas à communiquez avec nous pour toutes questions ou encore à partager cette  campagne de financement! Vous pouvez également nous suivre sur Facebook, Instagram et sur notre site Internet: www.malchaussees.com .

    À bientôt!

Nous avons pensé à vous et avons trouvé des façons originales de vous permettre de mieux nous connaître ou encore de découvrir la magie de la danse gumboot! Avec la contrepartie de LA MUTINERIE, vous pouvez même surprendre une personne pour une occasion spéciale où nous lui ferons une courte prestation!  Oui!!! On se déplace! 
On peut même venir faire une prestation dans le confort de votre maison ou de votre travail (il faut quand même avertir les voisins de notre venue et vérifier que les fondations sont solides, car on déplace bien des choses et pas seulement de l'énergie!).
Vous pouvez même devenir le FAN #1 et vous pourrez nous suivre pendant 1 an et on prendra soin de donner des nouvelles de toutes nos activités et même d'avoir ta place à tous nos spectacles!
N'hésitez pas à communiquez avec nous pour toutes questions ou encore à partager cette  campagne de financement! Vous pouvez également nous suivre sur Facebook, Instagram et sur notre site Internet: www.malchaussees.com .

story:
Who We  Are...

S. Charli Productions is a combination theater and performing arts group based in Philadelphia.  We have produced quality theater in Philadelphia for the past 5 years including our most recent acclaimed production "Princess Nylah and the Journey to the Magic Window" which premiered at The Venice Island Performing Arts Center to a sold out audience.

Princess Nylah and the Journey to the Magic Window is a children’s production written and produced by Susan C. Small. This musical fairy tale centers around Nylah, a self-proclaimed Princess who embarks on an epic journey beyond the "Magic Window" where she discovers the importance of courage and friendship. With rousing musical numbers like "Find Your Magic" and "Together", this production focuses on important themes such as faith and the importance of discovering ones "magic". 

The reviews of the show were stellar from child and adult audience members alike. It is our goal to bring the incredible message of this production to children and families everywhere. This production and emerging brand encourages children to be brave when facing life obstacles and challenges them to discover and hold on to their childhood magic!

With your contributions, we will be able to produce a Spring 2017 run of this amazing show. Children from all over will get the opportunity to experience a live theater performance produced with them in mind! In addition, we will also be able to expand the Princess Nylah brand to include:  a Princess Nylah Rag Doll and the Princess Nylah and the Joureny to the Magic Window Children's Story Book.

We Need Your Help

Your contributions will help us keep the ticket prices low while guaranteeing a quality production. We will be able to:

  • Rent a state-of-the art venue that will meet all lighting and technical needs of the production.
  • Compensate cast and crew.
  • Cover promotional costs (marketing materials)
  • Create custom costumes and set pieces that will bring the story and characters to life.
  • Purchase materials needed for production of the Princess Nylah rag doll.
  • Animate and publish "Princess Nylah and the Journey to the Magic Window" story book.

The Impact

Since the beginning of this project we have been able to put smiles on dozens of little faces! With your help and contributions we will be able to share the magic of this brand and production to  more children and families.

Risks & Challenges

One of the most difficult aspects of projects such as this is rallying the resources to meet the vision in excellence. It is our most sincere desire to provide our audience and patrons with an unforgettable experience from the time they walk in the door to the time leave the theater. We are confident that with the proper resources, we will be able to share the magic and message of this production and brand to children and families everywhere.

Other Ways You Can Help

IF YOU CAN'T DONATE TODAY, THERE ARE STILL PLENTY OF WAYS YOU CAN HELP!

Can't contribute monetarily? That's okay! Please consider doing the following:

Contact us (s.charliproductions@gmail.com) & let us know if you want to donate equipment, talent, labor or time. Contributions in kind and in all forms are valued!

Visit our website: http://www.scharliproductions.com

Like us on Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/s.charliproductions

Spread the word! Share our Indiegogo page on Facebook, Twitter & Instagram. Talk about the project.  Every little effort helps.

And last but not least, come out and see us Spring 2017! We are so excited to share this production and products with you.

With Sincerest Thanks,

- Susan & Kayla

story:
NC Dance Collective is a team of unparalleled modern dance leaders who have been emerging organically as a talented company. The Harvest Moon Dance show directors are Hilary Jordan and Sarah Molaro, both who hold extensive backgrounds in dance, performance and show creation. The larger collective consists of many long time dance teachers, choreographers and strong, experienced dancers who are excited to develop an intimate and memorable event, as well as a lasting impression in synergy and cohesive creative relating.

Our talents demand that we show ourselves to the community, that we let ourselves be seen as the artists that we are, and that we deliver our hearts to the community through our passion to dance.... Healing through art begins and continues as we embrace our abilities and create new pathways for relating, for supporting historical venues where art can safely unravel, and for delivering our best selves in a proud and honorable offering.

Our needs for this first show are very simple:

$1100 will cover the costs of:

 lights

 sound

costumes

 flowers

 marketing

 video

 venue care

dancer stipends

Thank you for your generosity and support as we take these first steps. With the bigger vision of evoking inspiration in our audiences, aligning with our truest expressions of dance and company, and allowing our community to realize movement as both visual art and powerful therapy, your help will ripple out to immeasurable pools of love, peace, and prosperity, right here in Nevada County. Thank you for supporting your local movement artists.

Blessings and Reverence-

NC Dance Collective

story:
The Project Summary

From £1 to £1000, your support helps...

Using Latin and Hip Hop dance theatre and culture, Ladylike, explores what it is to be ‘ladylike’ and and challenges our notions of gender, sexuality and identity.

Ladylike is very close to my heart.  I had been thinking about the complexities of male sexuality, the patriarchy and what it's like to feel silenced in a "man's world". At different stages of my life I have felt restricted by how communities or society teaches me to behave. I decided to explore these 'should' and 'should nots' through art.

Ladylike invites the audience to explore a range of themes in juxtaposition, including masculine & feminine, fight & flight, consent & rape, oppression & liberation. 

Cultural dances/ customs explored include the dances of Orisha deities & the Rumba dance of flirtation Guaguanco- dances from Cuba, which can be traced back to West & Central Africa in origins, as a result of the slave trade. There is also reference to Hip Hop, the Apache line of Uprocking from NYC, breaking and the overtly sexualised Reggaeton.

Simple props, music (composed by Sabio Janiak), language and light projections have been well considered to accentuate meaning, as well as beautiful costumes designed by Jodie-Simone Howe.

What We Want:

We are asking people to donate as much or as little as you can towards making this project happen, or just to spread the word to those you think might like to donate to a female empowering Afro-Latin- Hip Hop dance theatre piece!

We want receive enough funds to put the work onto the stage, pay the dancers to rehearse and perform, light the piece professionally and have someone to film it so we can promote the work and give it the exposure it deserves. 

It is important to all of us that this work is finished, & this unique language of Afro-Latin & Hip Hop Dance Theatre and feminine perspective is seen.

At the moment I have self funded paying the dancers for two weeks (though the have done at least three weeks of work), paying to hire lights, for accommodation, travel, a fee to finish the music, to have the work filmed and various other costs. I have not been able to pay myself for any of the work I have put in myself. 

We are raising crowd funds to pay for some of these:

Rehearsals (3 weeks at £450 per artist (4 artists): 2 weeks in London 10-14th October & 24-28th October, One week in Leeds, York & Newcastle including a sharing at York University (17-21st October)

To have the work filmed and edited  (£300).

To light the work professionally and hire lights (£650)

To hire an expert train us in working with young people to deliver sex education workshops on Consent, Gender & Pleasure, in particular looking at sexual violence (£500). 

Paying a rehearsal director (£200).

Employing a Stage manager (£150)

 

About the Artists:

My name is Ella: With a background in Latin Dance since 2000, I took up Breaking because I wanted to express myself in a way where it wasn't all about my smile or how many sequins I had on, and I decided to train as a contemporary dancer for two years in London, graduating with a postgraduate diploma from The London School of Contemporary Dance in 2011. I also have a politics and sociology degree from Leeds University. I love to create, and am passionate about seeing real high-level Latin and Hip Hop Dance in the Theatre in the UK. 

As the choreographer and director of Latin Hip Hop Dance Theatre Company Ella Mesma Company (2011), my work has been described as ‘stunning,’ ‘provocative’ and ‘unabashedly emotional’ (The Guardian).

I established Latin dance company Element Arts, in Leeds in 2005 and then began producing Roots of Rumba (an annual Latin Dance Theatre Festival which gives Latin dance artists a platform for their work) in London in 2013. My Latin accolades include Passista (First soloist) in Rio de Janeiro carnival 2006, Rainha Da Bateria for London School of Samba 2008, The Channel 4 Comedy Gala 2016 and a fellowship in Cuba & Brazil in 2015 (Winston Churchill Memorial Trust). I also teach and have been commissioned to create work and run workshops across the UK and internationally.

In 2013, I was selected as a future Dance Leader for the ABLE leadership program, and in 2015, awarded a Bench fellowship for emerging choreographers. I am currently Associate Dance Artist at Dance City in Newcastle. As a performer, I have worked internationally including tours with Russell Maliphant Company, Southpaw Company, & performing for the Olympics Opening Ceremony, Wendy Houston’s ‘Stupid Women’, Warsan Shire (as featured in Beyonce’s ‘Lemonade’)'s ‘The Ugly Daughter’ and Adidas  

Anna is Anglo-Argentine, and studied dance and athletics from a young age. She studied dance at Facultade Angel Vianna in Rio de Janeiro and worked with Gustavo Cirico, Frederico Paredes, and Deborah Colker. Anna worked with Vertigo Dance Company in Israel in 2015. Anna is a Tango Dancer and assists for the Leandro Palou Tango Academy. She has taught workshops for Come Dancing and Strictly Come Dancing.

Lianett was born in La Habana, Cuba, and trained at the National School of Art in Cuba (ENA), graduating in 2005 with a gold title. In 2006 she joined the National Company of Contemporary Dance in Cuba and has toured Internationally with them, as well as Havanna Rakatan, Balletronic and Carmen la Cubana.

Azara has been practicing various styles of HipHop including breaking for the last 10 years. She is also a live artist and actress. Performance experience includes Indigo2, Wembley Stadium, and The Olympics opening Ceremony. Azara was runner in The Winter Pride Art Awards 2016 with her debut solo piece ‘I Am Woman’.

Hsing Ya, born in Taiwan is an International Contemporary dancer. East and West training practices including Ballet, Modern, Gaga, Tai-Chi, Yoga & Belly dancing make her a diverse artist. She is also a choreographer and teacher. Her performance experience includes in Taiwan includes Feng Dance Theatre, Dance Forum Taipei Company, WC dance company. Since she came to UK in 2016, she has performed for Appetite Dance Productions and recently joined Ella Mesma Company. Hsing Ya has also taken part in a Choreography Residency at Watermill Center, Long Island in New York, The American Dance Festival and The Taipei Artist Village.

Sabio is a Composer, producer, multi-instrumentalist based in London, Sabio has a masters degree in classical percussion (Academy of Music in Poland) and music production and performance (London Centre of Contemporary Music-). Sabio plays more than 150 instruments and his experience of working together with world famous artists, have contributed to enhancing his rare musical sensibility and interest in the science of sound.

Ciaran has worked at Melton Mowbray Theatre and Barry Young's Star Dust as well as gaining a BTEC in Technical Theatre (Brooksby Melton College), BA (hons) in Technical Theatre Studies at East15 acting school resulting in a full time position at Terry Tew Sound and Lighting. Ciran was charged with overseeing the Lighting and Rigging departments for 3 1⁄2 years before freelancing. He has lit work for Ballet Black, The Young Vic, New York Theatre Ballet and Gecko to name a few.

Jodie-Simone has created the costumes for this work, which will be completed ready for the 1st September and will be used from the first days of rehearsals in October. Jodie has been working within the Creative Arts for the past 5 years in Costume and Visual Aesthetics within Dance Theatre. Her experience as a researcher in marketing, television and radio, along with her passion for art and dance have given Jodie a well-rounded background in creative arts. She has worked with the Company since 2012. She has made costumes for Ivan Blackstock, Young Vic and Breakin Convention to name a few.

 

The Impact

Sadler's Wells liked our work so much that we will be premiering it in London at Sadler's Wells, with our very own Wildcard on 8th June 2017.

We want to reach a mixed audience including those not usually interested in dance through this issue based work. My intention is to  attract a mixed audience, including men as there are inferences relating to masculinity (not to just preach to the converted).

With the theme of gender in society and specifically perceptions of women’s role is universal, and following Michelle Obama's wonderful speech in October, and the surprising US election results, I feel this work has arrived at a poignant time. 

To date, people have said:

'Strong & Empowering' Richmix

'Brilliant show and Q&A session' Mandinga

'Timeless and current issues that women continue to face everyday' The Tabernacle 

'Absolutely stunning and provocative piece I saw last night , thank you for the inspiration and celebration of your exploration!!!' Yorkshire Dance

'Completely engaged- enthralling, emotional, inspiring and grounding work' Mercy Nabirye

 

How Can You Can Help?

We are asking people to donate as much or as little as they can towrads making this project happen, or to spread the word to those you think might like to donate to a female empowering Afro-Latin- Hip Hop dance theatre piece!

Below are the links if you would like to help:

Website: www.ellamesma.co.uk

Twitter: @EllaMesma

Facebook: /EllaMesma

Instagram: @EllaMesmaCo

Richmix Event: https://www.richmix.org.uk/events/dance/ladylik...

Facebook Richmix Event: https://www.facebook.com/events/177091069393620/

Crowdfunding Campaign: https://www.indiegogo.com/campaigns/ladylike

Sadler's Wells show: https://t.co/E9ndQK240L

THANK YOU! 

For your passion, for taking the time to read this campaign, for sharing, and for making a difference.

Lots of love, 

Ella, Anna, Azara, Hsing Ya, Lia, Ciaran, Jodie-Simone & Sabio!
story_txt:
The Project Summary
From £1 to £1000, your support helps...
Using Latin and Hip Hop dance theatre and culture, Ladylike, explores what it is to be ‘ladylike’ and and challenges our notions of gender, sexuality and identity.
Ladylike is very close to my heart.  I had been thinking about the complexities of male sexuality, the patriarchy and what it's like to feel silenced in a "man's world". At different stages of my life I have felt restricted by how communities or society teaches me to behave. I decided to explore these 'should' and 'should nots' through art.
Ladylike invites the audience to explore a range of themes in juxtaposition, including masculine & feminine, fight & flight, consent & rape, oppression & liberation. 
Cultural dances/ customs explored include the dances of Orisha deities & the Rumba dance of flirtation Guaguanco- dances from Cuba, which can be traced back to West & Central Africa in origins, as a result of the slave trade. There is also reference to Hip Hop, the Apache line of Uprocking from NYC, breaking and the overtly sexualised Reggaeton.
Simple props, music (composed by Sabio Janiak), language and light projections have been well considered to accentuate meaning, as well as beautiful costumes designed by Jodie-Simone Howe.
What We Want:
We are asking people to donate as much or as little as you can towards making this project happen, or just to spread the word to those you think might like to donate to a female empowering Afro-Latin- Hip Hop dance theatre piece!
We want receive enough funds to put the work onto the stage, pay the dancers to rehearse and perform, light the piece professionally and have someone to film it so we can promote the work and give it the exposure it deserves. 
It is important to all of us that this work is finished, & this unique language of Afro-Latin & Hip Hop Dance Theatre and feminine perspective is seen.

story:
Hello,

I'm Francesca, a writer, performer and theatre maker and this is an unashamed bid to get some pennies and pounds to support taking a new show to Edinburgh Festival. I'm working, as always, with award winning producer Pippa Frith, following on from a successful Edinburgh back in 2011 and a host of successful commissions and national tours in the years in between.

Stories to Tell in the Middle of the Night is something like a live late night radio show that takes you through the night. In an hour. Except the DJ (that's me) is spinning stories instead of records. It's not durational. The stories will follow the pattern of not being able to sleep, a reflection of the night.

It came from not sleeping, the strange stories and thoughts that occupy the night, the mind, while awake. What keeps us awake and what connects us. Or disconnects us. What stories we tell in the dark. Rage, narcissism, technology and solace. It also comes from listening to old raconteurs on the radio, the good old tradition of storytelling. I will be talking directly to the audience, we'll make the most of these moments live, together. 

Here's how the copy goes:

'I'll take you through the night, it's highs, it's lows. Those frustrations. Lets populate the long dark hours and the small light hours with stories. People, until the morning'

A live radio show for those that can't sleep, aren't asleep. Instead of records this DJ is spinning stories. Tales in tangled sheets that are odd, true, funny and familiar.

Stories is different to some of my previous work and I've got a brilliant team to push me on my way. Lekan Lewel, a new collaborator, currently RTYDS Resident Assistant Director at Derby Theatre has come aboard as director. With Iain Armstrong as sound designer and Claire Browne as set designer.

We'd like to take this show to Edinburgh Fringe, one of the best places to showcase new work. It is considered the place to get great audiences, promoters, booking and reviews and press coverage. It is also pretty hard to fund. Which is where you come in.

We've got a place at Summerhall one of the best venues going and we've got some support and funding, as well as reaching in our pockets (and behind the sofa, in the change jar) but we need a bit more to get us there. 

By supporting us in this, we'll get to Edinburgh but also hopefully secure future tour dates taking the show to wider audiences nationally. Times are tough at present but we'd be grateful for anything you would like donate, it all adds up. And if you can't please do share to your networks.

We're hoping that you'll enjoy the possibilities of what you can get for your pounds & pennies.  We had fun drawing up the list of perks and they're aimed at giving you a little piece of the show, or a little piece of you in the show or if you really want, your very own show.

Thank you Fran
