story:
"The Fabulous Fables of Aesop"

Described as a “near perfect formula for child entertainment” and “an inspired piece of theatre”, The Fabulous Fables of Aesop creates a new dimension in children's theatre.  Four actors navigate their way through the magic of Aesop. Through song, dance and humor, this bright and colorful children’s musical educates as it entertains. Answering life’s most pressing questions through allegorical myths portraying animals engaged in human-like situations, they are sure to resonate with both children and adults alike. The fabulous and timeless fables of Aesop represent one of the oldest characteristics of human life: storytelling. ShoWorks Entertainment presents “The Fabulous Fables of Aesops”, where the mouse squeaks, the lion roars and the grasshoppers sing!

“The Fabulous Fables of Aesop”, originally created by the late Keith Galloway, has been presented over the last 30 years in various guises all over South Africa.  Originally performed in 1992, it was presented at the Waterfront Theatre College, during a specially arranged cultural festival for children from disadvantaged backgrounds.  The fables were presented in a mixture of English and isiXhosa. Surprisingly, the show has never been filmed in its entirety, although there have been over 15 versions throughout the years.  As this is my late father’s work, the project is very close to my heart and I am passionate about bringing the project to life again, creating relevance in a new era.  ShoWorks is proud to be honoring the memory of this brilliant actor and father, who dedicated his life to teaching and inspiring students all around the world. We believe there is a market for good, solid Children's Theatre here in LA, and, with your help, we believe we can achieve a magical, professional production we can all be proud of. 


About ShoWorks Entertainment

Welcome to our fresh fun children's entertainment and production company ShoWorks Entertainment! We specialize in all aspects of performing and training for children in the entertainment industry.

At ShoWorks, we believe in nurturing the most important attribute children have - IMAGINATION! 

ShoWorks also focuses on versatility, and, therefore, we are producing our first children's theatre production.  We understand that LA is primarily a TV/Film town, however, it is also a town full of actors, and actors want to act. Not wait to act. That makes you a waiter :-) The more skills you have, the more versatile you are, and the more options you have to do what you love - and that is why we are all here right?

At ShoWorks, we believe in imagination and creation, whilst helping prepare the up-and-coming actors of the future to work with integrity and discipline. As well as remembering that we get to dress up and play for the rest of our lives. How much fun is that!


Why we need your help

With your help, we can bring this beautiful, educational musical to life!

As ShoWorks is funding this entire production, with no assistance from sponsorship or outside investors, we are are reaching out to you to help us mount our show.  As you can imagine, the cost of sets, costumes, props, venue and technical support can quickly add up.  We firmly believe that actors deserved to be compensated for their talent, even if it is a small amount. Since we are hoping to create a professional working environment, we want to offer our talent some form of compensation for their commitment and unique skill set.


What we need

The pre-production and running costs of a musical of this kind are relatively inexpensive by most full-scale musical standards.

With a budget of $5,000, we can bring this show from page to stage!

We understand that not everybody is always in a position to financially contribute to the many causes and campaigns requested support.  You can also help us by sharing our campaign on social media and help raise awareness. Any and all assistance is greatly appreciated!


About the Creator: 

Keith Galloway appeared in, choreographed or directed no less than 17 West End musicals, prior to arriving in South Africa in 1976. UK credits include “ Man of La Mancha”, “ Hallo Dolly”, “The Music Man” and “ How to Succeed in Business”, which he also directed in Denmark. UK television credits include choreography and appearances for BBC, ITV and the USA. In SA, he quickly established himself as South Africa’s top television choreographer, his production of “ Magic Maestro Please” winning the first ever Artes Award.  Keith has written and directed numerous original productions, from youth theatre to plays, musicals and corporate events, as well as choreographing dozens of television commercials.


The Team behind ShoWorks

Jo Galloway - Originally from Cape Town, South Africa, Jo is an internationally qualified dance (modern and tap) and drama teacher through the I.S.T.D of London and the Waterfront Theatre College of Cape Town. She is also a professional actress, singer, dancer (ballet, modern and tap), writer, TV Host and international voice artist, and has performed in numerous musicals and stage productions all over the world. Including productions of "Cats," "Hairspray," "The Full Monty," African Footprint," Some Girls," Look Back in Anger,""Boeing-Boeing," "Perfect Wedding" and " That'll Be The Day - The Buddy Holly Story," to name a few.

Jo was nominated twice for her stage performances - the role of Demeter in "Cats," followed by Amber in "Hairspray."

Jo has also co-written three original productions "Dick & I" - a parody on Richard the III, "Happily Ever Laughter," and "The Fugard Fest of Comedy," which was performed at the prestigious Athol Fugard Theatre in Cape Town.

Before leaving South Africa, Jo moved into television and film, and co-wrote the hit sketch comedy TV show "Sketch U Later." South Africa's answer to SNL. She has most recently been working on the production and acting side of multi-camera children's Disney shows such as "ANTfarm," "Mighty Med," "Bunk'd" and "Gamers Guide," as well as continuing to act professionally in TV and Film here in the USA.

In addition, Jo also hosts her own online TV show "From Hollywood with Jo Galloway" for TMTvSA.

www.jogalloway.com


Darren Portilla -

A born and bred LA native, Darren is one of the creators and directors of ShoWorks Entertainment. Luckily he is still able to play the "18 to look younger" roles, which has allowed him to become very familiar with the world of Disney and Nickelodeon.

Darren is well known on the production teams of many Disney shows. Working on sets such " ANT-farm," "Mighty Med," "Bunk'd," "Bella and The Bulldogs," "Gamers Guide," and "Jessie." As well as an actor and writer, Darren has worked extensively in the Multi-Cam comedy genre, with a recurring role on Nickelodeon's "Supah Ninjas." Darren has also recently booked a role on the new hit CBS show "Code Black." 

In addition to shooting many national television commercials for clients such as "Starbucks," "Union Bank,"Nike," and "Teen Nick." Darren is trained in all aspects of the performing industry including voice over, and is currently writing a half-hour comedy show together with his business partner and co-founder of ShoWorks Entertainment, Jo.

That makes you a waiter :-) The more skills you have, the more versatile you are, and the more options you have to do what you love - and that is why we are all here right?At ShoWorks, we believe in imagination and creation, whilst helping prepare the up-and-coming actors of the future to work with integrity and discipline. As well as remembering that we get to dress up and play for the rest of our lives. How much fun is that!Why we need your helpWith your help, we can bring this beautiful, educational musical to life!
As ShoWorks is funding this entire production, with no assistance from sponsorship or outside investors, we are are reaching out to you to help us mount our show.  As you can imagine, the cost of sets, costumes, props, venue and technical support can quickly add up.  We firmly believe that actors deserved to be compensated for their talent, even if it is a small amount. Since we are hoping to create a professional working environment, we want to offer our talent some form of compensation for their commitment and unique skill set.What we needThe pre-production and running costs of a musical of this kind are relatively inexpensive by most full-scale musical standards.With a budget of $5,000, we can bring this show from page to stage!We understand that not everybody is always in a position to financially contribute to the many causes and campaigns requested support.  You can also help us by sharing our campaign on social media and help raise awareness. Any and all assistance is greatly appreciated!About the Creator: Keith Galloway appeared in, choreographed or directed no less than 17 West End musicals, prior to arriving in South Africa in 1976. UK credits include “ Man of La Mancha”, “ Hallo Dolly”, “The Music Man” and “ How to Succeed in Business”, which he also directed in Denmark. UK television credits include choreography and appearances for BBC, ITV and the USA. In SA, he quickly established himself as South Africa’s top television choreographer, his production of “ Magic Maestro Please” winning the first ever Artes Award.  Keith has written and directed numerous original productions, from youth theatre to plays, musicals and corporate events, as well as choreographing dozens of television commercials.
The Team behind ShoWorksJo Galloway - Originally from Cape Town, South Africa, Jo is an internationally qualified dance (modern and tap) and drama teacher through the I.S.T.D of London and the Waterfront Theatre College of Cape Town. She is also a professional actress, singer, dancer (ballet, modern and tap), writer, TV Host and international voice artist, and has performed in numerous musicals and stage productions all over the world. Including productions of "Cats," "Hairspray," "The Full Monty," African Footprint," Some Girls," Look Back in Anger,""Boeing-Boeing," "Perfect Wedding" and " That'll Be The Day - The Buddy Holly Story," to name a few.Jo was nominated twice for her stage performances - the role of Demeter in "Cats," followed by Amber in "Hairspray."Jo has also co-written three original productions "Dick & I" - a parody on Richard the III, "Happily Ever Laughter," and "The Fugard Fest of Comedy," which was performed at the prestigious Athol Fugard Theatre in Cape Town.Before leaving South Africa, Jo moved into television and film, and co-wrote the hit sketch comedy TV show "Sketch U Later." South Africa's answer to SNL. She has most recently been working on the production and acting side of multi-camera children's Disney shows such as "ANTfarm," "Mighty Med," "Bunk'd" and "Gamers Guide," as well as continuing to act professionally in TV and Film here in the USA.In addition, Jo also hosts her own online TV show "From Hollywood with Jo Galloway" for TMTvSA.www.jogalloway.comDarren Portilla -A born and bred LA native, Darren is one of the creators and directors of ShoWorks Entertainment. Luckily he is still able to play the "18 to look younger" roles, which has allowed him to become very familiar with the world of Disney and Nickelodeon.Darren is well known on the production teams of many Disney shows. Working on sets such " ANT-farm," "Mighty Med," "Bunk'd," "Bella and The Bulldogs," "Gamers Guide," and "Jessie." As well as an actor and writer, Darren has worked extensively in the Multi-Cam comedy genre, with a recurring role on Nickelodeon's "Supah Ninjas." Darren has also recently booked a role on the new hit CBS show "Code Black." In addition to shooting many national television commercials for clients such as "Starbucks," "Union Bank,"Nike," and "Teen Nick." Darren is trained in all aspects of the performing industry including voice over, and is currently writing a half-hour comedy show together with his business partner and co-founder of ShoWorks Entertainment, Jo.

story:
Ever fallen in love?

Spill Your Guts Here is- at its heart- a love story. A story as old as time. Girl meets boy; girl loses boy; girl loses her shit.

But this being 2016 it’s also a story of the internet. According to research our interaction with Facebook when we break up from a romantic relationship increases by an average of 225%. That’s a whole lot of time spent looking at our exes and making out that “we’re just fine thank you”. But are we? In an age where we can spend hours altering filters on our photographs to ensure we look together and moved one, what’s happened to finding the space to be sad and (God forbid it) maybe a bit of a mess? And when we’re constantly surrounded by manicured images and posts of others’ perfect lives what effect does that have on our less socially acceptable emotions?

Becks is pushing 30 and is unable or unwilling to move on from her past, failed relationship. She whiles away her time obsessing on social media, drinking and scheming ways to win him back. But will she succeed? 

—

We need your help to stage Becks’ race to the bottom- and it’s a very messy race- online, offline and on the stage at this year’s Edinburgh Fringe Festival. We’ve been developing the show between us for the best part of 6 months now and the huge opportunities and challenges that a platform like Edinburgh offers us is the perfect space for this show to fully come to life. But it turns out, that doesn’t come so cheap.

So, what is that you want from me?

Ok, so so far we’ve put the majority of the money needed in from our own personal resources. We’re also staging fundraising events and looking to other bodies and funding groups to help us along the way. But we need your help too! Any help given is above and beyond appreciated.

Here are some figures of where the money we’re aiming to get from IndieGoGo will be going (to name but a few):

Venue hire- £1000

Marketing costs (e.g. graphic design, printing flyers etc)- £400

Technical design/operative costs- £400

London preview fee- £175

Set design- £150

And who are you?

We’re a team of three women working collaboratively to bring this show to life. “Spill Your Guts Here” is written and performed by Sophie Lakely and co-directed by Olivia Meguer and Jackie Fisher. Credits between us include Theatre 503, The Rose Bankside, Sheffield Theatres and Lodestar Theatre Company.

Are there any other ways to help?

We completely understand that you may not be in a position to give anything financially, but if you would still like to follow or support the show’s progress then please do feel very free to share this page! You can also follow us on Twitter at @beckyspillsit.

Thank you so much for all your support! 

Sophie, Olivia and Jackie

story:
Who are you? 

Hello friends, lovers and comrades,

I'm Stephanie Ware; creator of Eva Von Schnippisch - a comedy cabaret compere that has stolen the hearts of all who have found themselves in her company.  Over the 4 years that I have been performing as her she has morphed and grown into an inimitable force of nature and recently I felt that her back-story just HAD to be told to the world.  So I wrote the play, and then my musical partner Oliver Collier composed the most amazing score for it...and HOW EVA VON SCHNIPPISCH SINGLE-HANDEDLY WON WW2 the one-woman musical was born!  The show premiered at the Brighton Fringe Festival with a successful 4-night run at The Nightingale Room...and now Edinburgh is calling...
 

What is the show about?

How Eva Von Schnippisch Single-Handedly Won WW2

The official secrecy act is over – and Eva is ready to set the record straight. Germany’s greatest underground cabaret star turned into Britain’s No.1 spy and was given the toughest mission of all: infiltrate to the top.  Eva tells a comedic, saucy, ‘allo ‘allo-esque, action-packed story of love, betrayal, frankfurters, the 'other' Eva . . . and de-bunks the bunker story once and for all!
It’s time to burn your history books.

***********

“Hilarious” – Artefact Magazine

“A slightly warped randy Marlene Dietrich type.  She makes the whole thing look effortless, which of course means that she’s really good at her job” – London City Nights

"An absolute triumph! One of the funniest, most creative shows I have ever had the pleasure to see. Laughed so much I cried! 

"Back to back gags from start to finish, Brilliant!" 

"My face hurts from laughing so much!" 


What do you need?

I need your donations to help me take this amazingly 'hilarious', 'seat-wetting, laugh-a-minute" show to Edinburgh.  I have won myself a 10-night run with PBH's Free Fringe, a wonderful organisation that helps the 'little man' get their work seen at this world-class theatre & comedy festival.  'Free Fringe' means that performers can take shows to The Edinburgh Fringe without the financial risk, and audiences can go and see shows without spending loads of money.  So, while there are still the guaranteed out-laying costs...there is no guarantee of in-coming revenue. "Why do it then you crazy fool?!" I hear some of you ask.  I do it because I am passionate and committed to getting my show seen and enjoyed and hopefully reviewed so I can take it all over the world...or even just the country....or anywhere.  I'm just doing it, because that's what writers and performers do.  This is by far the finest work I have ever created, I am insanely proud of it and it needs to be shared.


How much are you aiming for & where is it going?

Ladies & Gentlemen I am aiming for £5000.

Putting on a show of any kind costs more money than you ever expect.  Here are just some of the things that your donations will go towards:

Poster & flyer printing, a tonne of blu-tak, national express coach ticket, national express excess baggage supplement ticket, PA hire, projector hire, sound technician for each show, eye-lash glue, costume repairs, frankfurter prop replacement, fresh Brie cheese for each show, batteries for my loudspeaker, insurance (yawn), food to keep me strong, throat lozenges, honey, yogi throat comfort tea, and vitamins to keep me healthy while I work my body, mind & soul to.the.BONE!  

Whilst the above may not appear to be that much, I can assure you that it all adds up quickly and very painfully.  So far I have funded my run at the Brighton Fringe 2016 completely on my own and out of my own pocket, and an artist's pocket is as deep as Boris Johnson's truth plane.  


Why should I donate to Eva?

If you have ever been in the company of Eva Von Schnippisch, if she has ever made you laugh, cry, cackle, smile, titter, raise an eye-brow, chuckle, breath in air through pursed lips, make your loins stir (more than likely), make your palms sweat, make your feet tap, your hips sway or your fingers click.  If Eva has ever made you look at the world in a different way, introduced you to ideas and notions you had never thought of before, made you dream of a better future, or made you remember times past.  If Eva has had any kind of impact on you...then please find it in your hearts and pockets to give her something back.  Think of all the joy she keeps on giving...and how you can re-pay her in kind and allow her to keep on giving that joy to those attending the Edinburgh Fringe and beyond.


Can I see the show before it goes to Edinburgh?

There is one chance and one chance only to see HEVSSHWWW2 before it goes north!
An evening of cabaret guests, 'Truth OR Dare For Dollar' fundraising...and then the hour-long show will take place on:
WEDNESDAY 27th JULY
7:30pm
'The Others', 6 & 8 Manor Rd, Stoke Newington, London N16 5SA

DIFFERENT TICKET TIERS AVAILABLE:
£10 - "I'm A Stingy Git Ticket" 
£15 - "Show Only Ticket"
£20 - "Show & Gift Ticket"
£30 - "VIP Show & Gift Ticket"
 

I'm skint sorry, but can I help Eva another way?

Crowd-funding at a time of austerity is never going to be a good idea *gulp*.  If you really cannot spare £10, but you want to help my cause, then here are some other ways you can help Eva:

  • Help share this campaign with your friends, maybe they can donate instead - so you don't feel so guilty about not donating.
  • Do you know anyone living or going to Edinburgh?!  Maybe they can come to one of my shows?  Maybe they can help me with a lift instead of taking a costly taxi?  Maybe they can make me a hot homely meal or a cup of tea and tell me "everything is going to be alright"?
  • Do you have any PRESS or REVIEWER contacts?  Eva would love you to share any useful contacts with her to help her get maximum coverage at the fringe.
  • Do you have access to unlimited Frankfurters?  Perhaps you know someone who worked for HERTA?  Maybe you can help me get sponsored by HERTA Sausages?
  • Do you have access to a quality printer at work and are happy to take on a covert-printing mission?  Large corporate companies go through paper and ink like its going out of fashion - so who's really going to notice?  Plus, you'll have the inner peace and satisfaction that you've helped the 'underdog' whilst sticking up a metaphorical two-finger salute to the corporate world.
  • Do you have any experience of taking a show to Edinburgh?  Eva would really benefit from your advice over a coffee sometime soon.
  • Follow Eva on social media - 'like', share and help Eva grow. https://www.facebook.com/EvaVonSchnippisch
    https://twitter.com/vonschnippisch
    http://www.missstephanieware.co.uk

story:
Short Summary

Fuse Theatre began one year ago as the realization of a life long dream of Stacey Ardelean to create a theatre community that brings together people to celebrate and learn with and about one another.  This Indiegogo campaign is the result of a year’s worth of planning and preparation.  We have started several partnerships and projects, developed our business plan and are ready to take the company to the next level!  This startup campaign will allow continued development of these partnerships and the ability create new ones. Fuse Theatre is a not for profit, 501(c)3 corporation and contributions are tax deductible.

Fuse Theatre Values:

Collaboration    *    Creativity    *    Connectivity

What we do:

Stage Practice:  Production of original or published works typical of theatres.   Fuse Theatre’s approach is to add elements of audience engagement to deepen understanding and connection to the performance.  The goal of our productions is to engage the community in the production.  The Dating Chronicles is an example of this work.

Applied Theatre Practice:  Applying theatre methods of playmaking, community-based theatre and theatre in education, Fuse works with community partners – both actors and non-actors to generate thought provoking performances. The goals of these programs are to teach, to provide opportunities for collaborative work (create opportunities for silenced voices) and create awareness of social issues through performance.  Fuse Theatre’s Community-Based Theatre Ensemble is an example of this practice.

Civic Engagement Practice: Artists work with the community members to engage in dialogue and discussion using theatre techniques.  The goals of this practice are community connections and civic dialogue.  Fuse Theatre’s co-sponsorship with the San Mateo County History Museum of Pecha Kucha: Redwood City is one example of this practice.

For more about our programs and partnerships go to our website: www.fusetheatre.org

What We Need & What You Get

Our goal is to raise $5000 for our startup fund.  The campaign will fund marketing expenses including graphic design and materials, further web development and seed money for our current projects.  Further funding will be sought for individual projects through grants, ticket sales and sponsorship.  We have several levels of giving so you can help….Light the Fuse! 

*Shirts will be unisex sizing.  When you purchase a Perk that includes a shirt, please make sure you indicate size in the notes section.

*For those supporters out of the area, we will provide you with another special gift from Fuse Theatre!

*Please indicate in the note section if you would like your contribution to remain anonymous.

First 50 Donors over $50 receive a Fuse coffee mug and a special recognition as one of the First 50 for Fuse! 

The Impact

Our goal is building community and creating access to live theatre experiences.  Fuse Theatre’s main approach to create original community-based theatre with artistic partners brings a unique method and approach to our local area. With our startup fundraising we will also begin our Stage Practice and produce two scripted plays for families and youth. We are working to bring theatre into many non-traditional spaces and increase the access to great theatre in our community. 

Risks & Challenges

In a community like the Bay Area where the rents and housing costs continue to rise the challenges facing non-profit arts organizations are great.  By remaining a “nomadic” company we can fulfill our mission of bringing theatre to unique spaces and widen the scope of access for theatre AND can keep our overhead costs lower and focus on creating great theatre while paying our artists competitively.  Our first order of business was to obtain our 501(c)3 so that we could begin to apply for grants and sponsorships. This is of course a challenge as well as a brand new company with a very short history.  This startup fundraiser will also help us establish a "track record" of fundraising and be more marketable in the philanthropic community.  Our current board of directors has experience in marketing, business management, human resources and financial planning.  We are actively seeking other board members with legal, arts marketing and/or theatre experience.

Other Ways You Can Help

Can’t contribute right now?  No worries!  There are lots of ways for you to get involved with Fuse Theatre.

Help us Light the Fuse by….

·  Signing up on our mailing list at fusetheatre.org

·  Follow us on Facebook, twitter and instagram, and/or LinkedIn

·  Enroll in our upcoming Community-Based Theatre Ensemble this fall through Redwood City Park and Recs.

·  Come see our shows!  The next is the Dating Chronicles on June 25th in Redwood City at Angelicas. Click here for tickets! (or donate and receive tickets as a perk!)

·  AND share the FUSE news and this campaign with everyone through Indiegogo’s share tools.

overhead costs lower and focus on creating great theatre while paying our artists competitively.  Our first order of business was to
obtain our 501(c)3 so that we could begin to apply for grants and sponsorships. This is of course a challenge as well as a brand new company with a very short history.  This startup fundraiser will also help us establish a "track record" of fundraising and be more marketable in the philanthropic community.  Our current board of
directors has experience in marketing, business management, human resources and
financial planning.  We are
actively seeking other board members with legal, arts marketing and/or theatre experience. 
Other Ways You Can Help
Can’t
contribute right now?  No
worries!  There are lots of ways
for you to get involved with Fuse Theatre.

Help us Light the Fuse by….
· 
Signing up on
our mailing list at fusetheatre.org 
· 
Follow us on
Facebook, twitter and instagram, and/or LinkedIn
· 
Enroll in our
upcoming Community-Based Theatre Ensemble this fall through Redwood City Park
and Recs.
· 
Come see our
shows!  The next is the Dating
Chronicles on June 25th in Redwood City at Angelicas. Click here for tickets! (or donate and receive tickets as a perk!)
· 
AND share the
FUSE news and this campaign with everyone through Indiegogo’s share tools.

story:
About us:

Nebula Company Theatre is a not-for-profit theatre company in Vancouver BC led by artistic director Mily Mumford (who is also the writer/director for this show). Our mandate is to create intelligent, political and innovative theatre that promotes the work and voices of racially and gender diverse artists. We also incorporate an element of science fiction to every show.

 

About the show:

In short- it’s the Breakfast Club in space. It is two generations into the future and Earth is uninhabitable. A subsection of the population survives in space stations in orbit around our planet, a "time-capsule" of mostly very privileged Americans. A misfit group of the “post-script” generation- the first to be born in space- bond over their shared anxieties and a desire to reconcile with what happened to the rest of humanity. It aims to shed light on the dynamics of oppression in our current society, while providing a futurist view of what climate change and a divided Western World could produce. Also spaceships, hoverboards and a sassy social media robot called Facebot.

 

So here’s the breakdown:

Making cool science-fiction-dystopic-#resistance theatre isn’t free. Now we at Nebula Company are pretty crafty at making cool space effects on the cheap, but we still need a bit of help to cover the costs of things like venue space, paying house technicians, materials for set (think plexi-glass, a LOT of plexi-glass) and costumes. We want to try to raise as much money as we can to cover these costs so any money we make on ticket sales can go back to our performers, designers and crew.

 

Now will $2500 cover all of it, you may be wondering? No. We are applying for additional funding through Granville Island, the City of Vancouver and individual donors. But we realize that a lot of folks we share this campaign with are in a similar boat to us- that is, dirt poor living on the salary of a moisture farmer on Tatooine. So we wanted to make a realistic so contributions of small amounts like $5-15 still make a big difference. In fact, we’d only need 500 facebook friends to give us 5 bucks.

 

Here is what we are going to be spending this campaign money on:

$500 event insurance (required by venue)

$500 makeup, latex prosthetics and contact lenses

$200 costumes (we have sourced some already from the workshop)

$250 sfx rentals (fog machine, extra projectors, super secret hologram building supplies)

$250 marketing (part of this will be posters, photography and our publicist)

$500 set materials (scrim material, pvc pipes and PLEXI-GLASS)

$300 rehearsal space rental for last two weeks of rehearsals

 

Anything you can give helps! And if you can't contribute please share our campaign. And thank you for reading and supporting!

story:
If you've seen The Humble Boys live in concert, you know that when they begin to play, the room stops, heart rates rise, goosebumps appear, and eyes start to mist. 

When Juan and Ahmed approached me with the vision for this live show, I experienced the same symptoms. "All You Seek" is a collection of songs that take the listener on a journey through artistic struggle, love, loss, and revitalization. They wanted to tell this story not just musically, but visually, through dance and movement. I come from a deep background of physical theater, and I know how powerfully an actor can engage their body to tell a story.

We have gathered a group of performers with immense talent: Actors with backgrounds in African Dance, Jazz, Ballet, Tap, Pole Dance, and more. Actors with intensive physical theater training and with music in their bones. We've recruited a company of talented strings, brass, and percussion players, to fill out the sound that The Humble Boys envision. Juan and Ahmed have entrusted me (Dani Larson) with the role of Director, and I am going to bring together all of these different elements to tell the story of "All You Seek."

Your donation of $25 gets you a ticket to one of our two performances this December:

All You Seek

Friday, December 1st 8:00 p.m.

Friday, December 8th 8:00 p.m.

 Performances @ Downtown Dance & Movement

What We Need & What You Get

As you probably know, not all artists are rolling in dough, and not every project is backed by a generous and financially-blessed funder. This group is incredibly rich in training, qualification, and talent, but this show has no Executive Producer. YOU are the Executive Producers. With $6,000, we can...

  • Finish booking rehearsal space.
  • Pay all the performers. (Much less than what they are worth, but more than nothing!)
  • Move a piano into the performance space.
  • Hire a lighting designer for the show. 
  • Pay The Humble Boys and the director. 

If just 240 of you (that's 120 people per performance) donate $25 each, we can reach our goal. You donation is your advanced ticket sale to see the show.

Without these advance ticket sales, the show won't happen. 

Your donation today gets you something truly tangible. Your butt in a seat on December 1st or December 8th. These are going to be truly magical, can't-miss evenings, filled with electricity. I am truly overwhelmed by the amount of talent behind this project already, and I can promise you that you will get every penny's worth of your investment in this project today. 

Real Talk

Since completing my M.F.A. in Acting at USC in 2015, I have learned....SO much in the school of life. Here are some things I've learned:

  1. Everyone is hustling. How many jobs do YOU have?
  2. Nothing is free. Do you know how much a cup of coffee costs at Intelligentsia in Silver Lake? I. Can't. Even. Tell. You. It's too embarrassing. Ahmed and I accidentally had a meeting there one time and immediately regretted it. Never again. We have learned our lesson. We are THRIFTY. 
  3. You have to create opportunities yourself. I am so tired of telling myself the story that I don't have the resources, the opportunities, the connections, to do what I was born to do. I'm a storyteller, and I'm here to rewrite this story. 
  4. In this crazy, mixed-up world, ART MATTERS. Talent matters. Heart matters. It is so easy to look around the world today and feel despair. To feel helpless. But when we come together to create something collaboratively, we literally change the world. 

So. Help us rewrite the story of the struggling artist. Participate. Be our Executive Producer. If you can't afford $25, that's okay, we'll still welcome you to the show with open arms. If you can afford more than $25, that's great! You are sending the message that art matters and that artists deserve to be paid. Either way, just make sure to tell us which night you'd like to come when you make your donation, and help us spread the word. Invite a hot date to come with you, bring your Mom, bring a stranger, make a friend. 

We thank you from the bottom of our hearts for your vote of confidence, and for your investment in us. We look forward to seeing you in December. 

All of my best, always,

Dani Larson

P.S. Want to learn more about us? Go to www.thehumbleboys.com and www.danilars.com . We are like, so legit, that we even have websites.

story:
Short Summary

My name is Iyun Ashani Harrison and I am the artistic director and founder of ASHANI DANCES. Throughout my education at the Juilliard School and Hollins University; my professional career with Dance Theatre of Harlem, Ailey II and Ballet Hispanico; and my teaching at Goucher College, The Ailey School, and Pacific Northwest Ballet, I have developed a passion for choreography and mentoring young dance artists as they launch their performance careers.

ASHANI DANCES will return to The Baltimore Theatre Project from November 17, 18 & 19, 2017 to present FIVE! The concert features a collaboration with Baltimore singer song writer, Marc Avon Evans. Mr. Evans is a Baltimore based, international recording & performing artist who tours Europe, Asia, & Australia. He and his band will set the stage for a steamy night club scene where the Ashani Dancers live out Charm City fantasies.

This year’s concert features a special event for its Saturday matinee performance of Goucher College's Dancers of Color Coalition. The DOCC will present an interdisciplinary concert conceived, created and performed by Goucher student artists. 

It also presents young DMV talent with alumni and current students of Goucher College, and Virginia Commonwealth University. We will also have will have dancers from Cornish College of the Arts and New World School of the Arts.

Contributing to ASHANI DANCES' FIVE! campaign will help to underwrite the costs of our theater rental, advertising, archiving the concert, production expenses: costume design and construction, musical commission fee, lighting design, technical staff fees and dancer salaries.

What We Need & What You Get

ASHANI DANCES needs to raise $8,000 to cover our production expenses. These are some of our expenses:

Theater Rental - $3,000

Compensation for 8 dancers - $5,000

Musician fees - $2,000

Poster & postcard design, Photography & Videography: $1,500

Give $1000 and a dance will be titled with your name! You will also receive a signed ASHANI DANCES season poster, company t-shirt, attendance to any/all rehearsals and performances of your choosing, and your name will be listed in the concert program as: "Platinum Donor for Ashani Dances" and you will be invited to join the advisory board of ASHANI DANCES!

Give $500 and you will receive a signed ASHANI DANCES season poster and company-shirt. Your name will be listed in the season program as: "Production made possible by a generous donation from (your name here)". Attend one rehearsal of your choosing and a reserved seat at the opening night performance of ASHANI DANCES' FIVE! and you will be listed as a "Gold Donor" in the concert program.

Give $100 and you will receive a signed season poster, a reserved seat at the opening night performance of ASHANI DANCES' FIVE! and you will be listed as a "Friend" of ASHANI DANCES in the concert program. 

Give $50 and you will receive a signed copy of the ASHANI DANCES' season poster. 

Give $5 - $49 and you'll get a shout out on our Facebook page.

The Impact

I’d like to share some of the positive feedback about ASHANI DANCES' previous concerts.

Andrew Sargus Klein of Bmoreart.com writes,

“Love Me, Now Leave Me Alone is an important reminder that dance is a powerfully responsive tool, one that has the power to delve deeply, and then go beyond, visual work like Hopper’s ... there were beautiful, breathtaking glimpses of intimacy and melancholy, love and despair: all Hopper-esque, but also universal and evergreen.”

http://www.bmoreart.com/2016/10/love-me-now-lea...

Alice Kaderlan of The Seattle Times writes, 

"Ashani Dances Is On The Rise ... Harrison, with three very different works. Together, they showcased an artist of diverse talents with sophisticated musical tastes and an understanding of how to use a bare stage to full effect. Appearing at the Broadway Performance Hall, Harrison relied on lighting, rather than expensive sets, to enhance the mood and energy of his ballets. The costumes were simple but effective ..." 
http://seattletimes.com/html/thearts/2023801915...

Gabrielle Nomura of Seattle Dances writes,
"The result is a company [Ashani Dances] on par with Seattle’s elite in contemporary dance: Spectrum Dance Theater and Whim W’him,Harrison’s international experience and classical background presents a refreshing niche in Seattle’s contemporary dance market; his technical, virtuosic dancers are appealing to both dance aficionados, as well as the general public." 
http://seattledances.com/2014/06/harrison-helps...

Ciara McCormack of Seattle Dances writes:
"Harrison’s The Leaves Have Fallen ... lifts and transitions were seamless, a constant connection between the dancers carrying them from one set to the next ... the structure of the piece rose to the surface, highlighting the identities of the characters and reflecting the development of their dialogue. The work’s vocabulary and the magnetic ebb and flow of the dancers’ spatial relationship implied an intimate relationship, which can easily be construed as a depiction of romantic struggle and loss. Harrison stressed in the talk that his mentorship of a younger dancer and the experience of sending him off to a new opportunity inspired the piece. At its heart, Leaves is a tough conversation between two people who love and respect each other, who rely on each other, yet have separate paths to follow." 
http://seattledances.com/2014/05/veteran-dancer...

Dean Speer of  Critical Dance Forum writes, 

"Not only did Harrison show off what the dancers can do, the dancers showed off his truly excellent dances." 

http://www.ballet-dance.com/forum/viewtopic.php...

Michael Upchurch of the Seattle Times writes,

"Last weekend I described Ashani Dances as "a promising new local dance company." Scratch that. This troupe is exceptionally accomplished, and their showcase of three new works by artistic director Iyun Ashani Harrison is a knockout. Most of the dancers have an affiliation with Cornish College of the Arts where Harrison teaches (some are graduates, some still students). All have strong, agile ballet skills which are given an intoxicating Afro-Caribbean twist in "Artifact," a joyous, sassy, intricate homage to what Harrison calls "the beautiful traditional dances of my childhood in Jamaica." Local composer-percussionist Ben Morrow penned the dance-propulsive score. Sean Rosado and Sam Picart are reasons alone to catch this while you can."

Other Ways You Can Help

If you are not able to contribute financially but are still interested in helping, here is how you can do so:

Share our campaign on your social media pages.

Volunteer to help us load into, and out of the theater.

Organize a group of your friends, family or children to attend our concert at Baltimore Theatre Project from November 17, 18 & 19, 2017.

story:
The Shooting Stars Experience is an epic 3 day dance journey offered to dance artists to deepen their art in an intimate setting with a world renowned artist of Bellydance.  As a reward for all of this hard work, we host an evening dance showcase called Shooting Stars Of The Night that allows these dancers to showcase their art to the world, allowing for networking and professional opportunities for those involved.  Your donation helps us to make sure the financial needs of this Experience are covered, allowing us to offer our dancers this full weekend of exploration and growth year after year.

 

It is very hard to create an event like this without proper financial backing. We depend on participants and the generosity of our family, friends, fans, and community to make these events successful. We cannot do it without all of you!

 

In exchange for your generous donation, you will be recognized as an official sponsor of our 2017 event.  You will also obtain exclusive access to the show!  Only our followers on Patreon and YOU get this opportunity!

 

Celebrate life, dance, and growth with us at The Shooting Stars Experience!  Hugs and shimmies to one and all!

 

If you would like to be involved in The Shooting Stars Experience as a student or vendor, please check out our Facebook event page for all of the info: https://www.facebook.com/events/1511337002213481

story:
WORLD PREMIER: OCTOBER 2017, NYC - TICKETS ON SALE AT ABRONS

ABOUT THE SHOW
It is seventeen minutes past midnight, Oceanic Time. On a sparse soundstage, a show is about to begin - there is an occasional flicker of light - a sonic shudder - an atmosphere of electronic energy. In this sci-fi misadventure of secret agents and seductresses, where Alphaville meets ASMR, Why Why Always conjures a live cine-performance through the interplay of otherworldly video, music, sound, and technology. Mesmeric whispers fill the air, lighters flash, linens are folded, and a tyrannical super computer is foiled.

In April 2016, we staged a workshop performance of Why Why Always at Abrons.  The positive feedback we received during that run inspired us to continue working and fully realize this project.

This show is complex! – we have four live performers, multiple projections, performers on video, seven live-feed cameras – and a bare bones crew (consisting largely of ourselves)!  In the final weeks before our World Premiere - we need to raise at least an additional $5,000 to pay our amazing performers and collaborators as well as hire additional tech and administrative support. 

ABOUT US
We are Brooklyn based, multiplatform artists who make interdisciplinary performances, multimedia installations, films and interactive video scores for live performance. Recent projects include a feature-length documentary Standing By: Gatz Backstage about ERS's epic production Gatz, Keep Your Electric Eye On Me, a multimedia performance seen at HERE (2014), as well as a self-generating video installation, Atmospheres & Accidental Ghosts (NY Electronic Arts Festival, 2015). Our work has been seen in NYC, nationally, and internationally at venues such as BAM, The Brooklyn Museum, Abrons, The Chocolate Factory, Anthology Film Archives, Tokyo Wonder Site, REDCAT, and the Venice Biennale. They have received numerous awards including grants, fellowships and residencies from the NEA, NYSCA, NYFA, LMCC, Jerome Foundation, Harvestworks, Asian Cultural Council, Signal Culture, Yaddo, The MacDowell Colony, BAU Institute/Camargo Foundation and the Bogliasco Foundation. www.automaticrelease.org

 

Created and Conceived by Shaun Irons & Lauren Petty
Video and Media and live-processing by Shaun & Lauren

Performers (live): Jim Fletcher, Elizabeth Carena, Laura Bartczak, Marion Spencer
Performers (video): Scott Shepherd, Madeline Best
Narration: Christina Campanella
Voiceovers: Olivier Conan, Kate Valk, Shaun Irons
Additional music: Brian Rogers
Costumes and Props: Amy Mascena
Creative Technology Design:  Danli Hu, Lauren Petty
Sound Engineer: Ian Douglas-Moore
Lighting: Jon Harper
Ending choreography originated by: Shandoah Goldman
Stage Manager:  Randi Rivera
Technical Consultant: Bill Kennedy
 


 Why Why Always is made in part with support from New York State Council on the Arts Individual Artists Program (Film, Media, New Technology Production and Theater Commission) with the support of Governor Andrew M. Cuomo and the New York State Legislature. Additional sounds and images were created during a residency at Signal Culture.
story_txt: WORLD PREMIER: OCTOBER 2017, NYC - TICKETS ON SALE AT ABRONSABOUT THE SHOWIt is seventeen minutes past midnight, Oceanic Time. On a sparse soundstage, a show is about to begin - there is an occasional flicker of light - a sonic shudder - an atmosphere of electronic energy. In this sci-fi misadventure of secret agents and seductresses, where Alphaville meets ASMR, Why Why Always conjures a live cine-performance through the interplay of otherworldly video, music, sound, and technology. Mesmeric whispers fill the air, lighters flash, linens are folded, and a tyrannical super computer is foiled.In April 2016, we staged a workshop performance of Why Why Always at Abrons.  The positive feedback we received during that run inspired us to continue working and fully realize this project.This show is complex! – we have four live performers, multiple projections, performers on video, seven live-feed cameras – and a bare bones crew (consisting largely of ourselves)!  In the final weeks before our World Premiere - we need to raise at least an additional $5,000 to pay our amazing performers and collaborators as well as hire additional tech and administrative support. ABOUT USWe are Brooklyn based, multiplatform artists who make interdisciplinary performances, multimedia installations, films and interactive video scores for live performance. Our work has been seen in NYC, nationally, and internationally at venues such as BAM, The Brooklyn Museum, Abrons, The Chocolate Factory, Anthology Film Archives, Tokyo Wonder Site, REDCAT, and the Venice Biennale. They have received numerous awards including grants, fellowships and residencies from the NEA, NYSCA, NYFA, LMCC, Jerome Foundation, Harvestworks, Asian Cultural Council, Signal Culture, Yaddo, The MacDowell Colony, BAU Institute/Camargo Foundation and the Bogliasco Foundation. www.automaticrelease.org Created and Conceived by Shaun Irons & Lauren PettyVideo and Media and live-processing by Shaun & LaurenPerformers (live): Jim Fletcher, Elizabeth Carena, Laura Bartczak, Marion SpencerPerformers (video): Scott Shepherd, Madeline BestNarration: Christina CampanellaVoiceovers: Olivier Conan, Kate Valk, Shaun IronsAdditional music: Brian RogersCostumes and Props: Amy MascenaCreative Technology Design:  Danli Hu, Lauren PettySound Engineer: Ian Douglas-MooreLighting: Jon HarperEnding choreography originated by: Shandoah GoldmanStage Manager:  Randi RiveraTechnical Consultant: Bill Kennedy  Why Why Always is made in part with support from New York State Council on the Arts Individual Artists Program (Film, Media, New Technology Production and Theater Commission) with the support of Governor Andrew M. story:
Hello & Thank You for reading.....

We are Tenth Muse Productions and we are passionate about creating exciting and innovative theatre that is accessible to everyone. Our company represent a team of dynamic female creatives who wanted to bring 'Beauty' into the 21st Century whilst maintaining a Gothic Fairytale world.

The idea of 'Beauty and the Beast The Play' was born out of our desire to create something new and different in theatre. To take one of the most famous stories ever written and actually rewrite it. Transport it to a darker world and bring something to audience goers that they have never experienced before. This project is extremely important to us in helping to promote women in theatre and brings together an ethnically diverse and international cast. 

As aspiring creatives promoting work in a competitive industry can be difficult, but art is a communal thing and we want to share our work with as many people as possible and your support would not only help us to stage a great theatrical experience, but also help us to stage future versions of the show.

All funds raised will help to create our costumes, set, lighting and sound which together will bring this concept to life.  And for your support - you'll find our perks listed on the side, and each one has been lovingly crafted to give you a heartfelt thank you for your generosity. 

Can't donate? We still like you! Hey, you took the time to read our page! You would still be helping us massively by spreading the word! Have any friends or family who like theatre? Please feel free to share our campaign on social media. Any exposure would be extremely helpful, and top up your balance in the bank of karma!

And if you want to just come along and watch the play, that's great too! We're performing at The Omnibus Theatre in Clapham, London from the 5th July - 14th July every night at 7:30pm and there are matinees on Saturday 7th and Saturday 14th July at 2pm.

story:
The Chain Theatre Story: True Grit

For 8 years we’ve brought the NYC community some of the hardest hitting revivals and new plays being produced in the five boroughs and have supported thousands of artists.  We celebrate independent filmmakers with regular screenings and an international film festival every summer. And that has happened because of YOUR SUPPORT and the community around us.  Starting August 1, 2018 we have been given the opportunity to help build an artistic community once again -  The Chain will have a new 66 seat home in the Theater Building 312 W. 36th St (Between 8th and 9th Ave) NYC.

It is no secret that the current state of the arts is one of incredible challenge for independent artists - yet in the face of constant overwhelming adversity, we have always succeeded.  In 2012 after bouncing around different theater spaces in Manhattan we opened the Chain Theatre in Long Island City. It was tough. We were under funded. We were understaffed. And we built it with our own hands during Hurricane Sandy when the contractors walked off the job. But… it was glorious. We built a family of artists. The theater was open 7 days a week. We gave other theater companies the opportunity to produce in our space. We won awards. And then in 2016 the landlord sold all of his property in LIC and we lost the place we had poured our souls into.

WE DIDN’T STOP: From 2016 we’ve continued our SOLD OUT comedy shows, the Usual Rejects in NYC theaters and Comic Conventions on the east coast.  In the summer months we gained inspiration from special guests at our annual International Film Festivals from screenwriters Richard LaGravense (The Fisher King) and Richard Price (The Color of Money). In 2017 we worked with Tony Award Winning Playwright David Rabe on a revised revival of In the Boom Boom Room. These years have shown us the opportunity for expanded audience in NYC. Also, this proved to us that we again wanted someplace we could call home.

The Theater Building at 312 W. 36th Street in NYC between 8th and 9th Ave is in the heart of ‘the crossroads of the world’. The best location, in the best city for theater in the entire world. A hop, skip and jump from Times Square. 

We know how to do this. We’ve done it before. We are ready. Our work will have more visibility, frequency and longevity in this location. 

Your TAX DEDUCTIBLE contributions will help:

Buy new equipment to improve the venue. 
We need new lighting instruments, a new light board, and would like to start making the move toward a more energy efficient LED system. Not only will it make our space more sustainable but it will significantly reduce the electric bill.

Operational Expenses.  This is a big step forward for us.  That step also means a significant “cost of living” increase.

Support our programming. We have a new theater development lab ready to begin as well as many shows that we are looking forward to beginning work on. Usual Rejects shows will be performed every month.

Spread the word through increased targeted marketing.  We need to get the word out and the best platforms in the world exist now to create an impact on a low budget.

Support our year-round internship program.  Providing stipends to our interns for travel and food.  Many of our interns have become members of the company and continued their higher education in theater and film.

Move our equipment out of storage and into the new space.  Luckily we’ve done this before and have some equipment. It will cost to get out of storage and move. Moving vans and the help to make the move.

By helping us reach our goal you will be part of the foundation of our company’s future in our new space.

Building for success:

Past support has led to 20 award winning main stage productions, 6 playwriting festivals, 26 comedy events, and 5 international film festivals. It is often hard for granting organizations to wrap their head around the fact that we support both theater and film artists. We see it as our key to success. Films are accessible, theater is not always viewed that way. It is why we often choose plays that have been developed into films. We firmly believe that for theater to have a lasting impact, it needs to be accessible to everyone. We need to shake things up. 

If you are unable to financially contribute; please share this campaign on social media: Facebook, Twitter, Instagram. It makes an impact. Thank you for listening to our story.

 

"The leaders of the Chain are among the great unsung heros of cultural New York. Chain Theatre screenings and on stage interviews are both excellent and funkily unique. Long may wave." Richard Price Academy Award Nominated Screenwriter and Novelist  (The Night Of, The Color of Money, The Deuce, The Wire, Clockers)

 

We want to thank Indie Space and Randi Berry for bringing this opportunity to us; continuing their important mission to keep theaters open in NYC.

story:
THE STORY


A young Syrian woman living in New York City has forgotten all about her past, but when she identifies her estranged grandmother on the news among Syrian refugees in the Balkan borders, she embarks on a mission to find her. It will become a spiritual journey to rediscover her roots and her own identity. Dhana is a sort of upside down Greek heroine:  she doesn’t return home after the war, but runs away from peace to find home again in the war. 

Looking for her grandmother, Sham, Syrian-born American Dhana travels to the Balkans at the heart of the migration crisis, across borders and through refugee camps, train stations, and makeshift shelters. Amidst such dramatic circumstances, Dhana gathers a clue to unlocking her identity at every step on her journey. 

 

The Scene (Dhana #Scene49)  Which You Will Help Us Bring to Brooklyn

Inside a tent within a refugee camp, a young Syrian is getting married and all the women around her participate in the ritual to ready her for this special moment. 

While watching these unique circumstances unfold, Dhana finds herself trapped in a suspended dreamlike reality. All women in her present and in her past surround her and merge: her Syrian childhood memories resurface, the ones no bomb could destroy.

Why Support This Performance?

Migration is a topic that dominates public debate all over the world. While we live our lives in relative comfort and security, migrants are leaving their homes forever, losing loved ones, and risking death. Through this performance of Dhana and the Rosebuds, we seek to raise questions, emotions, and doubts. This is a crucial moment, and we want to channel the public attention and raise awareness of this defining phenomenon of our time - migration and immigration.  This performance of Dhana and the Rosebuds explores the  refugee crisis in a more intimate way than the statistical reporting of news outlets through an all-female personal narrative. Dhana's journey is extreme and unique, but it is also universal.  In addition to sustaining live theatre, your donations support a story which elucidates topics such as the evolution of personal identity and the challenge to return to the past in order to embrace the future. 

History of the Performance

The performance Dhana #Scene49 is an adaptation of the original screenplay, Dhana and the Rosebuds, written by Federica Cellini and Giulia Corda, which first appeared on stage in Washington, DC. The performance for the In scena! theatre festival is adapted and directed by Federica Cellini. The cast consists of actors Ali Evarts, Valerie Fenton, Lia Johnson, Lauren Kieler, and Sue Struve. The music is composed and improvised by Irene Jalenti.

Federica Cellini, director and artist, Federica Cellini, defines herself as a storyteller above all. With a journalistic background, her long and creative professional journey is an evolving experiment on trying to achieve her goals in presenting each story in a specific manner. She uses various media in her research, exploring them all to the fullest, mostly focusing on social issues and current affairs. 

The “migration crisis” swallows fears, dreams, and the stories of these people.This journey is too often translated only into numbers building up in news reports. Dhana and the Rosebuds was born from the desire to explore the refugee crisis in a more intimate way. Cellini harnesses the power of live performance to tell the story of a woman whose identity lies at the very heart of the past she is trying to run away from. Bouncing between different places over the years has made her aware of the connections among seemingly distant human beings and of the challenges faced by immigrants.

What We Need

  • Round-trip ground transportation between DC and NYC - $875
  • Accommodations for directors, cast, and crew in Williamsburg, Brooklyn - $2000
  • Actor reimbursement for one week of rehearsals - $375 ($75/actor)
  • Actor reimbursement for the performance - $1500 ($300/actor)
  • Transport of heavy props (i.e. a piano and a bathtub) from DC to NYC  - $250

  • Total: $5,000

Ready to Donate? 

Click "Back It" and enter the amount with which you are comfortable, or check out our three perks!

Other Ways You Can Help

If you're not ready to donate, you can still support our performance of Dhana and the Rosebuds by:

  • sharing this fundraiser page as well as any other updates about Dhana and the Rosebuds. (Word of mouth is key!)
  • coming to see the show at The Brick Theater in Brooklyn on May 14th_  https://inscenany.com

story:
Short Summary

“Foolery, sir, does walk about the orb like the sun; it shines everywhere.”
–William Shakespeare

My name is Will Sanders. I'm a professional clown. I started Fool Foundry in late 2017 because going to France for two years to clown school was a ridiculous notion, especially given all the fabulous talent in my hometown, Houston, TX. Art doesn't come from merely L.A., New York and Chicago. Our diverse, enormous, and economically prosperous city has been producing staggeringly great art for YEARS. 

But there is a problem. We in Houston, in Texas, and in the Southwest have failed to participate in the great tradition of theatrical clowning.

Down here, theatrical clowning is a desert. We do have many clowns, mainly of two kinds - Birthday Party clowns and Rodeo clowns. They are funny and important, but limited in scope. This clown, at least in the public eye, is only a caricature of something deeper. This "High Clown" has the potential to be more meaningful to audiences, and in my opinion, crucial to our world. Fool Foundry is one answer to bringing high clowning to our community.

So what kinds of clowns qualify as Fool Foundry type clowns? Examples include the great Slava of Slava's Snowshow, Marcel Marceau, Charlie Chaplin, and so, so many others. And though too few Americans realize it, clowning is an ancient tradition, and is internationally recognized as a fine art. It is enjoyed by all in circuses, theatres, opera houses, classrooms, even on the street, and all over the world ...except here. That's why we need your support to build our great community.

Fool Foundry's mission is CHANGE this. I cannot tell you the amazing energy coming from our performers and community at large. They have been begging for something like this for a long long time. With your support, we will build just that!

What We Need & What You Get

Our very first mission is to send a group of clowns to the Center for Movement Theatre in Washington, DC. http://www.thisisthecenter.com/cmt.html, for a workshop running June 4 - 9.
Here, we will begin our training in a wonderful tradition of mask-driven theatre, a starting point to the Clown. To engage with the body this way, is to develop a kind of language of gesture. If you have ever seen a talented mime, who has complete control over the expression of their movement, they likely have had this training.

  • We need 1,200 dollars. It's not much (well, it's a whole heck-of-a-lot to us!), but it does cover tuition, and travel expenses for two clowns-to-be. We must start this small, as Rome was not build in a 30-day indiegogo. If we surpass this goal, we will invest it into the company, and do bigger, better, theatre. From the class, we will return to Houston and begin performing and offering classes in this heightened form of Clown. Additionally, and perhaps more importantly, we will work to expand charitable efforts such as clown doctoring, and serving underprivileged youngsters through performance in schools and Theatre for Young Adults (TYA).

 

  • We've got three rewards for our backers. Performances, Classes and Merch! Enjoy our live and digital performances, t-shirts, wristbands, signed masks (from the video!) and hoodies. Give what you can, and get back our tremendous thanks and thank-you gifts. You've put us one step forward on a very worthy path.

 

  • If we fall short, the funds will be used to partially cover tuition for the mask class. The only difference is that we are that much poorer, and y'all don't get that cool merchandise!

The Impact

Clowning, at its best, touches people on a fundamental level. Clowns give us the freedom to feel. They nurture our joy, make us laugh, make us feel safe to be vulnerable. Those who learn the art of clowning are taken back to their childhood selves, back to the place before we learned to judge ourselves, to be embarrassed. Ask yourself, does the world need this kind of empathy?

If you answered, 'yes,' then you understand the stakes: We live in a time when our world and its people are undergoing massive changes. We are ever more divided in an increasingly technological, mechanical age. Anxieties ranging from nuclear war, unending prejudice, and a relentless onslaught of pressure upon our children makes our world a harder place to live, to be happy, to be free. Clowning frees us from these anxieties, shows us we can make mistakes, and helps us to overcome psychological barriers to happiness, such as fear, doubt and cynicism. Clowning can be one answer these problems, but only when we work together.

  • Apart from receiving our thank you gifts, you will be helping build a wonderful community of artists. As clowns, our primary mission is to make people happy. With your donation, you know that there is more laughter and joy in the world. How awesome is that?!

 

  • I have been building organizations and businesses since my teenage years. There have been many more failures than successes. I've made more my share of mistakes, all of which have been wonderful learning opportunities. I am excited to funnel all the lessons I have learned into Fool Foundry, and  to continue learning.

 

  • This is your chance to make a difference in more lives than any of us can imagine. From we at Fool Foundry, to our internet audience, to the children that will forget their particular difficulties, your dollars are working, literally to make more people happy. We don't do this stuff to get rich quick. We don't perform to live a charmed, starving artist's life. We do it because we love it, we believe in its power, and we want to make a difference. Please join us as we do just that.

Risks & Challenges

Building an entire art scene from scratch is no easy feat. It will take many, many years to reach the vision I and our team see for ourselves. A simple class in DC may be our starting point, but when we get home, we have to hit the ground running! 

    Fortunately, we already have vendors, performance spaces, clowns, and students lined up. The final pieces are man power for taking care of business needs, such as social networking, legal fees and other necessary expenses. With your donation, we WILL overcome those challenges.

    Other Ways You Can Help

    Just because you can't donate today, you CAN hit that share button! Let your friends know about us. Subscribe to us on youtube, follow us on facebook, twitter, and Insta! Visit us at foolfoundry.fun to keep up with all our important information, and silliness.

    Facebook

    Twitter

    Instagram
story_txt:
Short Summary
“Foolery, sir, does walk about the orb like the sun; it shines everywhere.”–William Shakespeare
My name is Will Sanders. I'm a professional clown. I started Fool Foundry in late 2017 because going to France for two years to clown school was a ridiculous notion, especially given all the fabulous talent in my hometown, Houston, TX. Art doesn't come from merely L.A., New York and Chicago. Our diverse, enormous, and economically prosperous city has been producing staggeringly great art for YEARS. 
But there is a problem. We in Houston, in Texas, and in the Southwest have failed to participate in the great tradition of theatrical clowning.
Down here, theatrical clowning is a desert. We do have many clowns, mainly of two kinds - Birthday Party clowns and Rodeo clowns. They are funny and important, but limited in scope. This clown, at least in the public eye, is only a caricature of something deeper. This "High Clown" has the potential to be more meaningful to audiences, and in my opinion, crucial to our world. Fool Foundry is one answer to bringing high clowning to our community.
So what kinds of clowns qualify as Fool Foundry type clowns? Examples include the great Slava of Slava's Snowshow, Marcel Marceau, Charlie Chaplin, and so, so many others. And though too few Americans realize it, clowning is an ancient tradition, and is internationally recognized as a fine art. It is enjoyed by all in circuses, theatres, opera houses, classrooms, even on the street, and all over the world ...except here. That's why we need your support to build our great community.
Fool Foundry's mission is CHANGE this. I cannot tell you the amazing energy coming from our performers and community at large. They have been begging for something like this for a long long time. With your support, we will build just that!

What We Need & What You Get
Our very first mission is to send a group of clowns to the Center for Movement Theatre in Washington, DC. http://www.thisisthecenter.com/cmt.html, for a workshop running June 4 - 9.Here, we will begin our training in a wonderful tradition of mask-driven theatre, a starting point to the Clown. To engage with the body this way, is to develop a kind of language of gesture. If you have ever seen a talented mime, who has complete control over the expression of their movement, they likely have had this training.
We need 1,200 dollars. It's not much (well, it's a whole heck-of-a-lot to us!), but it does cover tuition, and travel expenses for two clowns-to-be. We must start this small, as Rome was not build in a 30-day indiegogo. If we surpass this goal, we will invest it into the company, and do bigger, better, theatre. From the class, we will return to Houston and begin performing and offering classes in this heightened form of Clown. Additionally, and perhaps more importantly, we will work to expand charitable efforts such as clown doctoring, and serving underprivileged youngsters through performance in schools and Theatre for Young Adults (TYA).
 
We've got three rewards for our backers. Performances, Classes and Merch! Enjoy our live and digital performances, t-shirts, wristbands, signed masks (from the video!) and hoodies. Give what you can, and get back our tremendous thanks and thank-you gifts. You've put us one step forward on a very worthy path.
 
If we fall short, the funds will be used to partially cover tuition for the mask class. The only difference is that we are that much poorer, and y'all don't get that cool merchandise!

The Impact
Clowning, at its best, touches people on a fundamental level. Clowns give us the freedom to feel. They nurture our joy, make us laugh, make us feel safe to be vulnerable. Those who learn the art of clowning are taken back to their childhood selves, back to the place before we learned to judge ourselves, to be embarrassed. Ask yourself, does the world need this kind of empathy?
If you answered, 'yes,' then you understand the stakes: We live in a time when our world and its people are undergoing massive changes. We are ever more divided in an increasingly technological, mechanical age. Anxieties ranging from nuclear war, unending prejudice, and a relentless onslaught of pressure upon our children makes our world a harder place to live, to be happy, to be free. Clowning frees us from these anxieties, shows us we can make mistakes, and helps us to overcome psychological barriers to happiness, such as fear, doubt and cynicism. Clowning can be one answer these problems, but only when we work together.
Apart from receiving our thank you gifts, you will be helping build a wonderful community of artists. As clowns, our primary mission is to make people happy. With your donation, you know that there is more laughter and joy in the world. How awesome is that?!
 
I have been building organizations and businesses since my teenage years. There have been many more failures than successes. I've made more my share of mistakes, all of which have been wonderful learning opportunities. I am excited to funnel all the lessons I have learned into Fool Foundry, and  to continue learning.
 
This is your chance to make a difference in more lives than any of us can imagine. From we at Fool Foundry, to our internet audience, to the children that will forget their particular difficulties, your dollars are working, literally to make more people happy. We don't do this stuff to get rich quick. We don't perform to live a charmed, starving artist's life. We do it because we love it, we believe in its power, and we want to make a difference. Please join us as we do just that.

Risks & Challenges
Building an entire art scene from scratch is no easy feat. It will take many, many years to reach the vision I and our team see for ourselves. A simple class in DC may be our starting point, but when we get home, we have to hit the ground running! 

Fortunately, we already have vendors, performance spaces, clowns, and students lined up. The final pieces are man power for taking care of business needs, such as social networking, legal fees and other necessary expenses. With your donation, we WILL overcome those challenges.

Other Ways You Can Help
Just because you can't donate today, you CAN hit that share button! Let your friends know about us. Subscribe to us on youtube, follow us on facebook, twitter, and Insta! Visit us at foolfoundry.fun to keep up with all our important information, and silliness.
Facebook
Twitter 
Instagram

story:
Written by Toronto playwright Dainty Smith (Les Femmes Fatales: Women of Colour Burlesque Troupe, Aluna Theatre 2017 & Obsidian Theatre Playwright's Project recipient) and directed by Ravyn Wngz (ILL NANA/DiverseCity Dance Company) - Daughters of Lilith is the story of six complicated sisters who are bound together through blood, Blackness, femininity, the past and the present.

Featuring an all Black women cast, Daughters of Lilith premiered in June 2017 at Buddies in Bad Times Theatre as part of their Pride Programming to great acclaim. A remount is in the works for May 15 & 16, 2019 but we need YOUR help! Support this project by donating, sharing and / or buying a ticket.

Tickets are on sale now - $25 or PWYC: http://buddiesinbadtimes.com/event/daughters-of...

 

What You Are Funding

Bring the Daughters of Lilith project to the stage for two workshop performances! 

Funds raised from this campaign will go towards set design, costume design, rehearsals, and critical funding for cast and crew to bring this important story to stage. This is an entirely independent, grassroots production. When you donate, you are supporting local artists, creators, and theater patrons who are committed to bringing cutting edge, Black theater to the stage.

 

Our Rewards

We have a series of incredible rewards from local artisans and small businesses for you to choose from, or you can just donate out of the goodness of your heart! 

If you do not want to purchase a reward, you can make a custom donation by clicking the "BACK IT" button above! Every little bit counts, and we sincerely appreciate your support no matter the amount. 

Indiegogo rewards generously donated by:

- Delicia's Delights 
- Esther De Ville
- Gigi's House of Frills
- Les Femmes Fatales: WOC Burlesque Troup
- Toronto Burlesque Festival
- Wolf Crown & Alchemy
- Zyra Lee Vanity

Make a contribution! Any amount helps. If you aren't able to donate any funds, we would love if you could share the campaign on your social media platforms and/or via email.

Tell people why you’re excited about Daughters of Lilith and invite them to be part of this incredible world.

RSVP on the Facebook event page: https://www.facebook.com/events/599401903875462/

Follow our cast on Instagram:

www.instagram.com/daintysmith
www.instagram.com/ravynwngz
www.instagram.com/pureivorydotca
www.instagram.com/mahlikah_aweri

Hope to see you at the show :)
