story:
Short Summary

We are bakubakubaku, also know as the Dream Eaters Performance Collective, a trio of performers who met in New York City, and have been creating experimental immersive puppetry performances together since 2014. Library of the Dreamless will be the third in a trio of experiments exploring the world of dreaming through the folklore of the Baku, a creature said to devour your dreams. 

We have been invited to perform Library of the Dreamless at the Prague Quadrennial as part of its PQ:Studio programming this summer, which is a great honor and an opportunity for us to share this new work. Unfortunately, the invitation does not come with any monetary support for travel. As a non-profit group, we are relying on fundraising, donations, and our own funds to make travel for this performance possible. Anything you are able to offer will help make this dream opportunity a reality.

What We Need & What You Get

We are raising funds to help cover the flights and lodging in Prague for our three members for the duration of the 2019 Prague Quadrennial. 

For those of you who are able to offer a donation, we have a number of fun, unique perks created by the members of our collective that you can choose from. They reflect the themes of our piece, The Library of the Dreamless, and include opportunities to have original artwork created for you around the theme of dreaming. Please check out what is on offer!

Even if we don't reach our goal amount, anything we are able to collect will help us offset the costs of the trip and allow us to continue to develop new projects. Anything collected above our goal will be put toward improving the performance and further opportunities to develop and stage additional performances.

The Impact

bakubakubaku seeks to create experimental, immersive performances that provide a shared dream experience for the audience members. To whom do our dreams belong? Who are we without our dreams? We seek to explore our shared humanity through the universal landscapes of dreaming. Your support will allow us to continue these experiments and explorations, giving us and our audiences the opportunity to share in art and in expressions of dreaming.

We are all increasingly relying on a panoply of apps and devices to help regulate and improve our health and wellbeing every day. In order for these apps to work, we have to surrender a lot of our medical and physiological data that we may not even be conscious of ourselves. In Library of the Dreamless, we ask what happens when ‘care’ is overextended and slips into dependency. How much of our data, and how much of our agency, and perhaps even our humanity, do we surrender to get better?

Other Ways You Can Help

Anything you can offer is much appreciated, including non-monetary support, such as sharing the campaign with others and reaching out in support of our work. Thank you so much for checking us out!

Production Details

There has been a crisis of dreaming...In a climate of pervasive fear and perpetual uncertainty, sleepers have been seized by recurrent nightmares. Desperate and anxious, the restless sleepers resorted to the iBaku, a device named after the mythological dream-eater that feeds upon nightmares. At first, they were pacified when they found relief as they yielded their nightmares to the advanced technology of the iBaku. But soon, they grew dependent on the device, feeding it their dreams and even their hopes. Now, these sleepers dwell in the artificial haze of dreamless stupor, hovering between contentment and despair. 

All that is left is the Library of the Dreamless, a repository pieced together from the fragments of dreams that were salvaged from the iBaku. Some sleepers have chosen to make their way to these ruins in hope of finding new ways to dream again, even if they must risk living their nightmares. 

Library of the Dreamless is an atmospheric, immersive performance, animated by puppetry. It is the third iteration in a series of intimate dream performance experiments exploring the mythology of the dream-eating Baku of Japanese folklore, with puppetry and an immersive environment. In this installment, created specifically for the Prague Quadrennial PQ:Studio, audiences are invited to experience the show in small groups of 15, as they inhabit the role of sleepers navigating the surreal landscapes of the Library of the Dreamless. The performance is a response to the collection of personal data and the role the tech community currently plays in that collection. 

The mythological Baku is a creature from Japanese folklore that consumes nightmares. When someone has experienced a nightmare, the Baku is summoned by calling out its name three times. However, over-dependence on the Baku may also lead to it devouring the individual’s hopes and desires. In the Library of the Dreamless, the Baku is now incarnated as a device-based app, where the excessive dependence on it has led to the point where people have forgotten how to dream and even hope. The apps are effective not only because of the technology but because of the design of its social interface, built to cultivate and manipulate that very dependence. There is a quasi-sentience endowed upon the Baku that is reminiscent of the social robots that we are familiar with today.

Performance Details

PQ Studio: Festival, Prague 13 & 14 June 2019

At the invitation of the Prague Quadrennial Studio Festival (PQ Studio), members of the bakubakubaku collective will be staging an intimate performance-installation animated by puppetry, in which audiences become sleepers navigating the uncanny world of the iBaku. Each performance is for a maximum of 15 people, and will take place in the Řetízek Studio (located in DAMU, the Theatre Faculty of The Academy of Performing Arts in Prague). There will be three shows presented over two days.

story:
About The Dream Factory

The Dream Factory: The 60 Most Fascinating People is the first full-length immersive and interactive experience from the upcoming company, Silver Dream Projects. The show has been created through a collaborative devised process by students of the SUNY Purchase College Theatre & Performance program as part of several senior projects. This production is made up of two major shows: Femme Fatale and The 60 Most Fascinating People.

            Femme Fatale finished its premiere at The Dixon Place in May of 2018. Vulva, one of Drellas rising stars, put on a hell of a performance art piece which was preceded and followed by immersive and interactive pre and post shows featuring some of the other major Superstars including Taxine, the Duchess, Whips and IV, just to name a few. As does everything in the Drellas Factory, drama erupted when it was discovered that Gerard, Drellas right hand man, would be leaving the factory.

            The 60 Most Fascinating People, set for April 17th – April 20th 2019, will be the grand finale to the saga. It will be performed in the Purchase College Dance Theatre Lab.  Drella will be throwing a huge party to announce and celebrate his newest set of Superstars, an astounding 60 of them, and one will be crowned the single most fascinating person. This final installment will push the Superstars to their breaking points as some will risk it all in order to be Drellas favorite.

Check out our website: www.thesilverdreamfactory.com/home/ 

About Silver Dream Projects

            Silver Dream Projects (S.D.P) was founded in 2017 by Andrew Wehnke and currently is comprised of over 20 Purchase College students from varying majors including Theatre & Performance, Dance, Film, Arts Management, Visual Arts, and Studio Production.

            S.D.P. is devoted to creating cutting edge Mixed Reality Performance, specializing in Immersive, Environmental, Transmedia, and Multimedia performance existing in the realm of Nostalgia.

           As S.D.P. is strongly influenced by the Pop Art Movement of the 1960’s, we consider ourselves pioneers of Pop Theater, a new experiential look at theater as it relates to Pop Culture and Pop Art.

Your Contribution

            The majority of our costs are found in the set design. We will be extensively redesigning 3 – 5 rooms, one of which is a 65’ x 55’ black box theatre, and 2 hallways. Approximately $3500 of the budget will be allocated to the set design, $1000 will be used for extensive costume design, and $500 will be set aside for marketing materials and purposes including merchandising. Aside from money we will also be happy to take noncash donations if you think you have something that will act as a great set piece or prop.

            We have a list of great perks with some exceptional rewards including interviews with the creative team, and special merchandise opportunities so be sure to check those out and see if your contribution matches any of the rewards.

            Finally, your contribution is going to help breathe new life into theatre. We at S.D.P. firmly believe that immersive and interactive experiences such as ours is where the world of theatre is heading. We see this with other great shows such as Sleep No More as well as Then She Fell. You can help us achieve the same level of success.

Have any questions or a noncash donation? Email us at SilverDreamProjects@Gmail.com with the subject line DONATION INQUIRY

story:
Short Summary

In a working class town in the UK, five creatives struggle to make a living out of their chosen careers as poverty, exclusivity and lack of opportunity continues to hold them back. Forced to sign on at Universal Credit, the group find it difficult to stay hopeful that things will change as the system that is meant to help them only pushes them further down the drain.

Throughout the summer of 2018, against a backdrop of scorching heat and the World Cup, the five friends battle societal and financial hurdles as they try to find ways to get the same opportunities as everyone else.

This play has been born of my own experiences as well as those of friends, family and former colleagues; experiences of being working class, of living in culturally impoverished towns, of the soul-crushing experiences of being on Universal Credit, the treatment and judgement of being unemployed, the struggle to find work, any work, the lack of help and lack of encouragement from both society and the government. 

However, as stated, one of the themes of the play is the lack of opportunities for working class creatives, especially those over the age of 26, to get into the industry. Therefore, my intent is, from this play, to start a theatre company where other work can be produced, allowing opportunities for all working class creatives, with the hope that, if one person, one company, can't solve the problem entirely, it can at least make a dent in it. 

Where the Funding Goes

It takes a lot to bring a show together and so, to make this play happen, lots of things, both big and small, are needed. And for all of these things, we need funding. Even when keeping the budget as low as possible, there's some essential costs that just can't be avoided (and unfortunately, people don't accept Monopoly money. Believe me, I've tried). Therefore your contribution can help pay for the following things

  • Rehearsal spaces (essential for ensuring actors don't walk into tables or each other)
  • Theatre space (so we have somewhere to actually put on the show that isn't in our own heads)
  • Photography (Because as beautiful as our cast selfies inevitably are...they don't really have that professional trust-in-our-performance vibe)
  • Props (because we don't want to be miming typing on a laptop. That could get weird)
  • Costumes (As naked actors makes for a very different kind of show)
  • Flyers and posters (so people can know the show exists!)
  • Programs (so people can remember the show and can learn more about the people who made it happen. Also helps as proof the show wasn't imagined and actually happened)
  • Script printing (So our cast don't have to keep squinting at that phones for their lines in rehearsal. Also so they can doodle on scripts while pretending their taking important notes. We've all done it)

The play is working as a profit-share performance, meaning the greater profit we make, the more our hard working cast and crew will earn. Therefore, the more of these things listed above that can be paid with funding, the greater the profit-share will be, which means not only will our cast and crew have a happy pay day for their work, but it increases the likelihood of being able to do more shows in the future, and really get a theatre company going that has access for working classes to get into the arts. So your contribution can go a really, really long way! 

 

The Impact

As mentioned above, this play does come from personal experiences, both my own and that of friends, family and colleagues. I had, originally, believed these struggles to be unique to my own situation, but it was only when speaking with others, that I came to realise these experiences, theses frustrations and barriers, were shared across all industries, all areas of the working class. The increasing lack of work alongside the increasing lack of understanding of how difficult it is to find employment, the pressure everyone feels to give up on their careers simply because they're too poor to pursue it. 

I wanted to create something that exposed this, shared those stories, in an engaging  and entertaining way, and it was as I listened to people's stories, their stories of living below poverty lines, of struggling with their careers, the negative, debilitating experiences of being on Universal Credit, that this play started to develop. 

I come from a working class single parent family, I am working class, so is my Mother, so were my grandparents, great-grandparents, and I have been raised in a working class town, in the north, where there is much less culture and access to the arts than you find in other areas of the country. Where there is less money, there is less arts, and this not only deprives an audience of experiences, but it deprives the creatives living there of work. 

Therefore, I want this play to not just be about telling this story, but also about creating work for those very people it talks about. Job opportunities for everything from actors and directors to FOH and ASMs; my aim is, from this play, to create other productions, other opportunities, through a theatre company that will give work opportunities to the working classes, to help those without privilege or aid, those who are too old for the 16-26 program cut-offs, or live outside of the Greater London area location cut-off,  to get that first foot in the door. 

 

The Hurdle. 

The greatest hurdle for this project is....money. The very thing this play is about, lack of funding, lack of access, lack of help, are the very same hurdles we face in making this play happen. Everything costs, and even the smallest things do build up over the course of production, and,  as explored in the play, being working class, having no personal finances to fall back on, so often ideas never come to fruition, not because the passion isn't there, but because the money isn't. 

I want to be able to use this play as a launchpad for starting a theatre company, a company that specialises in giving opportunities to creatives from the working class, especially women, as it is even harder for working class women than working class men, to find work in these industries: there are fewer female roles, fewer opportunities for female directors, fewer chances taken on female writers. 

Through this play, and through the eventual company it will be attached to, I want to help tackle these problems, to start putting a dent in the issues, but that can't begin if we don't have the money to get it rolling. All other hurdles can be overcome by determination, passion, talent, collaboration, an entire team...but no amount of sheer will can make money appear where it doesn't exist. 

The biggest hurdle is the funding, but the great news is that that is exactly when you can help! 

Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you can't make a donation right now, you can always help by spreading the word. Please share this link on all social media platforms, use the sharing tools available on Indiegogo itself, tell people in person. Please, just help get the word out and help us reach our goal!
story_txt:
Short Summary
In a working class town in the UK, five creatives struggle to make a living out of their chosen careers as poverty, exclusivity and lack of opportunity continues to hold them back. Forced to sign on at Universal Credit, the group find it difficult to stay hopeful that things will change as the system that is meant to help them only pushes them further down the drain.
Throughout the summer of 2018, against a backdrop of scorching heat and the World Cup, the five friends battle societal and financial hurdles as they try to find ways to get the same opportunities as everyone else.
This play has been born of my own experiences as well as those of friends, family and former colleagues; experiences of being working class, of living in culturally impoverished towns, of the soul-crushing experiences of being on Universal Credit, the treatment and judgement of being unemployed, the struggle to find work, any work, the lack of help and lack of encouragement from both society and the government. 
However, as stated, one of the themes of the play is the lack of opportunities for working class creatives, especially those over the age of 26, to get into the industry. Therefore, my intent is, from this play, to start a theatre company where other work can be produced, allowing opportunities for all working class creatives, with the hope that, if one person, one company, can't solve the problem entirely, it can at least make a dent in it. 

Where the Funding Goes
It takes a lot to bring a show together and so, to make this play happen, lots of things, both big and small, are needed. And for all of these things, we need funding. Even when keeping the budget as low as possible, there's some essential costs that just can't be avoided (and unfortunately, people don't accept Monopoly money. Believe me, I've tried). Therefore your contribution can help pay for the following things

Rehearsal spaces (essential for ensuring actors don't walk into tables or each other)
Theatre space (so we have somewhere to actually put on the show that isn't in our own heads)
Photography (Because as beautiful as our cast selfies inevitably are...they don't really have that professional trust-in-our-performance vibe)
Props (because we don't want to be miming typing on a laptop. That could get weird)
Costumes (As naked actors makes for a very different kind of show)
Flyers and posters (so people can know the show exists!)
Programs (so people can remember the show and can learn more about the people who made it happen. Also helps as proof the show wasn't imagined and actually happened)
Script printing (So our cast don't have to keep squinting at that phones for their lines in rehearsal. Also so they can doodle on scripts while pretending their taking important notes. We've all done it)

The play is working as a profit-share performance, meaning the greater profit we make, the more our hard working cast and crew will earn. Therefore, the more of these things listed above that can be paid with funding, the greater the profit-share will be, which means not only will our cast and crew have a happy pay day for their work, but it increases the likelihood of being able to do more shows in the future, and really get a theatre company going that has access for working classes to get into the arts. So your contribution can go a really, really long way! 
 

The Impact
As mentioned above, this play does come from personal experiences, both my own and that of friends, family and colleagues. I had, originally, believed these struggles to be unique to my own situation, but it was only when speaking with others, that I came to realise these experiences, theses frustrations and barriers, were shared across all industries, all areas of the working class. The increasing lack of work alongside the increasing lack of understanding of how difficult it is to find employment, the pressure everyone feels to give up on their careers simply because they're too poor to pursue it. 
I wanted to create something that exposed this, shared those stories, in an engaging  and entertaining way, and it was as I listened to people's stories, their stories of living below poverty lines, of struggling with their careers, the negative, debilitating experiences of being on Universal Credit, that this play started to develop. 
I come from a working class single parent family, I am working class, so is my Mother, so were my grandparents, great-grandparents, and I have been raised in a working class town, in the north, where there is much less culture and access to the arts than you find in other areas of the country. Where there is less money, there is less arts, and this not only deprives an audience of experiences, but it deprives the creatives living there of work. 
Therefore, I want this play to not just be about telling this story, but also about creating work for those very people it talks about. Job opportunities for everything from actors and directors to FOH and ASMs; my aim is, from this play, to create other productions, other opportunities, through a theatre company that will give work opportunities to the working classes, to help those without privilege or aid, those who are too old for the 16-26 program cut-offs, or live outside of the Greater London area location cut-off,  to get that first foot in the door. 
 

The Hurdle. 
The greatest hurdle for this project is....money. The very thing this play is about, lack of funding, lack of access, lack of help, are the very same hurdles we face in making this play happen. Everything costs, and even the smallest things do build up over the course of production, and,  as explored in the play, being working class, having no personal finances to fall back on, so often ideas never come to fruition, not because the passion isn't there, but because the money isn't. 
I want to be able to use this play as a launchpad for starting a theatre company, a company that specialises in giving opportunities to creatives from the working class, especially women, as it is even harder for working class women than working class men, to find work in these industries: there are fewer female roles, fewer opportunities for female directors, fewer chances taken on female writers. 
Through this play, and through the eventual company it will be attached to, I want to help tackle these problems, to start putting a dent in the issues, but that can't begin if we don't have the money to get it rolling. All other hurdles can be overcome by determination, passion, talent, collaboration, an entire team...but no amount of sheer will can make money appear where it doesn't exist. 
The biggest hurdle is the funding, but the great news is that that is exactly when you can help! 

Other Ways You Can Help
Even if you can't make a donation right now, you can always help by spreading the word. Please share this link on all social media platforms, use the sharing tools available on Indiegogo itself, tell people in person. Please, just help get the word out and help us reach our goal!

story:
That's right, we've saved an amazing set from the scrap yard and we'll be giving it a new lease of life to launch a fantastic new immersive show and we want you along for the ride!

We are a group of event & immersive theatre specialists who've worked together for over a decade, all over the world and we've decided to start a new, independent venture. 

Our team includes Ed Borgnis, a hugely experienced Technical Director/Producer and Craig Wilkinson, who runs a talent agency (and is an actor himself - see the videos!) We regularly work with some of the finest Interior Designers, Lighting and Sound Designers, Script Developers and Food and Beverage Consultants to bring projects to a variety of audiences.

We've been fortunate enough to work on some amazing productions and we've got a wealth of experience to ensure this will be an unforgettable experience.

 

You! If you're reading this far, its likely piqued your interest.... So jump on board the train for an adventure you will never forget. The show will be open to 18+ Adults at first, with a view to inviting younger audiences down the line for future productions.  

 

We're investing our own time and money in the project, which has included sourcing a venue and creating a new show. We're crowdfunding to help us pre-sell tickets to breath a new lease of life into this spectacular set. 

The investment will enable the creative development of the project and form part of our renovation budget so we can refresh the set and interiors, build our internal necessities (Kitchen, Bar, Bathrooms) and secure the necessary licenses so we can get the train back on the tracks....

 

 

  • Advance Booking - 3 Course Meal & Immersive Theatre Show - reduced price - £52 
  • First Class - AB plus glass of champagne on arrival, Photo with Cast - £65
  • Opening Night - Ticket for our Opening Night with suprise (Limited Availability) - £90
  • Name a Character in the show - £120 (Limited chance)

 

What if we don't hit our funding goals?

  • Tickets will be put on sale to the general public as part of a wider marketing campaign, during which time we'll be drawing on other sources of investment to the project. 
  • If we are unable to put the show on for any reason, we would of course refund any tickets sold.

 

Risks & Challenges

There are obviously risks with any project. Ours is financial. Yours is not liking our show! Rent in London isn't cheap and as a purely independent project we have already invested to get where we are today. Your investment at this stage is risk free - this is simply a pre-sell on tickets and marketing for us to enable us to begin spreading the word.

We have worked with this set and other immersive experiences all over the world, both together and independently. We are perfectly placed to bring this to life. Our largest hurdle is the upfront cost to preparing the venue which is why we are here.

 

Even if you cannot lend your support financially please do help us spread the word by sharing our story on social media. We will keep you up to date with our journey through our website.

@themurderexpress

 @murder_express

  @theMurd3rExpress

 

FAQ'S

Where will this be?

A location in East London with good transport links; road, Overground and Underground.

When will it open?

All being well we’re looking to open at the end of May this year (2018)

How long are you going to be open for?

A limited time, but we’ll run through the Summer, closing in September for a brand new show to open

What’s the food going to be?

We’re currently working with a top class chef to bring you a delicious 3 course menu, enjoyed during the show.

How interactive is it?

It’s an immersive show, so we’ll be looking to get you, the audience, involved from the moment you arrive…. But if you’re shy, don’t worry we’d never make you do anything you weren’t happy to do

Can I take photos and post to social media?

Of course. We only ask that you keep the secrets of the show to yourself so everyone can enjoy it!

Anything else?

Erm, yes. This?

story:
Meet the Artist!

My name is Nisha Hope. I was born on the beautiful Caribbean island,St. Vincent and the Grenadines. I have over 15 years experience in theatre and I am currently in the final semester of my undergraduate studies. Contributions from this campaign will enable the successful staging of a play that I will pen and direct, in partial fulfillment of my BFA in Creative Arts degree. 

It's important for me to mount this play because our country has been seeing an increase in the homicide rate within the last 5 years. I've not only lost friends to the upsurge of violence but I myself was a victim of a robbery at my own home.

While I feel persons are generally sensitised about the crime situation, there is a need for more research to figure out what are the enablers of homicides while finding effective ways to re-humanize a society that was once peaceful and a tourist attraction.  

I really hope to be the voice that allows for deeper discussion and I trust my play will speak to the humanity of its viewers.

 

What's Needed & What You Get

I need to raise $3000.00 to be able to stage this play that offers its viewers value. All of the monies raised will go towards preparing for the play during the 6 week rehearsal process, creating the set design, purchasing props, costumes and paying cast and crew. 

Contributors will be acknowledged in the playbill for making this play a success and those persons living in Barbados will receive half off on the entrance fee on Opening Night. 

The Impact

As a student of The University of the West Indies, I have a captive audience. The UWI boasts a student population of over 7000 that spans across 40 countries globally through our exchange program. It also offers an opportunity to Vincentian students to start the discussion and prepare them for the reality upon returning to the home they call Hairouna. 

Risks & Challenges

One of the biggest obstacles in achieving my goal may be human resources and networking as I am mounting the play in Barbados as a foreign student and not familiar with local artists. However, I have started fairly early to cast and I believe this hurdle will be a small one. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Maybe you like my idea but cannot contribute right now. You still can help.

Here's how:

  • Get the word out and make some noise about my campaign by sharing with friends, family or organisations who are passionate about my cause.
  • Use the Indiegogo share tools to spread the word!

Thanks for your time and assistance.

story:
Who are we?

Hello! I’m Jenny Rocha, choreographer and founder of Rocha Dance Theater. I’m also a performer, costume designer and teaching artist and I’m based in Brooklyn, NY. For my current repertoire, Battledress, I’m working with longtime company members, Jillian Hollis and Courtney Drasner, as well as composer and husband, Joseph Rivas. We have all been involved in the creative process for Battledress since its first commission in 2013 by The Boston Center for the Arts. Since then, the work has been performed at The Philadelphia Museum of Art, Roger Williams University, New Bedford Art Museum, MANA Contemporary and Baryshnikov Arts Center.

What’s Next?

Battledress: The Azores Premiere & Workshop Series

Rocha Dance Theater will be participating in their first international tour to Azores, Portugal this September. Myself, Jillian Hollis and Courtney Drasner will perform a trio version of the repertoire at a local theater Teatro Ribeiragrandense. My husband, Joe Rivas, who composed the music for Battledress, will also attend, documenting the workshop and performance.

With the support of a grant from the US Embassy in Lisbon, we were able to incorporate a crucial arts education component to this project: Prior to the performance, I will lead a 5 day workshop for students ages 13-18, teaching a modern technique class and teaching a section of Battledress. At the end of the week, the students will have an opportunity to perform the piece as part of our show. 

What are we asking?

While the grant from The US Embassy in Lisbon covers airfare and the workshops that I’m leading, the company still needs to raise an additional $5,000 to make this project happen. I hope that you will consider a donation towards RDT’s first international workshop and performance! Your support is greatly appreciated, and will be used to cultivate a cultural exchange in dance, support equitable artists fees, and promote access to dance education.

Perks!

In addition to supporting all of the artists and communities served, you will also receive some amazing perks! Take a peek and learn some Portuguese while you're at it!

Funds will go towards the Azores tour and the company whether or not the goal is reached.

Description of work

Battledress challenges preconceptions of the female by juxtaposing stereotypical femininity with powerful figures clad in protective armour. At times, the women are held captive in unwanted cages; later, they are stern, statuesque, performing gestures of authority. The performance depicts an internal battle as its characters attempt to deconstruct their assigned roles, presenting an alternate reality that is at once dream-like and relatable.

Bios

Jenny Rocha is a choreographer, dancer, costume designer and Artistic Director of Rocha Dance Theater since 2001. She is also the Director of The Painted Ladies, a cabaret group that was admitted into the Burlesque Hall of Fame in Las Vegas. A first generation Portuguese-American from New Bedford, Massachusetts, Rocha attended Roger Williams University for Dance and Performance, where she graduated with an Outstanding Achievement in Dance Award. She then moved to New York City, where Jenny served as a member of Sean Curran Company, Heidi Latsky Dance, Kelli Wicke Davis and other choreographers for 12 collective years.  Her choreography has been presented by esteemed venues such as The Philadelphia Museum of Art, The Boston Center for the Arts, Danspace Project, La MaMa, Galapagos Art Space, and more. Rocha has received awards and residencies including The Puffin Foundation grant, Galapagos Art Space Residency from 2008-2014, Armitage Gone! Dance/MANA Contemporary Space Residency and CUNY Dance Initiative in 2015 and 2018. The US Embassy in Lisbon awarded her an Innovation Grant to perform her work Battledress in Azores, Portugal, as well as host educational workshops in September of 2018.  Rocha’s choreography has received critical acclaim from The New York Times, The Boston Globe, and The Village Voice, among others. As a teaching artist, she has taught dance at universities and colleges nationwide, including Roger Williams University, Connecticut College, West Virginia University, and Lehman College. Rocha currently teaches choreography at the Brooklyn Academy of Music (since 2012) and serves on the guest faculty of Mark Morris Dance Center. Most recently, she received the CUNY Dance Initiative 2018-19 for a residency at John Jay College and performance at their Gerald Lynch Theater in 2019.

Courtney Drasner grew up in Minnesota and later received her BFA in dance from NYU. Since graduating, she has been fortunate enough to perform with Donnell Oakley, Gina Gibney, Max Stone, Jana Hicks, the median movement, Janessa Clark, Jenni Hong, Erica Essner, and Jordana Toback, among others. She is thrilled to be a part of Battledress and Rocha Dance Theater.

Jillian Hollis was born and raised in Syracuse NY. She began dancing at a very young age and graduated from Point Park University with a BA in dance. Jillian is a long time company member and rehearsal director for Heidi Latsky Dance. She has taught and set work for the company at universities across the United States and abroad. Jillian has also danced for Take Dance, Carrie Ahern Dance, Joseph Mills, Heather Harrington, and Jenny’s award winning group, The Painted Ladies. Jillian has been dancing with Rocha Dance Theater since 2004 and is thrilled to be a part of “Battledress” in the Azores!

Joseph Rivas is the founder of Beat Instinct Music. His work includes original production, remixing, mixing, mastering, sound design, vocal and instrument tracking and sound for film and dance. Joseph also teaches music production and mixing, offering lessons in studio setup, DAW work flow, advanced beat programming and mastering techniques. Rivas is certified Pro Tools Operator and is fluent in all major digital audio workstations. Joe works in genres that include hiphop, electronic, RnB, orchestral, bass music and pop. He is a 5 time Indaba Music contest winner including two grand prizes for his original productions in the Com Truise (ghostly international) sample session at Converse Rubber Tracks and the IHEARTCOMIX sample session featuring Franki Chan, Heems, Gavin Turek, Pictureplane and Mark Redito fka Spazzkid. Joe also mixes feature length documentaries and short films. Beatinstinct.com

About The Azores!

The Azores is one of two autonomous regions of Portugal. It is an archipelago composed of nine volcanic islands in the North Atlantic Ocean about 850 miles west of continental Portugal. There are nine major Azorean islands and an islet cluster, in three main groups. These are Flores and Corvo, to the west; Graciosa. Terceira, Sao Jorge, Pico and Faial in the center; and Sao Miguel, Santa Maria to the east.  The islands are characterized by dramatic landscapes, fishing villages, green pastures and hedgerows of blue hydrangeas. São Miguel, the largest, has lake-filled calderas (volcanic craters), natural hot springs and the Gorreana Tea Plantation.

My family immigrated to Massachusetts in the early 1970’s. Here is an interesting article about how Portuguese immigrants came to New England: Click Here

Here is a map of its location in the middle of the Atlantic Ocean!

A first generation Portuguese-American from New Bedford, Massachusetts, Rocha attended Roger Williams University for Dance and Performance, where she graduated with an Outstanding Achievement in Dance Award. She then moved to New York City, where Jenny served as a member of Sean Curran Company, Heidi Latsky Dance, Kelli Wicke Davis and other choreographers for 12 collective years.  Her choreography has been presented by esteemed venues such as The Philadelphia Museum of Art, The Boston Center for the Arts, Danspace Project, La MaMa, Galapagos Art Space, and more. Rocha has received awards and residencies including The Puffin Foundation grant, Galapagos Art Space Residency from 2008-2014, Armitage Gone! Dance/MANA Contemporary Space Residency and CUNY Dance Initiative in 2015 and 2018. The US Embassy in Lisbon awarded her an Innovation Grant to perform her work Battledress in Azores, Portugal, as well as host educational workshops in September of 2018.  Rocha’s choreography has received critical acclaim from The New York Times, The Boston Globe, and The Village Voice, among others. As a teaching artist, she has taught dance at universities and colleges nationwide, including Roger Williams University, Connecticut College, West Virginia University, and Lehman College. Rocha currently teaches choreography at the Brooklyn Academy of Music (since 2012) and serves on the guest faculty of Mark Morris Dance Center. Most recently, she received the CUNY Dance Initiative 2018-19 for a residency at John Jay College and performance at their Gerald Lynch Theater in 2019.
Courtney Drasner grew up in Minnesota and later received her BFA in dance from NYU. Since graduating, she has been fortunate enough to perform with Donnell Oakley, Gina Gibney, Max Stone, Jana Hicks, the median movement, Janessa Clark, Jenni Hong, Erica Essner, and Jordana Toback, among others. She is thrilled to be a part of Battledress and Rocha Dance Theater.
Jillian Hollis was born and raised in Syracuse NY. She began dancing at a very young age and graduated from Point Park University with a BA in dance. Jillian is a long time company member and rehearsal director for Heidi Latsky Dance. She has taught and set work for the company at universities across the United States and abroad. Jillian has also danced for Take Dance, Carrie Ahern Dance, Joseph Mills, Heather Harrington, and Jenny’s award winning group, The Painted Ladies. Jillian has been dancing with Rocha Dance Theater since 2004 and is thrilled to be a part of “Battledress” in the Azores!
Joseph Rivas is the founder of Beat Instinct Music. His work includes original production, remixing, mixing, mastering, sound design, vocal and instrument tracking and sound for film and dance. Joseph also teaches music production and mixing, offering lessons in studio setup, DAW work flow, advanced beat programming and mastering techniques. Rivas is certified Pro Tools Operator and is fluent in all major digital audio workstations. Joe works in genres that include hiphop, electronic, RnB, orchestral, bass music and pop. He is a 5 time Indaba Music contest winner including two grand prizes for his original productions in the Com Truise (ghostly international) sample session at Converse Rubber Tracks and the IHEARTCOMIX sample session featuring Franki Chan, Heems, Gavin Turek, Pictureplane and Mark Redito fka Spazzkid. Joe also mixes feature length documentaries and short films. Beatinstinct.com
About The Azores!
The Azores is one of two autonomous regions of Portugal. It is an archipelago composed of nine volcanic islands in the North Atlantic Ocean about 850 miles west of continental Portugal. There are nine major Azorean islands and an islet cluster, in three main groups. These are Flores and Corvo, to the west; Graciosa. Terceira, Sao Jorge, Pico and Faial in the center; and Sao Miguel, Santa Maria to the east.  The islands are characterized by dramatic landscapes, fishing villages, green pastures and hedgerows of blue hydrangeas. São Miguel, the largest, has lake-filled calderas (volcanic craters), natural hot springs and the Gorreana Tea Plantation.
My family immigrated to Massachusetts in the early 1970’s. Here is an interesting article about how Portuguese immigrants came to New England: Click Here
Here is a map of its location in the middle of the Atlantic Ocean!

story:
A Folyügyről

Két évvel ezelőtt egy szép őszi napon megcsörrent a telefonom, és egy ismeretlen cég ismeretlenen alkalmazottja megkért, azonosítsam magam.

Azt, hogy miért hívott többszöri kérésemre sem közölte, egyre csak a személyes adataim iránt érdeklődött. Természetesen semmit nem mondtam el Neki, és az abszurd drámába illő beszélgetést posztoltam a Facebook falamra.

A telefonhívások ez után rendszeressé váltak és egyre furcsábbak, röhejesebbek lettek, így kénytelen voltam minduntalan posztolni azokat. A hívások két év után nem rég maradtak abba. Ez alatt a két év alatt nem csak telefonbeszélgetéseket, hanem velem megesett városi sztorikat, párbeszédeket is írogattam.

A posztok egyre népszerűbbek lettek, egyre többen követték a történeteket, köztük kortárs írók, színészek, rendezők is, akik meggyőztek: írjak darabot a párbeszédekből. A szövegkönyv el is készült, az utolsó simítások vannak már csak hátra, az RS9 Színház pedig bevállalta, hogy áprilisban műsorra tűzi a darabot, melyet kis költségvetéssel már öt teltházas előadás árából meg is tudunk valósítani.

Segíts, hogy megvalósulhasson az előadás! Röhögjünk együtt 2017 áprilisában!

Braun Barna vagyok, az ELTE BTK Irodalom és kultúratudomány mesterszakán végeztem, ezzel párhuzamosan kezdtem el az RS9 Színházban dolgozni mint PR-os és kommunikációs referens, az elmúlt két évben rengeteget tanultam itt a színházszakmáról, amely azóta nem csak a munkám, hanem szenvedélyem lett.

Előtte hasonló pozícióban a József Attila Kör irodalmi egyesületnél dolgoztam, az én ötletem alapján valósult meg pl. 2014-ben a népszerű "búspoéták" pólócsalád. 10 éve alapítottam a FÉLonline.hu nevű független kulturális-művészeti folyóiratot, melynek estjeit magam szervezem a színházi esemény-menedzsment feladatok mellett.

Dolgoztam már szabadúszó újságíróként, írtam konferencia előadást, tanulmányt, sőt még verseket is, ez lesz az első drámám. 

Csáki Rita kollégám, barátom az RS9 Színház lelke. Amit a színházcsinálásról tudok, azt tőle tanultam. Kiváló rendező, a háta mögött sok sikeres, népszerű RS9-es darabbal. Ő rendezte pl. a legendás Mennyország című előadást. Jelenleg futó darabja az Érzéki matematika, november 11-én pedig szintén egy első drámás szerző művét mutatja be: A Tizenegyes kórterem címmel.

Amikor először felmerült, hogy színdarab készüljön a Folyóügyből, nem volt számomra kérdés, hogy Őt kérjem fel a rendezésre.

Társadalmi üzenet

2015 nyarán a 24.hu-n riport készült az abszurd telefonbeszélgetésekről. A cikkben megszólaló ügyvéd megalapozta a Folyóügy társadalmi üzenetét, hiszen 

"Dr. Székely Andrea, ügyvéd szerint, amit a követeléskezelő cég művel, az törvénytelen. Szimpla zaklatás, de lehetséges, hogy eddig bevált nekik a módszer. A tények: a követeléskezelő cég tényleg nem beszélhet meg egy ismeretlennel egy ügyet: azonosítaniuk kell az ügyfelet. Braun Barna viszont a lehető leghelyesebben jár el, amikor nem adja ki akárkinek a személyes adatait, hiszen azokkal bárki visszaélhet."

A sztorikra többen úgy reagáltak: mióta olvasták az párbeszédeket és a cikket, bátrabban mondanak nemet a zaklató telefonokra, s ha már csak egy néző is tudni fogja, hogyan kell reagálni egy ilyen helyzetben megéri elkészíteni a darabot. 

Mire fordítjuk a támogatásokat? Céljaink. 

Célok: 

A kampány során elsősorban a bemutató és az első öt előadás személyi költségeire gyűjtünk (ezért a kis költségvetés), hogy ki tudjuk fizetni a színészeket, a rendezőt, és a technikai személyzetet.  Négy színésszel, és a rendezővel számolva a próbafolyamatra 5 x 375 dollárt szeretnénk költeni, míg a darab technikai megvalósulására 200 dollárt. Természetesen nem csak próbapénzt, hanem előadásonként is szeretnénk fizetni a stábnak, 5 x 40 dollárt, plusz a technikai személyzetnek 25 dollárt. Így az előadás megvalósulásának minimális, de elégséges költségvetése $3200.

Mérföldkövek:

Ha elérjük az alapcélt, folytatjuk a kampány, hogy a lehető legjobb minőségű előadást láthassátok áprilisban az RS9 Színházban. Ehhez szükségünk van a látványosabb díszlethez, jelmezhez, és kelléktárhoz szükséges forrásokra.

  1. MÉRFÖLDKŐ: KELLÉKEK – ~$375 
    A darabban rengeteg karakter jelenik majd meg a színpadon, melyeknek szeretnénk hiteles, jó minőségű kellékekkel felruházni.
     
  2. MÉRFÖLDKŐ: JELMEZ – $1700 
    Ha elérjük az első mérföldkövet szeretnénk a karakterek hiteles jelmezéhez gyűjteni a forrást, ehhez további $1700-ra lesz szükségünk, melyből $1300 a jelmeztervező díja, és $400 anyagköltség.
     
  3. MÉRFÖLDKŐ: DÍSZLET - $2500
    Nem csak karakterből lesz sok a színpadon, de helyszínből is, ha volna lehetőségünk, szívesen bevonnánk a darab megvalósításába olyan különleges (és drága) színpadi technikát, melyeket jól lehet kis színpadon még nem is alkalmaztak ezelőtt. Ennek megvalósítására $2500-ra lesz szükségünk, melyből $1300 munkadíj és $1200 anyagköltség.

Mit kapsz cserébe?

2$-ért már ajándék matrica jár.

4$-ért ezen felül egy A3-as plakátot is kapsz. 

 

7$-ért egy ajándék tollat is kapsz.

10$-os támogatásért cserébe ezeken túl a tiéd egy Folyóügy bögre is! 

12$-os támogatásért cserébe már egyedi, sorszámmal ellátott színházjegyet kapsz, amit az általad választott előadás időpontján tudsz majd beváltani az RS9 Színházban. (a megjelölt dátum csak minta!)

20$-ért PÁROS belépőt kapsz.

$25-ért az ELSŐ ELŐADÁSON AZ ELSŐ SORBAN ÜLHETSZ majd ,vagy 

Választhatsz magadnak egyedi Folyóügyes pólót


$29-ért beleleshetsz a próbafolyamatba, véleményezheted a készülő darabot. Vendégünk vagy egy próba utáni sörözésre, ahol a véleményed is elmondhatod a készülő darabról. Sőt, ráadásként kapsz egy PÁROS BELÉPŐT, egy plakátot, egy matricát, digitális háttérképet és egy tollat is, amivel bármit aláírhatsz! KORLÁTOZOTT SZÁMBAN!

$45-ért A producerünk lehetsz! Gyere el a premier utáni bulira, miután PÁROS JEGYEDDEL megtekintetted az előadást! Ünnepelj az alkotókkal és vidd haza, a bögrét, a tollat és a plakátot.

$60 támogatásért vagy így vagy úgy belekerülsz a darabba + megkapsz mindent, ami egy producernek jár.

$150-ért A Folyóügy Executive producere lehetsz! VIGYÉL MINDENT: kapsz egy PÁROS belépőt a premierre, páros pólót, bögrét, tollat, plakátot, matricát. Gyere el egy próbára, beszélgess az alkotókkal, és legyél jelen a premier bulin!

Minden projektnek kell egy FŐTÁMOGATÓ. Ez a poszt csak rád vár! Támogasd a darab megvalósulását 450 dollárral! Természetesen mindent megkapsz, ami egy főtámogatónak kijár PÁROS belépőt a premierre, páros pólót, bögrét, tollat, névre szóló dedikált plakátot, matricát. Gyere el egy próbára, beszélgess az alkotókkal, és legyél jelen a premier bulin! (csak egy főtámogatónk lehet)

story:
We are The NOW Collective! 

A theatre company providing a collaborative environment for artists to develop and share new stories. 

This spring, we will be hosting two workshop productions at our favorite downtown theater space, Access Theater! Join us in experiencing the work of two up-and-coming playwrights in The NOW Collective community, Matthew McLachlan and Terilyn Elise Eisenhauer! 

Donate at least $10 and get 25% off a ticket to each production! That means if you give $10 now, you will a $10 discount when you come see both shows!

With these workshop productions,  we’re encouraging you to engage in conversation with our playwrights, actors, directors, and production team to see what a show in-process looks like.  

But before we continue, we’d like to thank YOU for your support throughout the years. With our reading series and our full fledged production of The Wild Parrots Of Campbell in December you’ve supported us throughout this packed season of productions and now, we’re just asking for you to help us with the final push of $5,000.

The NOW Collective was founded to not only give theater artists the opportunity to collaborate with a supportive, dynamic community, but to also raise back the curtain, see what happens behind the scenes, hear our audience’s voices, and include you in the conversation. Join us as we wrap up this season to bring you the consistent work The NOW Collective is known for!

We have chosen two shows to be part of the new NOW Workshop Series: The Murder Play with Jack & Melissa by Matthew McLachlan, and Lovelocked by Terilyn Elise Eisenhauer. Both shows have been previously developed in the NOW Reading Series and will be staged for the very first time in the NOW Workshop Series! But that’s not all… the team will be highlighting a specific design element that is inherent to successful storytelling of each play. We’re excited to be finishing our season strong with these two new plays!

The Murder Play with Jack & Melissa takes the audience to a cabin on a mountain during a rain storm. Melissa wakes up to find herself taped to a chair and in the company of a kind-hearted serial killer named Jack...and he just wants a friend. This comedy explores the outrageous things we do to not feel so lonely, and the outrageous people we do it with. This two-hander involves a lot of fake blood. Special FX with props and costumes will be the highlighted tech element for this show. The Murder Play with Jack & Melissa runs March 18-22!

Lovelocked tells the story of Killian and his pet rabbit living on the Ha'Penny Bridge in Dublin. One night, Patrick Foran, a local city councilman, offers to share his whiskey, and the story of Killian and Caoimhe unfolds. Where did she go? Why did she leave? And how long will Killian wait for her return? Lovelocked features a cast of three. The story plays with time and changing locations in an instant. The highlighted tech element for this show will be Lighting Design, which will help guide the audience through the story, and differentiate the multiple locations and realities. Lovelocked runs May 13-18!

Both shows will be in The Black Box at Access Theatre. 
 

What We Need

This is the final push for the remaining $5,000 to make TWO shows happen! 
Here's the breakdown:

Actor Fees: $1,000
Writer Fees: $200
Director Fees: $500
Murder Play Props/SFX Designer Fee: $200
Lovelocked Lighting Designer: $200
Master Electrician: $250
Design Team: $450
**Murder Play Props/SFX Budget: $1,000
Stage Management & ASM Fees: $800
*Murder Play Fight Director: $200
*Lovelocked Dialect Coach: $200
TOTAL: $5,000!

*In both productions, although the plays are still in progress, we’re asking our directors, actors, and entire design team to create a polished piece of theater. Each production has a little something extra that requires a special addition to the production team. For the actors safety, we will be hiring a Fight Director for The Murder Play with Jack & Melissa. Since Lovelocked is set in Ireland, a dialect coach helps our actors speech with the natural cadence and tones of an Irish accent!

**We don't want to give anything away, but Murder Play is going to be a messy 5 day run!


What You Get

By donating at least $10 you will get a personalized discount code for 25% off a ticket to BOTH shows and a special thanks in our program! If you come see both productions, you will get a $10 savings when you donate $10.

Note: There is no perk to “claim”. Every person that donates will receive a discount code! So, you may give more than $10 if you'd like! You will receive an email from us with your individualized discount code shortly after you make your donation. 

The Impact

As you know, The NOW Collective supports the in-process generation of new work. With your help, we create an environment for playwrights to develop their plays alongside a cast and creative team. And we love giving our community a behind-the-scenes aspect of theater making. But most of all, two playwrights get to have their plays produced.

 

Risks & Challenges

The NOW Collective makes indie theatre because we weren't seeing the kind of shows that our community is craving! There was a call for new work founded in collaboration, so we became a source. We dream big and take risks, that's why we've been so successful in the past. We introduced two new kinds of programming this season, our World Premiere Productions and our Workshop Series, which have given us three new plays in our 2019-2020 season. The first, the world premiere of The Wild Parrots of Campbell, was a huge success for everyone involved! The 16-performance run at The Cherry Lane Studio Theater got raving reviews from critics and audiences. The second, is our Workshop Series featuring The Murder Play with Jack and Melissa and Lovelocked. 

We just need that final $5,000 for the Workshop Series to be successful! That's why we are reaching out to you. We understand The NOW Collective community, close friends, and family just donated back in September. We are so thankful for that! We are reaching out in case there were others who didn't get to give before or people generous enough to donate again!
 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you believe in the work we are doing, please share this campaign!
Follow us on Instagram! Like our page on Facebook!
Visit our website and sign up for our newsletter!
You can also see the shows this spring!
story_txt:
We are The NOW Collective! 
A theatre company providing a collaborative environment for artists to develop and share new stories. 
This spring, we will be hosting two workshop productions at our favorite downtown theater space, Access Theater! Join us in experiencing the work of two up-and-coming playwrights in The NOW Collective community, Matthew McLachlan and Terilyn Elise Eisenhauer! 
Donate at least $10 and get 25% off a ticket to each production! That means if you give $10 now, you will a $10 discount when you come see both shows!
With these workshop productions,  we’re encouraging you to engage in conversation with our playwrights, actors, directors, and production team to see what a show in-process looks like.  
But before we continue, we’d like to thank YOU for your support throughout the years. With our reading series and our full fledged production of The Wild Parrots Of Campbell in December you’ve supported us throughout this packed season of productions and now, we’re just asking for you to help us with the final push of $5,000.
The NOW Collective was founded to not only give theater artists the opportunity to collaborate with a supportive, dynamic community, but to also raise back the curtain, see what happens behind the scenes, hear our audience’s voices, and include you in the conversation. Join us as we wrap up this season to bring you the consistent work The NOW Collective is known for!
We have chosen two shows to be part of the new NOW Workshop Series: The Murder Play with Jack & Melissa by Matthew McLachlan, and Lovelocked by Terilyn Elise Eisenhauer. Both shows have been previously developed in the NOW Reading Series and will be staged for the very first time in the NOW Workshop Series! But that’s not all… the team will be highlighting a specific design element that is inherent to successful storytelling of each play. We’re excited to be finishing our season strong with these two new plays!
The Murder Play with Jack & Melissa takes the audience to a cabin on a mountain during a rain storm. Melissa wakes up to find herself taped to a chair and in the company of a kind-hearted serial killer named Jack...and he just wants a friend. This comedy explores the outrageous things we do to not feel so lonely, and the outrageous people we do it with. This two-hander involves a lot of fake blood. Special FX with props and costumes will be the highlighted tech element for this show. The Murder Play with Jack & Melissa runs March 18-22!
Lovelocked tells the story of Killian and his pet rabbit living on the Ha'Penny Bridge in Dublin. One night, Patrick Foran, a local city councilman, offers to share his whiskey, and the story of Killian and Caoimhe unfolds. Where did she go? Why did she leave? And how long will Killian wait for her return? Lovelocked features a cast of three. The story plays with time and changing locations in an instant. The highlighted tech element for this show will be Lighting Design, which will help guide the audience through the story, and differentiate the multiple locations and realities. Lovelocked runs May 13-18!
Both shows will be in The Black Box at Access Theatre.  

What We Need
This is the final push for the remaining $5,000 to make TWO shows happen! Here's the breakdown:
Actor Fees: $1,000Writer Fees: $200Director Fees: $500Murder Play Props/SFX Designer Fee: $200Lovelocked Lighting Designer: $200Master Electrician: $250Design Team: $450**Murder Play Props/SFX Budget: $1,000Stage Management & ASM Fees: $800*Murder Play Fight Director: $200*Lovelocked Dialect Coach: $200TOTAL: $5,000!
*In both productions, although the plays are still in progress, we’re asking our directors, actors, and entire design team to create a polished piece of theater. Each production has a little something extra that requires a special addition to the production team. For the actors safety, we will be hiring a Fight Director for The Murder Play with Jack & Melissa. Since Lovelocked is set in Ireland, a dialect coach helps our actors speech with the natural cadence and tones of an Irish accent!
**We don't want to give anything away, but Murder Play is going to be a messy 5 day run!

What You Get
By donating at least $10 you will get a personalized discount code for 25% off a ticket to BOTH shows and a special thanks in our program! If you come see both productions, you will get a $10 savings when you donate $10.
Note: There is no perk to “claim”. Every person that donates will receive a discount code! So, you may give more than $10 if you'd like! You will receive an email from us with your individualized discount code shortly after you make your donation. 

The Impact
As you know, The NOW Collective supports the in-process generation of new work. With your help, we create an environment for playwrights to develop their plays alongside a cast and creative team. And we love giving our community a behind-the-scenes aspect of theater making. But most of all, two playwrights get to have their plays produced.

 
Risks & Challenges
The NOW Collective makes indie theatre because we weren't seeing the kind of shows that our community is craving! There was a call for new work founded in collaboration, so we became a source. We dream big and take risks, that's why we've been so successful in the past. We introduced two new kinds of programming this season, our World Premiere Productions and our Workshop Series, which have given us three new plays in our 2019-2020 season. The first, the world premiere of The Wild Parrots of Campbell, was a huge success for everyone involved! The 16-performance run at The Cherry Lane Studio Theater got raving reviews from critics and audiences. The second, is our Workshop Series featuring The Murder Play with Jack and Melissa and Lovelocked. 
We just need that final $5,000 for the Workshop Series to be successful! That's why we are reaching out to you. We understand The NOW Collective community, close friends, and family just donated back in September. We are so thankful for that! We are reaching out in case there were others who didn't get to give before or people generous enough to donate again! 

Other Ways You Can Help
If you believe in the work we are doing, please share this campaign!Follow us on Instagram! Like our page on Facebook!Visit our website and sign up for our newsletter!You can also see the shows this spring!

story:
Ironbound is a play by Pulitzer Prize-winner, Martyna Majok, that we are putting up in Los Angeles. The story takes place at a run-down New Jersey bus stop, where Darja, a working-class Polish immigrant, negotiates for her future with men who can offer her love or security, but never both.

Your contribution will not only help us put up this brilliant play, but you will also be supporting WomenShelter of Long Beach.

Proceeds from our ticket sales will be given to the shelter to help with their ongoing supportive services for women and children. 

WomenShelter of Long Beach has helped thousands of families overcome the trauma caused by domestic abuse since 1977. WSLB assists victims and their children by providing safe housing and supportive services including an emergency shelter, 24-hour crisis hotline, counseling, social services support, legal and health advocacy, and much more.

After we secure funding, we will be able to form the rest of our team and book a theatre. 

Team members we will be adding include: another actor to play Vic, a lighting designer, a sound designer, a set designer, a board operator, and stage manager. 

We'll keep you updated on our process from rehearsals through opening night. We plan on performing during the first part of 2020. 

If you can't afford to contribute to the campaign, that's ok! You can support us by sharing this campaign with a friend. Send them this link or click the share buttons at the top of the campaign. 

We're grateful for whatever help you can give. Thank you for helping us make this happen!

story:
About Us

Boundless Theatre is a new 501(c)3 nonprofit theatre company based in Frederick, Maryland. Founded in 2018 by Zachary Harris and Jacob Young, who quickly assembled a team of like-minded artists to propel the company and its mission into action. With their strong inclination for collaboration and seeing the need for a shift in perspective, they came together to create Boundless Theatre. This team includes multiple Frederick natives who are passionate about bringing their skills to the Frederick County theatre scene.  

What We Need & What You Get

We need adequate funding in order to get our inaugural season off the ground. Aspects of theatre such as renting the space, building a set, making props, renting or making costumes, and stipends are all things that every company strives to be able to do; with these donations we will become one step closer to that goal. 

  • The $3,000 gets us one step closer to being able to bring you the wonderful season we have planned!
  • When you donate you'll be eligible for one of our lovely perks!

The Impact

Your contribution will help create a home for truly exceptional theater, and support the next wave of great artists in the DMV. We are so excited for what's in store and we hope that you will be able to contribute.

Spread the Word!

If you're not in a position to contribute financially, please help us get our message out:

Share our call for help Facebook and Instagram! To learn more about us and our mission you can find us on facebook at https://www.facebook.com/boundlessthre/ and on instagram you can find us at boundless_theatre (don't forget the underscore)!

Any help you can give us in getting the word out is very much appreciated.

story:
When Texas Light Opera (TLO) was founded, its principle desire was to popularize classical work and music materials through new theatrical productions. Last year TLO was presented with multiple Alamo Theatre Arts Council Awards and Broadway World awards including “Best Musical” for its small professional touring production of “The Last Five Years,” by Jason Robert Brown. TLO now partners with Aria Creative Productions to present a unique production of Hedwig and the Angry Inch this Summer. The smash rock musical touches on themes such as love and loss, overcoming personal tragedy, the power dynamics inherent in human relationships, mental illness and issues of gender and identity.

Hedwig opened Off-Broadway in 1998 and won the Obie Award and Outer Critics Circle Award for Best Off-Broadway Musical. The story follows Hedwig Robinson (Roy Thomas), a transgender East German singer of a fictional rock and roll band, who is the victim of a botched sex change operation which has left him, now her, with just “an angry inch”. The fourth-wall smashing rock signer’s relentless search for love and her other half is performed in song and monologue in the form of a rock gig backed by her band ‘The Angry Inch’. Notable songs painting the picture include “The Origin of Love” and “Sugar Daddy”. Multi-Award Winning Actress and Director, Morgan Clyde, will play the role of Yitzhak, one of Hedwig’s love interests and singers in the band. 

The music is steeped in the androgynous 1970s glam rock style of David Bowie (who co-produced the Los Angeles production of the show), as well as the work of John Lennon and early punk performers Lou Reed and Iggy Pop.

The story draws on writer Mitchell's life as the son of a U.S. Army Major General who once commanded the U.S. sector of occupied West Berlin. The character of Hedwig was inspired by a German divorced U.S. Army wife who was Mitchell's family babysitter and moonlighted as a prostitute at her trailer park home in Junction City, Kansas.  “It’s been ten years since it has been here in San Antonio and I couldn’t be more thrilled to reprise the role of Hedwig”, says Roy Thomas, actor and co-producer.  “Our production is a conglomeration of a theatrical performance, rock concert, and standup/improv. The performers routinely interact with the audience and break through the fourth wall”, he says.

Performances will feature pre-show opening acts from local performance troupes including musicians, street performers, drag artists and burlesque performers. Vendors and local artists will sell their wares and creations in our lobby before and after the show. The Saturday afternoon performance will be a charity show benefit for Fiesta Youth, Pride San Antonio and American Veterans for Equal Rights. We hope to shine a spotlight on our local artists and charities and further help to enrich our community. A small reception will be held after each performance to meet, greet and network. The benefiting charities provide much needed social services benefiting LGBT persons and youth in our community.

From East Berlin to Junction City, Kansas and beyond, Hedwig’s story is outrageous, hilarious, and at times, unexpectedly poignant and surprisingly truthful. Hedwig and the Angry Inch is a rocking ride that’s sure to inspire anyone who has felt life gave them an inch when they deserved a mile.

What We Need & What You Get

As a small production company we need your support to that we can pay for wigs (lots or wigs!), costumes, amazing lights and sound fitting for a rock concert. Oh, and we need to transform a large church space into a trailer park and a club!  So there's lot's of set work to do! We have an amazing team of designers and can't wait to see their ideas come to life and transport our audience into the life of Hedwig! 

Check out our Perks which include original artwork by local artists. We've got buttons, lobby cards, t-shirts, foam wigs, posters, VIP seating, a cast thank you video, tickets and swag bags! 

Why Should You Fund this project? 

  • We are donating to three charities (Fiesta Youth, Pride San Antonio and American Veterans for Equal Rights) that help the LGBTQ community.
  • We are marketing to non-LGBTQ audiences to provide awareness of transgender issues, particularly in youth where suicide rates are climbing and the number of bullying incidents is on the rise.
  • We are giving back to the community by offering an avenue for local artists and vendors to display and sell their works. 
  • We have produced shows throughout Texas and have an outstanding reputation of producing quality shows in a professional manner. 
  • The production team is highly respected in the San Antonio area having over 30 years of combined stage experience.     

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute to this project that's okay! You can still help us by spreading the word! Just share this campaign with your friends with Indiegogo share tools!

story:
Short Summary

  • LEYVA'S INDEPENDANT PRODUCTIONS was created as an avenue for creative artistic expression outside the norm. 
    ​Headed by Jason Leyva, L.I.P. Service is a full service production company, theatrical company, and artistic alliance. 
    ​L.I.P. Service has continuously offered alternatives for the main stream of creative endeavors and strives to maintain artistic excellence while doing so. L.I.P. Service is proud to produce a season of shows in the DFW Metroplex as well as partnering with other companies to bring inventive theater to the community. 
    In the past 7 years L.I.P. Service has grown to become a highly acclaimed theatrical group as well as being a multi-faceted company creating sets, teaching classes and ​​working with entertainment management.
  • By contributing to our campaign you will help achieve a once in a lifetime experience for our cast to share the art of theatre at one of the most prestigious festivals in the world along with providing two students the opportunity to experience different cultures, shows and casts providing them with an unique travel and educational opportunity.
  • Our campaign is seeking assistance in funding to mount one of theaters greatest masterpieces and continue the traditions of great storytelling by spreading the benefits of live theatre beyond our region. By accomplishing this venture, our company is looking to expand its artistic alliances across the pond while taking the efforts to study and invest in artistic opportunities and shows that grow our communities awareness in the arts.

What We Need & What You Get

  • We are seeking approximately $10,000 to assist in production cost, airfare and lodging for our cast and production team.  Your contributions allow us to stage and produce the high end product you've come to expect from this award winning team.
  •  Unique perks include tickets to pre-festival performances and workshops along with company merchandise and #Edfringe swag and season tickets to our partnering supporters. 
  • All funding achieved will go directly to production cost to cover rights, travel and lodging .

The Impact

  • Engaging with art is not simply a solitary event. The arts and culture represent one of the few areas in our society where people can come together to share an experience even if they see the world in radically different ways. The important thing is not that we agree about the experience that we share, but that we consider it worthwhile sharing an experience at all. In art and other forms of cultural expression, disagreement is accepted and embraced as an essential ingredient. In this sense, the community created by arts and culture is potentially a great source of inspiration for politicians and activists who work to transcend the polarising populism and stigmatisation of other people, positions, and worldviews that is sadly so endemic in public discourse today.
  • With 7 years of award winning productions and critical praise, you support allows us to continue this tradition of impacting our community thru art.
  • The simple truth is, we need you to help us continue this artistic experience, by doing so we will strive to spread the value of your support to audiences far and wide.

Risks & Challenges

  • For 7 years we have thought outside the box to bring quality theatre to our supporters. As a company we have embraced the challenges of finding spaces and funding thru different  avenues along with investments of our own personal funds and resources. While always a challenge, we have always found a way..  
  • As we finalize production and planning, we know that we can count on our audience and contributors to help us once again achieve our goals and continue our tradition of bringing quality productions, unique experiences and artistic opportunities to those who join us for this cause. #ITSALLABOUTTHEART

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean you can't help:

  • Please help us spread the word by using your social media and personal contacts to get the message out, YOU are our best advertisement!
  • Don't forget to use the Indiegogo share tools!

And thank you for keeping our art alive.

Jason Leyva

Owner/Producer

L.I.P. Service LLC.

story:
LAST YEAR SOLD OUT! Get tickets and perks for revival now!

Become a BNW MEMBER TODAY for as little as $150 and get the BEST SEATS to see this exceptional and unique production!

 

Please help BNW fairly compensate our 10 actor cast, 9 person creative team, crew of 6 and administrative staff.

 

A classic is a classic when it connects past to present. Arthur Miller's A View From The Bridge endures because it tells a story as universal as family, as timeless as revenge, and as current as the immigration crisis.

Read about last year's acclaimed production in the

New York Times:

https://www.nytimes.com/2018/05/16/nyregion/a-view-from-the-barge.html

 

From “Scene on Stage” Review 6/11/18

"Brave New World specializes in site- specific productions, and mounting “A View from the Bridge” on a barge actually afloat on the Red Hook, Brooklyn waterfront, is inspired. The ‘Waterfront Museum & Showboat Barge’ is covered over and cleaned up some from its seafaring days, but its original weathered deck and spars are intact. One can only wish that Miller, who died in 2005, were still around to sneak up the gangplank into a performance."

 

16 years ago Brave New World Rep set out to fill a gaping hole in the cultural landscape in Brooklyn; to literally bring great stories, well acted, beautifully conceived, designed and executed into our neighborhoods, and to present these stories to adults as well as children.

If you believe in that mission, and agree that more people should see our work, please consider becoming A MEMBER of Brave New World Rep for as little as $150. You will receive the best seats in the house, and help us pay our deserving artists!

You'll also help launch our 2019/20 season including:

  • Brave New Works 2020: Ditmas Park from Jan-March
  • Shakespeare on Stratford in April 2020
  • HAMLET directed by Tamilla Woodard in June of 2020 (more details to come by the holidays.) 

 

PLEASE HELP KEEP free-to-low cost Brave New World Rep readings and productions in Brooklyn! Support theatre for the community!  Join BNW today!!
